However, I am jonesing to buy the new Led Zeppelin live CD ("How The West Was Won"). It's a 3-CD set and Best Buy has it on sale for just $16.99 this week... I have to find some way to get it. Eating : My diet has been consisting mainly of homemade hamburgers (with bacon), McDonald's Cheeseburgers, and oatmeal cookies. I'm about ready to dig into a Boston Market chicken dinner though (with my raw carrots on the side). Getting back to normal, slowly but surely. Feeling : I've been feeling frustrated and disappointed. I'm ready to be well and get on with things. Physically, I'm still feeling pretty crappy, but better than I have been as of late. My ears are still semi-closed, I'm still wheezy, and my nose is stuffy, but my energy has picked up and the sore throat is entirely gone. Planning : I plan on getting better, getting auctions listed, getting a job, getting some new musical equipment (amp and a new guitar), paying some bills, getting my own band, and getting a car. I would settle for any of these right now.

Weird Night, Weirder Mother Ok, so I tell my Mom about last night, about how I kept changing temperature, and she tells me that she turned the A/C off and then turned it back on later, in the morning. When I was having chills, she thought it'd help me if she turned the air off, but then I guess she started getting warm too, because she turned it back on later. Me, I was so out of it and disoriented, I had no idea she was doing any of this. Nice. Anyhow, I just got back from the doctor's. I'm loaded up with more free medicines including more antibiotics (Augmentin XR, which are huge) and more decongestants (Entex). I also got a prescription for more of that cough syrup with Codine, which I was hoping to avoid since it makes me too tired, keeping me all out of whack, sleepwise. I am so glad he's been giving me the freebies. I'd really be in much worse shape, financially, if he wasn't doing that. So... it looks like another week of the same old shit: heavily medicated and out of it. After the new medications run out (if they work), I can start the Allegra. I'm hoping I will feel better by Friday, at least, so I can start putting up auctions again. I wish I was well enought to jam tomorrow night; JP is bringing in a bongo player/percussionist to jam with them. I would have loved that. I talked to him yesterday, I also talked to him about that new song of mine that he had worked on and he played a bit of it for me. He not only changed the chorus structure a bit, but he changed the rhythm patterns and the flow of the song. I told him not to play that one on Thursday because we need to work on it still. The chorus he came up with was pretty bland too, and too much like everything else he's done. I want to make it better, stronger, with more soul. He doesn't put any soul into his singing, something I gots to have, and when it comes to songwriting, he really doesn't seem to understand "flow" or "groove". He's going to come over on Thursday, before practice and we're going to go over that one. We really need to start writing together, instead of him taking my songs and running with them. I've never yet been happy with the results the way we're doing it now.

Weird Night I wanted to stay up until around 11pm last night, to get my sleep pattern back to normal since I got up at a normal time, but around 7:45pm I became totally fatigued, my left arm (from the elbow down) and leg (from the knee down) began aching, and I started getting chills. I had to go to bed immediately. I had a blanket and a quilt on but was still chilled all over (except for my head and neck, which were really hot), so I turned my fan all the way down, and that still didn't help. Finally, my Mom brought me a second heavy quilt from her room and that was a little better. At 10pm, my Mom called me to take my pill, as I'd asked, and I did. An hour or so later, I got out of bed and took 3 acetominaphen pills (they're like aspirin), hoping they would help. After a couple more hours, I started getting hot, too hot, I was sweating all over, so I took the second quilt off, then I took the other quilt off and wound up with only the light blanket on and still I was sweating all over. After a few hours of this, I started feeling normal again and eventually put on my regular quilt again. I stayed in bed until 7:30am, when I had to get up and eat something. I hadn't eaten since noon the day before, so I had two oatmeal cookies and some water and headed back to bed. I don't think I slept all night, maybe off and on briefly here and there, but I was pretty much awake and conscious all night long. I think I dreampt a bit, but I was also aware that I wasn't really asleep too. It was a really strange, shitty night. I'm heading for the doctor's office again, in about an hour. I had made the appointment earlier yesterday, at the doctor's request, before last night's weirdness happened. I really hope I get well soon, and quickly ...I am so over this crap.

Memorial Day Here's how I spent Monday, Memorial Day: I woke up around 10:30 am, watched about 5 hours of the Trading Spaces marathon on TLC, ate Arby's (tried the new Pot Roast sandwich), and then went to bed around 5:30pm. Truly, a memorable Memorial Day ...not. I'm still not feeling totally wonderful yet ...I still have some congestion and my ears are semi-closed (with some hearing loss), but for the most part, I am much better than I was. As per my Memorial Day activities, I'm still not sleeping normally and I am still not getting anything accomplished. The new sleep schedule for me now is to get up in the morning, stay up until late afternoon, and then go to bed and stay there until the next morning. I've been spending about 14 or 15 hours a day in bed these last few days. I'll get tired and have to lay down, but then when I'd normally get up, I stay down (I still have a serious lack of energy). I thought the tiredness was the Codine, but I ran out of Codine a day or two ago. I am about to run out of the other two medicines today or tomorrow. Because of all the sleeping, I haven't taken my medications when I'm supposed to, so I have some leftover (I should have finished all of it today). I still haven't went back to the doctors or made an appointment to be seen. I'm trying not to, actually. I just can't afford it and I do not want to continue borrowing from Mom if I don't have to. I will give it until later this week and if I'm not better by then, say Thursday, I will go in again. I have to go in to pay my bounced check and the bounced check fee anyway. I guess that means a 3rd missed band practice as well. Nice. I haven't done any eBaying either, so I have no new money coming in. I need to get well soon so I can get paid soon. If I'm better, I may go to the flea market this weekend and set up a table. I need to do something, and quickly. Before I know it, my Gateway bill will be due again (in about 2 1/2 weeks) and I'll be scrounging for money again. Life is sucking pretty damn hard for me right now.

Not Yet Wonderful I'm feeling a little better than before; my throat is better, the congestion is greatly reduced, and my sinuses aren't nearly as bad, but my ears feel no different. They still feel like someone has inflated balloons in my ears, a lot of pressure and discomfort, and my hearing is still impaired. I've been taking antibiotics (Omnicef) since Saturday; shouldn't there be an improvement by now? I have enough left to last me until Monday, and if there's still no difference, I guess I will have to go to the doctor's again (another $55 that I don't have to spend). My cough syrup (Promethazine with Codine) is almost out, and my decongestants (Histex) run out on Tuesday. That's when I start taking Allegra. I think it's probably the Codine, but whatever it is, something has been knocking me out everyday. I am only up for about 5 hours at a time, then I sleep for 7 or 8 hours. Needless to say, I haven't been very productive. I've been watching TV, playing urlLink marbles on the PC, and playing guitar in between my "naps". I just haven't had any energy at all. Yesterday morning I was at my most active all week: I sat on the porch and played guitar for about an hour, between 7 and 8 am, then I came in and watched TV. I saw a Steve McQueen movie I hadn't seen before, "Junior Bonner", which was pretty good. I tried staying up all day, to get back to a normal sleep pattern, but it only lasted until about 2 or 3pm. I went to bed and woke up around 12:30am and went back to bed around 4am. I woke up this morning around 8:45am. I pet the cat, Stevie, who woke me up, and then I got up and had coffee and donuts. I made the coffee (and cleaned the coffee maker) while mom ran for donuts. Since then, I showered (for the first time all week), played marbles on the PC, and ate lunch. Not much activity, but at least I'm doing a little more each day. I hope I can stay up all day and get back to a normal sleep pattern, but I just took my Codine, so I don't know if I'll make it past 2 or 3pm again. I have to get a few packages mailed today too, so I need to stay up. Right now, I'm waiting on the mail, to see if I'll have any more packages to mail today. I'd like to list some stuff on eBay tonight too, some CDs and a digital camera that doesn't work (the batteries need to be re-charged). Hopefully, I can get to that tonight too, before my "nap".

Down Man Being Kicked Okay, so the doctor's visit was already an unplanned expense, but then, just to make my life worse, I bounced the doctor's check on top of it. My bank is taking a $27 fee for the bounced check, and rather than holding the check for a day, they've sent it back to the doctor's so I'll get to pay an additional $30 fee. Fuck me. I don't have any money to waste on shit like that, certainly not $57. The thing that really pisses me off is that I had the money, it was in transit (I moved it from Paypal to my checking) and it was just waiting for the bank to clear it. If they'd have cleared my Paypal money first, before doing my checks, I would have been okay. I hate my bank, maybe all banks are like this nowadays, but they just don't give a shit about their customers and they just don't use common sense. So, the pittance I made on eBay this week ($107) was pretty wasted. It's going to pay bullshit fees rather than the bills I had planned on paying with it. Now I'll have to borrow money from Mom again, which is something I desperately wanted to avoid doing, or else I'll have to start selling or pawning my belongings. Life really fucking sucks. I'm taking a shitload of medicine, but it doesn't seem to be doing much (the hearing in my ears is at about 50%, and still painful; my throat is better, but still a little sore; I'm still congested, but not as bad as before). I can't start working until I feel better, or at least until I can hear again. I'm down and life is kicking the shit out of me. Thanks, life. Needless to say, I am not a happy camper right now.

Lately, I've been... Listening to : I put on my George Carlin "Classic Gold" CD (disc 1) and fell asleep to it a couple times the past few days. My ears are still too inflamed to listen to music. Watching on TV : I haven't really been watching much of anything, or at least paying attention to much of anything, mostly sitting in front of the PC or else in bed. I did watch "Saturday Night Live" this weekend (great show...Dan Aykroyd hosted for the 1st time ever), I re-watched my favorite episode of NOVA (where they build two medieval trebuchets), and I watched a movie, "The Last Tango In Paris", which was nowhere near as good as I've heard critics make it out to be. In fact, I got bored halfway through it and was ready to change it. Marlon Brando was just plain weird in it, and the dialogue was just dreadful. Maybe that's the way people talk to each other and relate to each other in France, I don't know, but most of it made little sense to me. Also, some of Brando's improvisations, besides being weird, seemed awfully stupid, especially the part about his father making him milk cows before a date, getting cow shit on his shoes, this suppoosedly being the reason he's such a jerk in the film. Still, Brando brought a lot to his character, while the character of his lover, Jeanne, was left quite underdeveloped. There were some worthwhile moments in the film though, some great acting by Brando (when he speaks to his dead wife), but overall, I think the movie was highly overrated and fairly boring. I also tried watching "Scream, Blacula, Scream" again, but I lost interest and near the end, during the movie's climax, I tuned out altogether. Downloading : I downloaded a few Johnny Winter songs this morning. I started writing a song on guitar last night and I came up with another part to it but I felt it was too similar to a Johnny Winter song, "Mean Town Blues", from Woodstock. I downloaded it and compared it and the part is pretty similar, but is used in a different way. I don't know if I should change it or not, after all, with blues, almost everything is borrowed from someone else. I listened to tow versions of his song, studio and live, and liked them so much I downloaded a few more to check out. I don't think I've ever had any of his albums, but I may have had a cassette of his back in the '80's. I should get some of his CDs. Reading : I haven't started anything new yet. I've been struggling to get sleep lately (from my sore head/ears), and I didn't want to waste any "bed time" reading. Jamming : As I mentioned, I started wring a blues song yesterday, it's in open tuning (G) and some of it is with a slide, some not. I also sat for an hour the other night and went through all of my old songs and played many again for the first time in years. Some of my stuff isn't bad, usually the music and melodies are great, but the lyrics are always too weak, too simple and bland. I may throw a couple of them in at the next band practice, if there is one. I still havent' talked to JP about quitting yet. I'm still undecided. I think what I may do is just keep my songs to myself until I've finished them, not letting him re-write or add anything, that way, if I break away, I will still have my own material. I can accept playing in his backup band for now, but I have trouble with him putting his name on my songs, especially in cases where I'm not happy with what he's added. He wants to get the new one copyrighted already and I'm not gung-ho on that idea at all. I need to call him to let him know that I can't play this week either. My ears haven't opened up yet, still inflamed and painful, and the amplifiers would absolutely kill me, like daggers in my ears. I hope to be ready next week though. Working : As if. Because of all the delays, I'm thinking that, as soon as I'm well, I will go to Olsten Staffing, a temp service I've worked for before, and work as a temp for a bit, to get some money in quickly. Buying : I have no job, no extra money, a ton of bills, and people I owe money too...I can't afford to buy anything. However... me being the impulsive shithead that I am, I bid on and won Doyle Bramhall II's out-of-print debut CD, still sealed, for $19.50 (includes shipping). I've seen it sell for twice what I paid for it. Luckily, payment is due in 30 days, so that gives me time if I need it. Eating : My diet for the last 5 or 6 days has consisted soley of: McDonald's Cheeseburgers, biscuits (with apple butter), chicken noodle soup, and I've also been drinking a lot of hot tea, water, and Gatorade. Feeling : Like life has kicked me in the sphincter yet again. Planning : I'm planning on getting well. All other plans are on hold until then.

Doctor's Visit I just got back from the doctor's office, and it appears that my days as an amateur diagnostician are over. The white circles on my tonsils and throat are not Strep, but ulcerations caused from all of the coughing and whatnot. D'oh! I got in and out of there in a little less than an hour, which wasn't too bad. The best part: he loaded me with freebies! I got four bags of free medicine: antibiotics, nasal spray, and pills for my congestion. I only have to buy one thing, a Codine cough syrup. I mentioned that I lost my job because of all the time calling in sick, and I also mentioned that the last antibiotics he prescribed cost me $75 and didn't work, and I think he took pity on me, hence the freebies (which helps me out big time). He also gave me free Allegra allergy pills and gave me a refillable prescription for those (5 times). I talked to him a little, asking him why I keep getting sick and asking how I can prevent it. He said it's most likely allergies, which have been a problem my whole life, but hadn't been too bad until late last year (perhaps around the time we got the new cats). I hope the Allegra works, it'd be nice to get back in the flow again, instead of always falling behind.

What's Up Doc? Well, I will find out soon. I have to go to the doctor's today. They open shortly and I'm going to try and get in. Besides the congestion, the coughing, and stuffy sinuses, it hurts like a bitch to swallow and my ears are getting worse and worse, more and more painful. I keep getting feverish too. I checked on the internet last night and found that I have all of the symptoms of Strep Throat. I looked in the mirror, with the aid of a flashlight, and the back of my throat is bright red . There are also little white circles on my tonsils and throat, they look like canker sores or something, all symptoms of Strep. It's too bad I have to pay the doctor for a diagnosis when I already know what I have. I wish I could just call up and get a prescription. But that's not the real world, and I ain't Elvis. I also can't afford to go to the doctors. With no insurance, I'm going to have to borrow money from Mom, which is the last thing I wanted to do. I may have to sell or pawn something to pay her back. This sucks on so many levels, it ain't funny. I have done very little these past days, other than watching TV or playing on the computer. I certainly haven't been sleeping. I just can't stay asleep for more than an hour at a time before the throat, the coughing, and the congestion get me up. I feel terrible; run down and beaten. I was supposed to have my niece and both nephews down this weekend while their parents did something special together, but that's not going to happen now. My Mom's going up there instead. I've been doing a lot of thinking too, mostly about the band situation I'm in. I'm really leaning towards getting out now. I don't like the situation, I don't like the direction JP wants to go in (nor do I like the directions he won't allow us to go in), and I don't like his laziness when it comes to learning covers. I learned the solo to "Crazy Little Thing Called Love", but when I played it with the band last time, it sounded like total shit. I said at the time that they must not be playing something right, and his reply was along the lines of "well do something different then", rather than "ok, I'll see what's wrong and fix it". I looked into it myself and I think they're playing the first part of the solo section wrong. Instead of playing Bb-D, I'm pretty sure they're playing G-C, which totally throws the solo off. I really dislike his lack of professionalism in that area, and the lack of commitment to the music. I also don't like the additions/changes he's made to my songs. I had hoped he'd make them better, but he usually makes them more common sounding. I want to get to a whole 'nother level, musically, but I don't think I'll get there with this band. I may not be ready to play with the band this week because of my ear infection and Strep Throat (which is highly contagious), but I should be back the week after. I will have to have a talk with him sometime in between. He won't be happy, especially since it looks like we're finally going to have his old drummer playing with us, but I told him it would be a see-and-decide-later situation with me when I entered into it. Who knows, maybe he'll have a change of heart... or maybe I will. I guess we shall see.

Le Miserable That would be me. I haven't slept yet, even though I tried to sleep several times last night. My ears are absolutely killing me, throbbing, plus I can't breath well, I'm coughing a lot, phlegmy (I hate that word: phlegm...yuk!), wheezing like mad, and now I've developed conjuctivitus or something in one of my eyes (it may have spread to both as everything looks hazy to me right now). I'm a fucking mess. Earlier, yesterday, I got dizzy a bit and nearly fell over, probably because of my ears. Mom brought home McDonald's cheeseburgers, my "sick food". Everytime I get really sick, that's the only food I want to eat, comfort food, I guess. She also brought home some Ginger Ale and 7-Up for me. I mostly sat in front of the TV all night (I finally watched "Orange County", which was pretty decent... very funny individual performances throughout), until 1am when I tried to go to sleep on the couch. I just couldn't get comfortable there, so after an hour or two, I got up and went to my bed, and tried to sleep again. I started getting really hot and the wheezing was driving me mental and I just couldn't sleep. After an hour or so of trying, I got up again and watched TV. Around 6:10am, I had my mom take my temperature, since I couldn't figure out how to read our stupid thermometer when I tried earlier. She had the same trouble that I did. It's nearly impossible to read, really poorly made. On her first try, she said I was about normal, but the second time, she said it was right about 100. Both times, it took her almost a full minute to read it, so I'm thinking my temperature might be higher. I certainly felt like I was burning up. I put a cold compress on my head and took some aspirin and tried to sleep, but here I am, up again, and still awake. Shit. I've said it before: I am sick and tired of being sick and tired. I wish I knew why I get sick so frequently. I wonder if it's our air vents (in 30 years, I don't think they've ever been cleaned out or replaced), or whether it's something in the air (we live next to a highway, plus, across the street is the dump, where they burn trash all day and night). All I know is that I've had this same illness 3 or 4 times this year already and that just shouldn't be. It even happens the same way each time, with the post-nasal drip/sore throat/stuffy nose phase, to the heavy congestion/runny nose phase with the earaches (from all the coughing and nose blowing). It seems like I keep getting the same exact thing over and over again and I wish I knew why so I could prevent it. In the meantime, I will be out of action for a few more days at the least. I'll tell you what: if I'd gotten a new job already, I'd be screwed...big time.

Frankenstein As I mentioned in my previous post, I am feeling pretty shitty. I decided to go to bed early, 2am, as I had begun feeling even worse. I started reading a book to help me get sleepy, but I guess I picked the wrong book because here it is six and a half hours later and I just finished reading the entire book . I can't believe I read the whole thing! The book I chose, as you might surmise from my heading, was Mary Shelley's "Frankenstein". It wasn't an easy read because of the language of the period, but it was an enjoyable one nonetheless. Quite different from what I'd expected. Having seen several of the old "Frankenstein" movies, I'd assumed the book was going to be similar, but it was much, much different. I heard the last Frankenstein movie, the one with DeNiro in it, is supposed to follow the actual book, whereas the others got the Hollywood treatment (totally sensationalized and only vaguely similar to the book). I can't see DeNiro as an eight-foot tall monster, but I can see why they chose him, after all, his character in "Cape Fear" is very similar to the monster in the Mary Shelley book. I will have to check that one out. I guess I will go and try to sleep again, though with the throbbing in my ears and the inability to breathe through my nose very well, that may not be such an easy thing to do. I don't know which book to start next: "Les Miserables" or "Lord Of The Flies", but I have a feeling I'm going to begin one of them shortly.

Lately, I've been... Listening to : Except for a few things I downloaded on the computer the other day, nothing at all. Between my toothache and my earache, I've been in the mood for silence. Watching on TV : "Tough Crowd", "Everybody Loves Raymond", "The Simpsons", and "Seinfeld", the NBA Playoffs, "Inside The NBA" (with Ernie, Kenny, and Charles...more entertaining than the playoff games), "The Osbournes", "Jackass", "Fear Factor", and "Trigger Happy TV". I'm pretty disappointed in the new "Trigger Happy TV" episodes. The original British series was outstanding, always clever and ballsy and funny, then they went and Americanized it, and now it's nowhere near as good, in fact, at times, it's pretty stupid. By the way, I'm usually doing stuff on the computer when the TV is on, so I don't actually watch TV as much as it seems I do; it's usually just on in the background. Downloading : After the Ben Harper concert, I downloaded some of his stuff, rare stuff I hadn't heard before (covers, live performances, whatever...). I haven't done anything since then, though, like I said, I've been in the mood for peace and quiet. Reading : I started and finished "Proof" (by Dick Francis) this week. It was a good book, interesting, exciting at times, and well written, but I kind of guessed where it was heading and the wine and horse racing stuff, though interesting, didn't really hold my interest. It would make a more exciting TV show, in the Columbo vein. I'm not sure what I'll start next, but the way I'm feeling, I should be in bed a lot this week and will want to read something. Jamming : I cancelled out of practice for tomorrow. I haven't practiced all week either, because of my ears. They feel clogged, have since the last practice. I'm sure the concerts haven't helped either. I talked to JP tonight. He worked more on that new song I started last week, even made a slight change to the music (which shouldn't hurt anything). He may practice with Al anyway. He was talking about going into the studio again in June and re-recording some stuff and maybe recording some new stuff, including the new song I started. He said when he goes in, he'll do it all under his name, not the band's name, since he's footing the bill. I'm not sure what that's all about; is he being vain or is he hinting that me and Al should contribute money to the studio project? I'm confused. I'm in a weird situation with him anyway, and this just muddies things even more. I'm in his band, doing his music, and his choice of covers... it doesn't feel as much like a real "band" than it does a "backing band". If we're really a "band", then I think we should all have a fair say in what we do "as a band". We still haven't worked in any of the covers I suggested, but we've learned new ones he's throw in since. I'm getting frustrated already. I just have to remember that playing in a backing band is still better than not playing at all. I think I need to work harder on putting my own band together. Working : I listed auctions this week, but I still haven't begun looking for an actual job yet (aside from scanning the newspapers). My sleep schedule is still out of whack, with me going to sleep sometime after 8am and getting up sometime after 5pm, so unless I change that, I will remain unemployed. Buying : I broke down and bought that Otis Redding 3-CD set the other day and then I bought my Mom a purple purse for Mother's Day. I haven't bought anything besides those two purchases. Eating : Mostly TV dinners, Stouffer's BBQ chicken strips and their nasty ass Lasagna (sucks bad). I had been on an Oatmeal cookie kick, but sadly, I ran out a few days ago. Must...get...more... I'm thinking about making a BLT tonight, but that will take some effort, and I'm not really in the mood to put out any effort. I might just go for another TV dinner... Feeling : Like shit. My throat, sinuses, and ears are bothering me a lot. My jaw is still sensitive due to the bad toothache I've had all week, and I feel a headache coming on. Like I said, like shit. Planning : I'm planning on eating something and then going to bed sometime afterwards. I also plan on getting up sometime tomorrow. That's about it for now.

Mother's Day For Mother's Day this year, my mom got the house to herself all day (I went to bed around 6:15am), I bought her a purple leather purse on eBay (she's a purple freak), and I watched my two nephews while my sister, brother-law, niece and mom went out to dinner at my mom's favorite restaurant (Arigato). I woke up & got out of bed when they all got here. I re-loaded Beachhead 2000 on my computer for my older nephew, Jesse, and put the "Spiderman" movie on for the younger one, Austin. This bought me enough time to wake up and get myself something to eat. I made hamburgers for me and a hot dog for Austin. After chow, I took the kids outside to play for a bit. I played catch with Jesse (whiffle ball plus plastic scoops to catch with) and Austin "killed ants", his favorite pastime, with a spray bottle filled with warm water and dish soap (we probably have the cleanest ants around). It was hot and humid outside, so I decided to try something with them that I used to do when I was a kid, something fun that would keep us cool: I make a poor man's slip'n'slide for them. I taped 3 trash bags together and hosed them down with water, then poured dishwashing liquid all over the bags, making them slippery. The kids loved it. They were sliding and flopping all over the place. I was spraying them down the whole time too. After awhile, everyone came back from dinner and came around to see what we were up to. One of my sister's friends, who we both grew up with, Jenny, showed up with her daughter. I wound up hosing everbody down, then I had the boys flop into mud and told them to go hug everybody. It's good to be an Uncle. I hosed myself down too and hugged Jenny, my sister, and my niece. After we got changed and dried, we went in and me, my sister, Dana (my niece), and Jesse, looked through family photos for awhile. We went out and put on an old family video for Dana. I found a tape from when she was around 10 years old and was acting like a total dork and wanted to show it to her. She was so embarrassed, she couldn't believe it! They all left around 8:30pm. Once again, I got into an argument with the younger nephew. I'm glad his mother actually took my side this time. He was picking his nose and I told him to use a Kleenex (which was maybe 8 feet away from him) and he responded by making a smartass face at me and sticking his finger up his nose even further. His mom jumped on him for it and then he went off and pouted. His mom said to just ignore him. He kept staring at me like I did something mean to him, and then he started talking shit about me ("I don't want to see Gary's face anymore...he's mean...he's a jerk!") as he left to stand by the front door. And then he started mocking everyone while we were watching and laughing at the video. Neither his mom or dad did a thing about it, so I yelled at him and told him to cut the shit. I hate always having to be the "bad guy", but goddamn, someone has to discipline him. Finally, his mom set him straight, told him to come back over there and stop acting like a jerk, explaining that I was was right to tell him to stop picking his nose. I hope she keeps doing that, otherwise he's going to turn out to be a jerk when he grows up, not respecting anyone. I love my family, but they really piss me off sometimes.

Ben Harper Concert Last night was terrible for me. My toothache got worse and worse all night (like a dumbass, I kept messing with it). The weird part: the tooth that aches is actually a crown, not a real tooth. I'd had a root canal several years ago, so there shouldn't even be a nerve there, but it is incredibly painful and sensitive right now. Do nerves grow back? I tried going to bed early, but only stayed down a few hours. I got up and got my mailings ready and goofed around for awhile. Around 4am, I got back into bed and started reading "Proof" a book by Dick Francis. I got tired and tried to fall asleep, but after a bit, I had to get up again to put some Orajel on my toothache. It was after daylight when I finally fell asleep. I kept going in and out of sleep all day. I started worrying, that between the toothache and lack of sleep, I wouldn't be able to go to the concert. I forced myself to stay in bed until 6pm. I wasn't tired, but the toothache was causing my jaw and ear to hurt. Regardless, I got up and got ready to go to the show. I'm very glad I did. JP arrived about 20 minutes later than he'd planned, but we got to Ruth Eckerd Hall and were in our seats in plenty of time. The opening band, Mofro, came out and promptly knocked me out. They were great! I had downloaded some of their stuff the other day to check them out, but their CD does them no justice. The singer played some wild ass harmonica, very reminiscent of Robert Plant's playing on some of the early Zeppelin albums, and had a great, bluesy voice. Their keyboard player had a very Doors-like sound on a lot of songs. The whole band was great, really. They played for about an hour. After their set, JP ran out to the lobby and bought their CD (as well as Ben Harper's first CD as well). I'll bet he's glad he did that now. After the stagehands cleared Mofro's gear off the stage, Ben and his band, The Innocent Criminals came out. Wow! What a great show! Ben was in very good voice, and his guitar playing was excellent, but what really blew me away was when he sat down and played the slide guitar. He was just phenomenal. His bassist took two solos during the show and was impressive (very, very funky). The percussionist was really something special too. Hell, the whole band was great! They played: Don't Take That Attitude To Your Grave Excuse Me Mr. I Shall Not Walk Alone Brown Eyed Blues Temporary Remedy Everything Ground On Down Sexual Healing Steal My Kisses Diamonds On The Inside Touch From Your Lust Alone So High So Low Burn One Down 1st encore: Please Bleed Walk Away Waiting On An Angel Roses From My Friends Pleasure and Pain Blessed To Be A Witness 2nd encore: With My Own Two Hands/War They played about 3 hours, including 2 encores! For the first encore, Ben came out alone and played a short acoustic set. It was great getting to hear him play like that. Right before he went into "Waiting For An Angel", the sound system went out. He played anyway. With no amplification, we all had to be absolutely silent so we could hear him. That was really something, a very strange and beautiful thing. Leave it to one asshole in the back to try and ruin the moment for everybody. Ben, heard almost as a whisper (or a prayer) was singing this really beautiful song, and some jackass yells out "Louder!!!", to everyone's disgust. During the next song, the same idiot yells out "The best slide player ever!!!" He yelled it again and someone else yelled out "Shut up a-hole!!" ... I swear I saw Ben flash a brief smile at that. Thankfully, the system came back up again, so only 1 1/2 songs were interrupted. After a few more acoustic songs, the band came out and joined him again and they played several more songs. At the end of the set they thanked everyone again and it looked like the end of the show, so everybody started heading out. I saw that they hadn't turned anything off onstage yet, nor had they brought the house lights up, so JP and I hung out a little longer. Glad we did: they played a 2nd encore! They did "With My Own Two Hands" with a bit of Bob Marley's "War" mixed into it. After the show, JP headed out to the back, to try and get an autograph. There were about 20 or 30 of us out there, but people began leaving after an hour or so. Eventually there was just JP, me, and six others (two couples, two other guys). Ben's percussionist, Leon Mobley, came over and talked with us and signed things for some people. He seemed really nice, shaking everyone's hand and chatting with us. We saw Ben come out and go to his bus and one of the guys yelled for him to come over and he said he would. Maybe ten or fifteen minutes later, he did. What a great guy. He was very gracious and friendly, thanking all of us, shaking everyone's hand, and signing things for everyone. He signed the cover of his "Welcome To The Cruel World" CD that JP had just bought between sets and he even signed the CD itself (without JP asking him to). I usually don't ask for autographs myself, but I had him sign my ticket stub. He hung out and talked for maybe ten minutes. He was talking about how he liked seeing a nice cross section of people at this show (the older, Ruth Eckerd season ticket holders mixed with people my age and the teenage crowd) and said that he had even had several generations of one family at one of his recent shows. I said something like "yeah, good music can cross any boundry" and he seemed genuinely appreciative of that (he even made a point to shake my hand again before he left). Pretty darn cool...

No Power, No Luck I went to bed early last night as planned, at 1am, but I didn't get to sleep until around 9 or 10am. Almost as soon as I laid down, the electricity went out. Without the fan next to my bed or the a/c running, my room got stuffy very quickly. I just could not sleep. I tried, for a good hour and a half, but eventually, I had to get up. I went in to check on my mom, to make sure her alarm clock wasn't going to get screwed up. She seemed concerned, so I lit some candles, grabbed the phone book for her and she called the power company. The power was out for my neighborhood and the surrounding businesses (very strange sight, sort of like that Twilight Zone episode where Burgess Meredith finds himself all alone after a nuclear blast), but they said it would be back on by 3am. It didn't come back on until 4:30am. In the meantime, I played guitar. I sat outside with it for awhile, then came in and played a bit (by candlelight). I came up with some song ideas and lyrics for an older song. I was dead tired by then though. I tried to lay down on the couch, it was cooler in the living room than in my bedroom, but a minute or so after I laid down, the power came back on. I went over and turned my computer on (to make sure the outage didn't harm it), but that was a mistake. I wound up playing urlLink the marble game until sometime around 8am, when I finally went to bed again. I had a very hard time sleeping, even though I was tired as hell. I got up around 2:30pm. My alarm was set for 2pm, but instead of getting up, I just laid there. I did get up eventually, after I remembered that an eBay auction I was watching was going to be going off very soon, an Otis Redding 3-CD set. I got there with 11 minutes left on it, and won it for $11 plus $3 shipping. It is brand new, still sealed, and the seller is someone I've dealt with before, so I know it'll be well packaged and mailed quickly. After that, I went out to check the mail and I found that they tried to deliver a package I had been waiting for for a couple of weeks (2 Hendrix CDs), but I hadn't been up to sign for it, so now I have to go pick it up or wait until Tuesday or Wednesday to have them re-deliver it. Yay. I had also missed the bug lady, our exterminator, who had been here sometime after 1pm. My mom didn't leave the door unlocked for her or leave a key, even after I told her I probably wouldn't be up when she got there, so she only sprayed outside, not inside where we really need it. That's two misses, here's the third and shittiest of them all: I found out I had won a pair of tickets to the Ben Harper concert from the Weekly Planet website, but since neither me or my mom check our answering machines messages very often, I learned this only an hour and a half before their offices would close for the weekend. I had to pick them up, in Tampa, by 5pm or else lose them. I lost them. I called all of my friends and family, but couldn't reach most of them or else they couldn't do it. That could have been a lot of fun. I was going to give a ticket to who ever picked them up and give the other one to my nephew, so he could see his first concert. Shit.

Lately, I've been... Listening to : I had Ben Harper's "Burn To Shine" CD on today...great album! I'd forgotten how good it was. I can't wait to see him live on Saturday! Woo hoo! Watching on TV : Right now, an old "Monty Python's Flying Circus" is on, but I'm only half-watching it. This week, the only show I've really been watching is "Tough Crowd with Colin Quinn". Reading : I read "Once A Warrior King" by David Donovan earlier this week. It's the story of his time spent in Vietnam as a "military advisor" to the local Vietnamese fighters. Very interesting read, and from a different perspective than I'd heard before. Jamming : We jammed tonight with Jimmy, the drummer from the old incarnation of this band. I don't think he'll be back next week (he's going out of town), but we may have him back after that. He's better than any of the others we've played with. We played a new one that I came up with earlier today and JP added lyrics to it. It sounded really, really good and everyone dug it. I think it's called "Get Back Home" right now, but JP may change the lyrics still. We really didn't do many originals tonight. JP's "As Low As It Gets" and "Promise You The Moon", which I changed again.. more singing at the beginning, no more guitar part. It's coming together slowly and is sounding better all the time. We also did his GAB song, but I would like to work on that one more. Since the chord changes are all G-A-B in the verse and chorus, I'd like to make each section sound more distinct. Plus, JP does this little lead line, a signature lick for the song, but he's only doing it once, as an intro, and I think he needs to do it again. We did a ton of covers, butchering some, kicking ass on others. We added a couple of older songs to the mix, "Feelin' Alright" and "All Right Now", plus I threw "After Midnight" out and we jammed on that one too. We also played Sheryl Crow's "If It Makes You Happy" and a Sister Hazel song (not sure what it's called). We did "You May Be Right", "Old Apartment", "The Way", "Before You Accuse Me", "American Girl", "Stuck In The Middle", and "Crazy Little Thing Called Love". I finally learned the solo (mostly) for "Crazy Little Thing Called Love", but when I played it, it sounded way off. I think the music they're playing beneath it was wrong, maybe in the wrong key. I'll have to check on that. It was disappointing. I thought I had finally nailed it. It was a pretty loose practice tonight. Al and I even jammed on several of the riffs that I kept throwing out. It was pretty loud too. Jimmy plays pretty loud, and I found myself turning up a lot tonight to match him. I had some sound problems tonight, I kept picking up radio on my guitar or pedal (maybe the combination of the two). Weird... Working : I haven't started looking yet. Next week, hopefully. I got up earlier today and I'm going to head to bed earlier tonight, so I should be getting back on track. I have my scanner, I'm online again, so I will have to list a bunch of auctions this weekend, well, Sunday anyway. Got that concert to go to on Saturday night. I might list some tomorrow. I really need to get some money flowing in. Buying : Nothing. I owe everybody and don't have much coming in, so I've resisted tha temptation... so far. Eating : Little Debbie oatmeal cookies! I had Arby's tonight (roast beef sandwiches). The rest of the week I've eaten: a Boston Market TV dinner (country fried chicken), eggs, waffles, hamburgers, corn, keilbasa, and tomatoes. I'm dying for something good (translation: something bad for me) like pizza or Stavros again. Feeling : Tired, out of it. I have a headache coming on too (my ears are sore from the noise level tonight). Planning : My plans are pretty much the same as last week. Food, TV, Spiderman, MTV, A Birthday, & More Food What a boring night. I ran around a little this afternoon, to the post office, to the bank, and then to Stavros for my greek salad and a gyro, then came home and chowed down. I'd been jonesing for a Stavros Greek salad for days. After that, I played around on the PC for awhile and then I wound up taking a nap sometime around 7pm. I got up around 8:30 and then I half-watched "Oceans Eleven" (the remake... pretty good movie... I'll have to watch it again though). I was going to watch "Saturday Night Live" tonight (it was a live show tonight), but I absolutely HATE HATE HATE the guy who was hosting this week, Ashton Kutcher (an untalented prettyboy), so I boyotted the show. Instead, I watched "Spiderman" ... finally. I just may have been the last person in America to have seen it. I thought it was ok, there were some cool parts, but then there were some parts that just made me scratch my head and ask "why" or "how". For instance, where did the high tech Spidey costume suddenly come from? Surely it cost more than the $100 he got from the wrestling match, and he didn't get a job until well after the Spidey costume appeared, so how did he get it? I didn't think the Green Goblin made much sense either. He had Spiderman alone on a rooftop and could have killed him, eliminating the only person who could have destroyed him, but instead, he tries to get him to be his buddy? Didn't the Goblin already kill a bunch of people whom he considered threats? And yet, here he has the greatest single threat to him, isolated and vulnerable, and he lets him go ? Ok....whatever. My other complaint was the action scenes, the computer animation. Other movies have done much more realistic jobs with the computer animation, the last Star Wars for instance, but a lot of the scenes in "Spiderman" looked almost like they came from an arcade game and just weren't very convincing. The physics just weren't true to life and you can't convince the eye any diifferently. It was an okay movie, but they should've worked a little harder to get everything just right. Anywhoo... I have to go to bed again shortly, gotta get up a little earlier tomorrow to head uo to New Port Richey for my nephew Jesse's birthday. He'll be eleven tomorrow. I asked him if there were any CDs he wanted (I love giving music). He surpised me and asked me to get him a Scorpions CD... how cool is that? Everyone else his age is listening to the typical MTV dreck, just like his sister (I think my niece is beyong saving, musically ...MTV and BET have her soul), but my nephew has promise. I always feel like Yoda talking to Luke Skywalker when I talk to my niece about music "trust not the MTV, young Skywalker, for evil it is." But my nephew already has CDs of Dio, AC/DC, Dokken (all stuff I got for him), and now he wants some Scorpions. It's still a long way off from Hendrix, Dylan, the Beatles, and other classic bands, but it's a start. Beats the shit out of Eminem, 50 Cent, and Brittany Spears. We're all supposed to go out to Red Lobster for dinner tomorrow. I hate doing that though, because his grandparents always end up buying for everyone. They're rich and can afford to do that, and I guess his grandmother enjoys doing it too, but I always feel like a mooch having them pay for my meal. It'd be nice to be able to return the favor sometime, but neither me nor my Mom can afford to do it. I hate being in that situation, so that's bad, but on the plus side, I'll be eating Red Lobster for dinner . (kicking it Homer style) Mmmmmmm......(drool).....lobster.

CSN Woo hoo!! I got to see Crosby, Stills, and Nash play live tonight (at Ruth Eckerd Hall) and they were absolutely fantastic! What a great show! The seat I had was awesome too; almost dead center and only 13 rows back from the stage. JP had an extra ticket (his wife decided she didn't want to go, not her type of music) so I took it. I'll have to pay him back for it though. It was $83, but well worth it to me. We arrived late, JP was running behind schedule, and CSN were already onstage playing when we got there. We didn't miss any songs, luckily. I found the set list on urlLink their website : Carry On/Questions Wild Tales Marrakesh Express The Lee Shore Deja Vu Military Madness Wasted On the Way Wounded World Dirty Little Secret Almost Cut My Hair Southern Cross 15 minute break Helplessly Hoping Cathedral In My Dreams Feed the People Lost Another One Ole Man Trouble Guinnevere Half Your Angels Our House Dark Star Wooden Ships 1st Encore My Country Tis of Thee Woodstock 2nd Encore Teach Your Children They sounded great, all three of them. They looked good and looked like they were having a great time onstage, especially Crosby, who joked around a lot. His voice is still extremely strong, and Nash's harmonies were always right on the money. Stills was hard to understand when he spoke (he sounds like a cross between Marlon Brando and Bob Dylan nowadays), but his singing voice and guitar playing are still great. I was in awe, especially when I paused to think about these guys, about their history. Individually, these three guys have been in some of the best bands of the sixties: The Byrds (Crosby), Buffalo Springfield (Stills), and the Hollies (Nash). They played at Woodstock together (along with their sometime bandmate, Neil Young). Stills was friends with (and jammed with) Jimi Hendrix. He even had Jimi play on his first solo album (as did Eric Clapton). Nash knew Hendrix as well, and was present during the recording sessions for Jimi's "Axis:Bold As Love" album (he even made "footstomping sounds" on one track). Nash was also friends with George Harrison. One of the songs they did tonight, "Lost Another One", was dedicated to "the quiet Beatle". He also played with Joni Mitchell, as did Crosby. Crosby's played with Bob Dylan, the Jefferson Airplane, the Grateful Dead, and many others. Wow. That's a lot of musical history there. Absolutely awesome. And then, if all of that wasn't impressive enough, the guy they had playing keyboards, Mike Finnigan, played organ on Jimi Hendrix's masterpiece, "Electric Ladyland". Holy fucking shit. Awesome just isn't strong enough a word. Great musicians, great show. JP was much cooler to go to a show with than my sister and brother-in-law. We had a good time and even hung out afterward (he wanted to try and get autographs). We saw them all come out and get into their buses (each had their own) but they didn't come over to sign or talk or anything. That stuff didn't matter much to me; I was satisfied with just seeing and hearing these guys play live, in person. Woo hoo!! By the way, I found a guy who put up pictures from urlLink the Zebra show I attended last Friday . I don't know how long the photos will be up or how long the link will be good for, so check them out while you can!

urlLink Saturday 8 What's the one memory of your childhood that makes you laugh everytime you look back? I wrote about this a few weeks ago, but it's the one that makes me laugh the most, so here it goes again. It was the time me and my friend, John Paul, covered the side of his mobile home with dog shit. We were out in his yard trying to play soccer, but there were piles of dog shit all over his yard (he had two big dogs) and it kept us from enjoying ourselves. I remember that I got a stick and flung a pile from the yard onto the side of his trailer ... and it stuck! We both laughed our asses off at that. It was so funny to us that we began going around the yard looking for more piles of poo to fling onto the side of his home. Before long, it was dotted by many, many piles of dog shit. His home looked like a chocoloate chip cookie. Needless to say, his parents weren't nearly as amused as we were. In fact, they were pretty pissed. Befuddled and pissed. I got sent home immediately and JP had to hose off the trailer. I think he got grounded too. Still, a very funny memory to me. Everyone had a favorite toy, pet, blanket, etc. What was your favorite thing as a kid? My teddy bear. I got it when I was a baby and I still have it today. It's missing an eye and some fur, but it's still with me. What was the most idiodic thing you did when you were a kid? I wrote about this in greater detail a few weeks ago as well. It was the time me and my friend, Mike, moved a newspaper box into the middle of a highway. I had wanted to move it onto the median, to confuse and irritate the newspaper delivery man, but Mike let it drop halfway across the road and took off running. A few minutes later a car hit it. It was a really dumb and thoughtless thing, but it wasn't my intention at all. As far as I know, the driver was not hurt, though his/her car must have had some damage to it. Who was your best friend as a kid? John Paul. Also known as JP, John, and Paul. We've been friends for about 28 years. He's like a brother to me. We're still friends today, but not as close as we once were (we grew apart a bit during High School when he moved away). Besides being my best and oldest friend, he's also my bandmate. Is there anything that you did when you were a kid that you still do to this day? For example, you might have a bad habit of biting your finger nails. I'm keeping my bad habits to myself! I have enough going against me as is! Who did you look up to as a kid? I don't think I ever had a role model or anyone that I looked up to as a kid. What was your favorite snack as a kid? I have no memory of a favorite snack, but I absolutely loved Chef Boyardee Pizza. My Great Grandmother used to make it for me and my sister when she'd babysit us. She was a wonderful woman. I wish she'd lived long enough for me to get to know her. My sister and I have fond memories of her. What's your fondest memory as a kid? Probably the summer I went up to Pennsylvania by myself. It allowed me to get away from the turmoil in my own home back in Florida, but more importantly, it allowed me to get to know my grandparents, aunts, uncles, and cousins. I have a lot of great memories from that time. I also gave the opportunity to appreciate how wonderful a place it was that I had come from. I may have lived in Florida nearly my entire life, but Pennsylvania is my true home.

Change If you know me, you'll know that I've been doing a whole lot of soul searching lately, trying to figure out who I am, what I am, and what I should be doing with my life. I keep having these nagging feelings that I should be out there, doing something, anything, to help make the world a better place. Now, I'm not so egotistical that I think I can go out and change the world all by myself, in fact, I've had serious doubts about whether or not it was even worth the effort. I mean, how can a song change anything, really? This brings me to Graham Nash. I saw Crosby, Stills, and Nash in concert earlier this year, and since then, I've visited urlLink Graham Nash's website several times. I noticed that he has a message board on his site, where he can, and does, communicate with his fans. He's someone who has put politics and social issues into his music for many years, someone who's fought for many good causes, and I thought he might be able to answer a question I had... so I left him a message on his message board. To my amazement, and to his credit, he answered me. Here it is: Hello Graham, I'm a musician and I am having an internal struggle of sorts. I have the feeling I should be doing something, saying something about the world, about America, about politics and other issues of the day, rather than just singing songs about love (finding it, losing it, being in it).The problem I have and the question I'd like to ask you is: do you think singing songs about these things can actually change anything? Gary GN: Any time you put your heart on the line things will change. You, the world around you. Take courage and get working. Silence is agreement.... Best, Graham Beautiful. With such few words, he managed to say a lot. "Silence is agreement." Wow. You know, it's funny he said that, because lately, I've been listening to a lot of urlLink Bill Hicks' material (man, we could really use a voice like his now), and his message was similar, that we've become sheep in this country, silently accepting whatever is thrown our way. Many of us don't like the way things are going with our country but by being silent about it, we are essentially agreeing to every bit of it. In fact, we are encouraging more of the same. I don't want to be a sheep anymore, I want things to change... so I am changing. I just have to figure out what my strengths are. Music? Writing? Humor? It's going to take some more work and soul searching to figure it all out, but I am going to do it, I am going to find a way to speak out, and I am going to try and make a difference. I am a man on a mission. Thank you, Graham Nash.

urlLink Monday Mission 1.What is the difference between spirituality and religion ? Spirituality is believing in something you can't see, but keeping it within yourself. Religion is believing in something you can't see and trying to make others believe that they can see it too. I dislike religion in a big way. 2. What is the difference between someone listening to what you say and hearing what you say ? There should be no difference, but I know that sometimes I'll listen to someone speak and realize later (sometimes seconds, sometimes hours) that I didn't hear a word they said. Their words didn't enter my brain, just bounced off my head. It usually happens because the person speaking to me has ignored the fact that I was busy with something else at the time and decided to talk to me anyway just because they felt like talking. When people talk, it should be a mutual thing. 3. What's the difference between a Father , and a Daddy ? There's probably a good Catholic priest joke in there somewhere! As Father Flannigan said to the alter boy, "just call me Daddy". Too bad I couldn't find it. Anyhow, to answer the question, to me, there is an implied difference between the two. "Father" sounds strict, like a disciplinarian, distant, cold, whereas "Daddy" sounds soft, caring, and affectionate. I think being a "Daddy" sounds more enjoyable, but you have to have some "Father" in there to keep the kids on the right road. 4. What's the difference between being married and living together ? Committment. Marriage is a lifetime committment, while living together is always having an open escape route. I'm not sure how I feel about living together before marriage. I guess if you're unsure of how much you really love the other person or of how much tolerance you have, then it might be for you. If it can prevent a possible divorce down the raoad, then it has some benefit to it. . 5. What's the difference between growing up and growing old ? Well you have to "grow older" to "grow up", but "growing older" and "growing old" aren't necessarily the same. Growing "old" means nearing the end, whether it's a boring activity or someone's life. 6. What's the difference between getting what you want and getting what you need ? For something to be considered a "need", it must make a difference in their life, in their wellbeing. A "want" is everything else. 7. What's the difference between punishment and discipline ? "Punishment" is the penalty a person receives for doing something wrong. "Discipline" in training that person not to do anything that would merit punishment. BONUS: Can you hear me calling you? Sorry, I had the stereo up too loud. You just can't listen to AC/DC quietly. Today's Comment Question: Do you eat breakfast, or just skip it and wait for lunch? I usually skip it. By the time I get up, it's lunchtime anyway.

I Found Something To Say In my mind, for awhile now, I've had an idea for a different way of life, a life in which no one person can ever possess more money than he will ever need or spend, while others go homeless. Should CEO's be paying themselves million dollar bonuses while their companies are failing? Of course not. Should anyone be out of work while others work mandatory overtime? If workers earned more or if the cost of living were less, why couldn't those hours be shared? If workers controlled the means of production, and if wealth was distributed fairly and equally, no one would be homeless or jobless, no one would be left behind and forgotten. I have had ideas about giving the government back to the people, of cutting the fat cats and their corporate masters out of the equation, and I think I've found the answer. The funny thing, it's been here all along. The answer? Socialism. urlLink Albert Einstein supported it , so I know it can't be too far from the right answer. I found a site that shares my views on the government and religion, and offers more insight into Socialism than I can. urlLink Click here for some info. Capitalism works really well for the ones with money, the rest of us work for those people. That's why the rich continue to get richer, and the poor continue to get poorer. Socialism is human oriented, it's looking out for one another rather than trying to screw each other trying to get to the top. There is a lot of discontentment in America today; we know we're not going in the right direction, and a lot of us want change. Here it is. More people need to educated about it, they need to learn that urlLink Socialism is not Communism , that Socialism is not anti-American, and that Democracy and Socialism can co-exist in a Socialist Democracy. Do yourself a favor and at least look into it.

Something To Say I get the feeling I should be doing something, something important, but I have no idea what. I've thought about writing a book, doing stand-up comedy, writing songs, etcetera...but I have a big problem: I have nothing to say. That's not entirely true, what I really mean is that everything I have to say has been said before, and by people who could say it better than I ever could: Bob Marley, Jimi Hendrix, John Lennon, Bill Hicks, George Carlin, and many others. But even then, having things to say and saying them doesn't mean much unless something changes because of it. Unfortunately, nothing ever seems to get accomplished by mere words alone. Action, that's where it's at, but who wants to stick their necks out and be a martyr, especially if no change would actually come of it? Our country is in an awful state, the world is in an awful state, and everyone seems to know it already. Would one more voice change anything? Would one more martyr mean a thing? It's like those monks who burned themselves to death during the Vietnam War; they didn't change a damn thing, and in the long run, they died for nothing. Footnotes to the Vietnam War, that's all they became. Still, I feel like I should be doing something, and I've had that feeling for a long time now. I wonder if a lot of people feel the way I do. I think it would be great if we could get together and take our country back from the millionaires, billionaires, and corporations and give it back to the people, make the government work for us again. But where do you start? It seems the only way for there to be a change is through revolution, revolution of the mind, and revolution in the flesh. But how does that begin? Could it start with one voice? One martyr? I suppose these are dangerous thoughts, but these are dangerous times, are they not? I, for one, am tired of working my ass off and barely getting anywhere, busting my ass to make the rich folks richer. I'm tired of being a sheep. I'm tired of not saying things that I feel need to be said.

urlLink This-or-That Tuesday 1. Newspapers or magazines? I tend not to read either. When I want some news, I put on CNN, and when I want any other info, I go to the internet. 2. Books-on-tape or regular books? I've had a book-on-tape, some Tom Clancy novel, for about 5 or 6 years and I still haven't put it on. Maybe if I had a car, I might listen to it in there, a little every day, but it's just too long to hold my attention. 3. Paperback or hardcover? I like paperbacks because more because I can buy used ones really cheap and because I don't care as much about damaging them, casuing wear and tear, because they're usually easy enough to replaceable. Hardbacks are fine too, but I'm always worried about messing them up, damaging their spines. 4. Fiction or non-fiction? I have no preference really, a good book is a good book. 5. Sci-Fi/Fantasy or romance novels? Sci-Fi allows you to use your imagination, taking you to different worlds, exploring technology. But romance novels? They're nothing but soap operas in a book, junk food for the brain. 6. Borrow from library or buy books (either new or used)? I like to buy my books, mainly because I never know when I'm going to feel like reading. 7. Subscribe to magazines or buy on newsstand? I used to subscribe to a lot of magazines, but I don't have any subscriptions right now. Money is tight, plus, the internet gets me most of the info I would want from my magazines anyway, and without any trees having to get chopped down for paper, which is a definite bonus. 8. Current best-sellers or classic literature? Classic literature. I never read much when I was younger, so I have a lot of classic literature to catch up on. 9. Lost In A Dream World Weird night last night. I went to bed around 6pm, dead freaking tired, but I wound up playing guitar and writing lyrics instead of sleeping. I got up again around 8:30pm turned on the PC and TV and zoned out for a few minutes before deciding I just had to go to bed again. I got up to take three Tylenol PM's just as my Mom got back home. When I woke up today, I thought I had dreampt all of that, and about letting her in the front door and helping her carry groceries in. As soon as she was in, I took the pills and went to bed right afterward. I slept pretty good, getting up only once to pee around 6:30am. I dreampt a lot, strange dreams too (including some swinging neighbors that I don't have, a wandering boy named Toby, and a crowded hallway and bathroom that was supposed to be mine). I heard a song in my dreams, something called "Golden Ships" or something like that ("Golden Skies"?), and I dreampt that I learned how to play the song (E and A were the chords, the A having a descending major line). Unfortunately, after I woke up, my mind turned to trying to remember whether or not I let my Mom in the night before or if I'd dreampt that; I never got the chance to bring the song into the real world before I forgot how it went. One is called "(I Love A) Rainstorm", another called "My Eyes Betray Me", and a third that I don't have lyrics for. That one is a blues, a real Delta Blues sounding song with some cool guitar parts. What if you had to choose whether to die in one week, or, starting tomorrow, live your life backwards until you cease to exist (meaning, you wake up tomorrow and it was two days ago, and the next day it was three days before that, and so forth, through your entire life, until before you were born)? That's a strange one. Would life make still make sense to me going in reverse? I mean, if actions have reactions and then you reverse it, wouldn't you continually be dealing with the outcomes of things that haven't happened yet. Everyday might seem like a new crisis and you'd probably feel like you had no absolutely control of your life whatsoever. I don't see any point in going backwards, it goes against everything we are as human beings. I'd constantly lose everything I've ever learned and I'd never be able to change anything because what's happened already will happen tomorrow. I hate to say it, but I think I'd choose death over life in this case because life in this instance would likely be a life of utter madness and confusion. 2. What if you had to choose whether to die tomorrow, or live out the rest of your life as a tree? I'd gladly live out my life as a tree, swaying in the breeze on some mountainside, preferably. It'd be a new experience, that's for sure. 3. What if you had to choose whether to, starting next week, live out the rest of your life alone in Antartica (with enough supplies to last but zero hope of rescue or escape) and be allowed one day of "going home" per year, or agree to go with the friendly aliens that landed in your backyard to explore other worlds for the rest of your life without ever once returning for even a visit? I'd choose the alien scenario over the Antarctica scenario for sure. In fact, I'd choose that over almost any scenario you could offer. I think it would be truly awesome to travel through space and explore the unknown. It'd be an honor to be chosen. 4. What if you had to choose whether to be imprisoned five days per week for the rest of your life, or contract sudden, incurable amnesia, and never remember who you really were or see anyone you loved again? This one needs a qualifier: would prison sex be part of the prison deal? If so, I'd opt for the amnesia. If I had to have my ass continually pounded by prison thugs, I'd pray for amnesia anyway. If it was solitary confinement, then I'd take the prison option. 5. What if, upon your death, you had to choose whether to unsuccessfully roll that big boulder up that hill in Hell for eternity, or simply cease to exist? I'm a lazy bastard, so I'd choose non-existance over hard manual labor most of the time anyway.

urlLink Saturday 8 What if a million dollars fell off a back of a truck. Would you keep it? If no one saw me take it and if the money wasn't traceable... HELL YES. For one thing, if you have a million dollars and are stupid enough to allow it to fall from a truck, or even allow it to be in the position where it could fall off a truck, you don't deserve it. What if you were most powerful person in the world. How would you use that power? I would try to do good for people, try to make everyone's life better, not just my own. I would set limits to how much money and property any one person could possess, I'd make people share the wealth. However, I would certainly see to it that me and mine lived very well. Without religion, peace in the world would almost be possible. What if you could take one thing back. What would that one thing be? The urlLink Friday Five 1. How many times have you truly been in love? Grrrr....I don't like these questions. Several times. I'll leave it at that, since the result is still the same: me, alone. 2. What was/is so great about the person you love(d) the most? Since I didn't end up with any of them, it's hard to consider any of them the person I loved the most. I'll just speak of the last girl I fell for, and what I liked about her most was her smile and the way she laughed when I'd say something funny. Grrrr... next question. 3. What qualities should a significant other have? She should have a great sense of humor and intelligence, She should be soft, strong, patient, loving, caring, romantic, and up for almost anything fun. She should smell good, have kind eyes and a pretty smile. But, most important of all, she should love me, really love me. She should also be real, not imaginary. Next question. 4. Have you ever broken someone's heart? Me? Well, maybe once, when I was a teenager. I used to talk to a friend of my sister's on the phone a lot and we always got along well. Eventually we met in person. We talked, held hands, and liked each other just fine. Then, the next day, on my birthday, we went out to the movies together and all she did was eat, eat, eat. She was a fat girl, and me being a fat guy, I just didn't want to be with someone who wasn't as ashamed and embarrassed of being fat as I was. I was embarrassed by her. It was really my problem, though, I know that now, but I wasn't mature enough to deal with it then. She was really nice to me too. She really liked me a lot, and I think I just might have broken her heart. I don't know for certain though, since we never really spoke again. I believe my sister told me that the girl eventually slimmed down, because of me, she said. Too bad I couldn't have seen past my own deficiencies, we may have had a good time together and maybe even slimmed down together. 5. If there was one thing you could teach people about love, what would it be? Women always complain that men are jerks, but they're the ones who make it possible for jerks to thrive. They create more jerky guys in the world because they always choose the jerk over the nice guy. Therefore, I would teach women this: start going for the nice guys in the world. You do that, then soon the jerks won't have any women to be jerks to. They'll have to start changing their jerky ways or be alone. If you keep going for the jerks, and I guarantee you this, there will never be a shortage of jerks in the world. Women shouldn't settle for anything less than a man who will treat her right.

Oh, I showed Al that Allman Brothers-like song I came up with but he thought it was too much like one of theirs. I guess I'll can that riff, but I might be able to work something with the rest of it. Working : Not working still, but I'm dying to get out there and get looking for a job. I have to get my sleep schedule back on track first.
