urlLink 3 For Thursday There is no new one this week, so I'm using last week's questions: Topic: Growing Up 1. What were 3 Summer Night games you used to play growing up? Kick The Can was a big one, as was Capture The Flag. We also played Kickball out in the street, more of a day game, but we played it into the night as well. 2. What were your 3 favorite board games to play? Checkers and Monopoly was it for me. I don't remember playing any other board games. We had Operation and I loved playing Battleship whenever I could, but they're not really board games, are they? 3. What were 3 mischievous/fun things you used to do? Three? You don't know me very well, obviously. I did tons of fun/mischievous things, I wouldn't know where to start. I can tell you the three most bizarre things I ever did for fun though: 1) Me and my friend JP were out in his yard one day trying to play soccer or something. Our play was impeded by the many, many piles of dogshit in his yard (he had a couple big dogs at the time), so we cleared the field by taking a stick and flinging the poo off the field, which was a good idea, and onto the side of his trailer, which probably wasn't such a good idea. We must have had about 20 or 30 piles of dogshit sticking to the side of his house before his parents discovered what we were doing. They could not believe we were doing this, they were totally mystified, and very pissed. 2) I live along a busy highway, with a ditch and a fence separating the road from my backyard. As a kid, we used to throw things over the fence at the cars. Not a very smart thing to do, looking back, but great fun at the time. Besides throwing the obligatory fruits and vegetables, we'd hollow out potatoes and fill them with every condiment we could find, a nasty mix. Myself, I enjoyed throwing weird stuff, stuff no one would ever expect to fly into their car in a million years. I'd throw whole loafs of bread or unopened packages of hot dogs, always aiming for the open window and sometimes actually getting in in! Again, these people probably could not believe we were doing this, they were likely mystified, and probably pissed. I know my Mom was. She'd come home and half the food in the house would be gone. 3) I liked doing things that were strange and absurd. One time, I wanted to move the newspaper box from the front of my park to the median strip of the highway, just to confuse and piss off the newspaper guy (I guess confusing and pissing people off was my thing). So my friend Mike and I were moving it, probably around 2 am, and we were halfway across the highway when Mike dropped his end and ran off giggling. I couldn't move it myself, so I dropped mine and ran off too. Someone at the corner trailer had heard us and I saw their curtain open, so we hauled ass from the roadside. As we got around the corner I told him that was pretty stupid and asked him "what if someone hits it". Just as I was saying this, there was a very loud crash followed by very loud screeching and squealing. We turned toward the road, knowing immediately what had happened, and saw the top of a car lumber past us, with a wall of sparks 10 feet high in front of it. They drove like that all the way down the road. We were scared shitless. We knew we were going to get busted for sure, after all, someone had seen us and everyone one in the neighborhood surely heard that ungodly screeching. Mike ran all the way home and I ran into my house, quietly as possible, and went straight to my bed where I yelled "Mom! What was that noise?", trying to create an alibi for myself. She said something like "I don't know....go back to bed". I kept an eye out, from my bedrom window, and I kept my ears open, listening for an ambulance (I had no idea whether someone had been hurt or not). Eventually, I saw a police cruiser come down the street into the park. He drove slowly, and right past my house. I thought it was all over for me. Strangely enough, we never got caught, in fact, we never heard more anything about it, except from our friends in the park the next day, who asked if we'd heard that loud noise. One kid heard it and he lived five blocks away. My guess is that the driver was drunk, I mean it'd be hard to miss a giant newspaper box in the middle of the road. And since there never appeared to be any investigation, I assume the police thought the driver had hit the box in their drunkedness. It was more scary for me than fun, but it was definitely mischievous, even though it wasn't intended, by me, to be as dangerous as it turned out to be. 4. What were your 3 most favorite toys? Do you still have any of them? How can "3 for Thursday" have four questions? I'm freaking out here, man! Anyhow, to answer the question/s, my favorite is probably my teddy bear. I got him when I was a baby, up in Pennsylvania and I still have him. He's missing an eye and some fur, his blue ribbon is long gone, but he's still here. My Big Wheel was a toy that I loved to death. Man that thing was fun! I wish I had a Big Wheel now, though it'd have to be much larger. I don't know what other toys I would consider a favorite, most simply came and went, the Star Wars stuff, the GI Joe stuff, etc... If my bike counts, then I'd choose it. I loved riding it through puddles, jumping off of it at full speed like a stuntman, popping wheelies...good times.

urlLink Wednesday What-Ifs? 1. What if you had to wear one item of clothing every single day for the rest of your life? I think I'd wear a loose-fitting robe, like what Jesus wears in all those pictures of him and like they still wear in Arab countries today. It'd keep the sun off me when I'm outside and it would cover all the naughty bits, yet it would still be cool and unrestricting. Ahhh... 2. What if you had to stay in one town/city and never step foot outside its lines for the rest of your life? I'd move the hell away from here, that's for damn sure! My first thought would be to choose New York City, since it has so much that appeals to me (museums, entertainment, nightlife), but Asheville, North Carolina is awful tempting too since it has a lot of cool stuff (music, arts) and it's got much more nature to enjoy (the best of both worlds, almost). I really love my hometown of Cochranville, Pennsylvania too. It's small, not a whole lot to do, but life is enjoyable there, peaceful. Tough one. I guess I'd choose Asheville. NYC is just too crowded and expensive and Cochranville is just too small and not varied enough. 3. What if you had to eat and drink only one kind of food and one kind of beverage for the rest of your life? Mexican food & iced tea. 4. What if you had to pretend to be someone else for the rest of your life? Would it just be me pretending around here, or would I actually possess that person's life and fill their shoes? If it's just me pretending around the house, I'd say Jimi Hendrix, since I'm a guitar player and I consider him the greatest guitarist ever. If I had to have someone else's life, complete with all of their possessions...well it wouldn't hurt to be a rich guy, someone living a life of luxury. Hugh Hefner or Bill Gates, perhaps. Hefner's old, but he's still got the life . Bill's got the money to have the life if he wanted it, so either of them would be fine with me. 5. What if you could only have one of your five senses (touch, sight, hearing, smell, or taste) for the rest of your life? Sight. I figured it'd be hearing since I'm a guitar player, but without the sense of touch, I'd probably be a lousy guitarist. I love being able to see, and I think I'd miss that more than anything else. People, their reactions & expressions, smiles, women, art, TV, butterflies, clouds, snow falling from the sky, birds in flight... I'd miss seeing life more than I'd miss touching it, hearing it, smelling it or tasting it.

urlLink This-Or-That Tuesday 1. Cats or dogs? Cats. Dogs are fine, but they require more time, work, and patience. Cats are good pets for lazy people like myself. Plus, they don't slobber all over you or try to hump your leg. I have a strict "no humping" policy when it comes to my pets. 2. Butterflies or birds? Awww... I know it doesn't sound real manly, but I think both are beautiful. I guess I'll go with butterflies though, since I've never seen a Hitchcock movie about menacing butterflies. 3. Horses or cows? Cows. They're both big and powerful, but I think, if it came down to it, I could take a cow, whereas a horse might be able to kick my ass. Plus, cows have that whole "steak" thing going for them... little do they know. 4. Turtles or snakes? I really wouldn't want either as a pet; reptiles don't do anything for me. I guess if I had to have one as a pet though, turtles are the more entertaining animals to watch. They eat, they walk, they swim, they stick their heads in and out of their little shells. Snakes eat and sit there. Plus, some snakes are poisonous, which sucks. In fact, the prospect of a rattlesnake crawling into my sleeping bag has totally put me off of going camping. Who needs to wake up with a pair of fangs in your ass? A kinky vampire, perhaps, but not me. I'd only have to worry about turtles if I went skinny-dipping in a pond filled with snapping turtles. 5. Frogs or grasshoppers? Frogs eat mosqitoes and I hate those little blood-sucking bastards, so definitely frogs. 6. Lions or tigers? Both are awesome, but Tigers have vibrant colors and they also have that whole striped thing going for them. Gorgeous animals. It'd almost be an honor to have such a beautiful creature rip my throat out. 7. Elephants or mice? I don't think I'd want either in my house. Here's how I see it: an elephant could easily kick my ass, whereas I know I could kick the shit out of a mouse, even the most badass, Steven Seagal-like mouse you could find. But on the other hand, mice give me the creeps (especially that Mickey bastard) and I could ride on an elephant and stomp on my enemies. Hmmm..this is a tough one. I will go with the elephant because, in my neighborhood, people will hassle a guy who has mice, but no one messes with a guy who has elephants. 8. Porcupines or aardvarks? Who the hell would want a freaking porcupine? That's a pet for S & M freakos only. The only thing I could possibly do with a porcupine is chuck it at someone I hated. I'd definitely choose the Aardvark. Besides not sticking you with sharp, pointy quills, they eat ants and I don't like ants. I'm very anti-ant. 9. Unicorns or dragons? This is a trick question. You didn't say whether the dragon was friendly or not. I wouldn't want a dragon that would kill me and my family and destroy my village, you know? I would want one that obeyed me, one that would fly me wherever I wanted to go (to work, to 7-11, to the Super Bowl), one that would barbecue chickens for me with his fiery breath, and one that would destroy all of my enemies (that means you, Mike, you prick). He'd have to be house-broken too, because there's no way in hell I'm cleaning up dragon doody. That all said, if the dragon isn't friendly and won't obey me, then I'll take the unicorn. They're boring, they won't destroy my enemies for me, but they're decent chick magnets. 10. Thought-provoking question of the week: You live in a rather dumpy apartment. A friend offers you a chance to be a roommate at a new place s/he is moving into, but they don't allow pets. You have a pet. Do you find your pet a new home and take the new place, or do you keep your pet and stay put? That's easy. I'd forgo the new apartment. I can't stand people who abandon their pets, especially when they've had the pets for years. That makes me sad. I'd like to climb upon my dragon or my elephant and destroy those people.

My Hairy Shower Buddies Ok... I'll admit it, right here, right now, for all the world to see: I shower with hairy guys... regularly. Of course, those hairy guys are Jimmy and Stevie, my two male cats. Jimmy, my chubby black & white cat, has been joining me during my showers for awhile now. Sometimes, even leads me to the shower, the same way he'll lead me to their empty food bowl, like he wants me to turn the shower on for him. When I'm in there, Jimmy usually sits on the ledge, outside the shower curtain, and will peer into the shower to see what's going on in there. I usually play with him by aiming the shower head at the curtain and he swats at the streams as they hit the curtain and sometimes he falls in the tub! Today, I noticed, he swatted at the stream while his tail and one leg were fully in the tub, getting soaked! He didn't seem to mind at all! Sometimes I'll stand under the shower so that the water will trickle down my arm to my fingers and I'll drip water on him. He usually just drinks the water. My favorite cat, the late Fluffy, did that too. Fluffy would also swat at the drips as they'd fall. I still miss Fluff a lot. Jimmy also licks the water off the curtain and spickets as well. His brother, the smaller gray cat, is a lot less daring. Stevie usually stands off and observes, but today he got up on the ledge and got a little wet. His tail especially. He didn't go for the streams though, so I poked at him through the shower curtain and he'd bite at my finger, but he'd rather run off then risk falling in the tub. The little chickenshit... My friend JP has a wacko cat that actually loves showers. I'd never heard anything like it. JP says the cat runs around inside the shower, under the water and everything! I wonder if Jimmy will eventually get to that point. That'd be kind of cool. The only downside might be that he'd start wanting his own private showers and by the time I'd get mine, there'd be no hot water left!

On The Horizon... We're supposed to pick up Jesse, my older nephew, tomorrow night (which, I guess, is actually tonight ). He's going to stay until Sunday night. I had wanted him down for a full week, just like last year. I kept asking my sister about having him down and she never bothered to get back to me about it or make plans with me. Hell, she never even asked him if he wanted to come down like she said she would. So now, with school less than two weeks away, with his football season beginning, and with him having company next week, I only get him for four fucking days , with only a single day to prepare for his arrival and plan things we can do. I guess I'm lucky to get him for the four days; my sister didn't even try to work with me on having my niece down this year (she spent a week down here last year). My sister's really been pissing me off for awhile now. It seems like she'll bend over backwards for her wealthy in-laws, but when it comes to her own family, me and Mom, it often seems like she could care less how we feel. I like seeing the kids and doing stuff with them, so does my Mom, but my sister lives an hour away from here so we don't get to see them much. However, quite often, my sister comes down this way to go to the beach with the kids and she doesn't even show us the consideration of stopping by to say hello... even when I've asked her to. She's always too busy, too inconvenienced... everthing's a hassle with her. She even quit exchanging birthday and Christmas gifts with me, saying she doesn't think it's fair that she be expected to buy me something when she can't afford to. Christmas, I can understand: she's got three kids to buy for, so it's not that big a deal to me (I still bought her gifts anyway, not expecting anything in return), but not giving gifts on birthdays is too much. Birthdays are about the person whose birthday it is, it's their day to feel special, to feel loved. You just don't blow off the birthday of someone you love, it's not right. On my last birthday, she came down here and went shopping, buying stuff for her, my niece and my younger nephew, but she couldn't even see fit to pick out a $10 CD for me. It's not that I feel like I have to have more stuff either, it's about seeing the little joys in life taken away, the family stuff, the traditions, the considerations. They say it's the thought that counts, and it's true, but it seems like my sister's becoming more and more thoughtless all the time. Enough about her... it bothers me too much, makes me angry, and there isn't anything I can say or do to make her change her ways anyway. I talked to JP tonight too. Jimmy, the drummer, isn't going to make it to practice this week. This is not good at all and it really worries me. He's only available one day a week, and sometimes, not even that. If the band starts doing well, his lack of free time could stall, and possibly prevent, the band's progress and success. I would like to be getting together at least twice a week to play. We're progressing at a snail's pace. JP wants us to go into the studio in a month and we've barely played together at all! JP, Al, and I are going to get together on Thursday (at Circle) anyway and try to tighten up our rhythm and try out some new ideas (mostly mine) with the songs JP wants to do in the studio. I was going to bring Jess along, but now that's it's mostly going to be working and arranging, I don't think that'd be a good idea. Maybe Mom can take him swimming that night.

WTF!?!? Man. I think I've been hacked. Around 4am, as I was shutting down for the night, I suddenly started having weird PC problems, mainly with Explorer. Things started freezing up, then a deleted item wouldn't delete, so I restarted my PC and it wouldn't start up right (the screen looked like safe mode, with the big icons and stuff). I hit con+alt+del to see what I had running and there was something listed as "unknown" in there. I immediately shut off my PC and as it was shutting down a strange box appeared on the screen. I caught the word "frequency" and saw numbers spinning by and quickly pulled my cable modem plug. Next, I started up again (it still looked like safe mode, but wasn't) and went straight to Kazaalite and downloaded a firewall. I thought for a minute and then decided to do a system restore and that straightened out the big icon/safe mode deal. I had to reinstall the firewall again, but I'm up and running and everything looks normal again. Whew!

On The Issues Wow! I just found a great site that I thought I'd share! It's called " urlLink On The Issues ". It lets you see how all of the 2004 presidential candidates (and all other elected officials) feel on the issues based on their voting record and on comments they've made. It's really a fantastic tool for learning and research. I'm still researching all of the candidates for the upcoming election and I want to be sure to support the right person. Right now, urlLink I'm supporting Dennis Kucinich . In my opinion, he is exactly the kind of person we need in the Oval Office. For instance, here's what Kucinich said about the economic divide in this country: Economic inequality is the result of two and a half decades of government policies and rules governing the economy being tilted in favor of large asset owners at the expense of wage earners. Tax policy, trade policy, monetary policy, government regulations and other rules have reflected this pro-investor bias. We propose the introduction or reintroduction of a package of legislative initiatives that will close Americas economic divide and address both income and wealth disparities. The concentration of wealth is a problem because it distorts our democracy, destabilizes the economy and erodes our at our social and cultural fabric. Too much concentrated wealth leads to too much concentrated power and begins to undermine our participatory democracy. Unfortunately, I don't think he'll be able to get the Democratic Party nomination since he's so progressive (like there's something wrong with that). You never know though, sometimes longshots pay off. Either way, I'd like to find a "backup candidate" to support, just in case. Most of the others are just so middle-of-the-road, politically, though... I guess I'm off to " urlLink On The Issues " to do some more research.

Stupid Corporate Automatons I was busy all night last night listing auctions on eBay (I listed 79 of them last night, a personal record) and today I receive an email that they've cancelled several of my auctions because of a violation of policy within my auction descriptions (which has been in my item descriptions all year). The violation was this line: "I accept Paypal (for cards ending under $2, winning bidder agrees to add $0.30 to the price to cover Paypal costs)" The reason I had that line in there was because a lot of my auctions (the majority) were ending at $1.00, of which eBay takes $0.40 (the $0.35 listing fee + a 5% ending price fee) and Paypal* takes another $0.30 (minimum), leaving me with a "profit" of about $0.30 per card, which is not even a "profit" at all, since I paid $1.00 or more for most of my cards. I put the $0.30 Paypal fee in there so I'd make at least $0.50 per card. That's fair enough isn't it? Well, apparently to eBay it isn't (or whomever reported me to eBay). It's a violation of their rules. Ok, no problem: their site, their rules. I went and edited the "offending line" out of 118 auctions, which was a time-consuming pain-in-the-ass, but hey, their site, their rules. The thing that really burns me up is this: none of my auctions can end for less than $2 anymore. I now start them all at $2 or $3. The offending policy violation isn't even applicable . So, in reality, they cancelled some of my auctions for nothing, and I can't just re-list them because I deleted the scans from my computer, so now I'll have to re-scan them all too. Bastards! I miss the old days when people used common sense and discretion. Too many huge corporations, too much automation, not enough dealing with people and their problems on a one-on-one basis. They didn't have to cancel my auctions. They could have just emailed me and asked me to take the line out. I certainly would have complied. But no... rather than using some common sense, or showing me some courtesy, they just zap my auctions like it's nothing. Nothing but my time and my effort. *Just to note: Paypal was bought by eBay awhile back, so in reality, if I sell a card for $1, it's eBay, the corporation, that gets $0.70 of the dollar, leaving me with a measly $0.30. Nice, huh?

urlLink Monday Mission 1. Have you ever had, or known someone who has had, a "Mid-Life Crisis?" What happened? Is there such a thing or is it just an excuse? I haven't, no, and I'm not sure I know anyone who has. I know there are people in the world who use it as an excuse to behave like assholes though, cheating on their spouses and whatnot. 2. Have you ever had a dream so vivid, that you woke up with certain emotions towards a person for what happened in your dream, even though they didn't do a thing to deserve it in real life? What did you feel and and what was the dream? No, I can't say that I have ever had that occur. 3. How do you express your creativity? Have you ever made money from it? I make music and I also write (in my blog) a lot. I also use my creativity when my niece and nephews visit, trying to think up fun stuff to do with them. I have made exactly $1 playing music so far. 4. Has anything you created ever been stolen? How did you handle it? Not that I know of, no. 5. Do you think downloading music via file sharing is "stealing?" Is taking songs without paying for them any different than someone taking your work without your permission? No, I do not feel that just downloading songs is stealing. If you can listen to songs on the radio and TV, why not on your computer? The only difference is, I'd get to decide which songs I hear. However, if you burn the music to disc, then I'd say that is stealing because you have the music in the same format intended for consumers to buy. 6. How do you feel about the RIAA targeting everyone (parents, teenagers, grandparents) who share songs over the Internet with expensive lawsuits? Should they be selective in who they subpoena, or should all who violate copyrights be treated equally? Or are they going too far? Should the music be free? The RIAA are a bunch of greedy scumbags. They don't want to change with the times, so they try to sue people to keep things the same. The thing is, times have changed and so must they. The RIAA is anti-technology and anti-consumer. There is no good reason a CD should be almost $20, other than pure greed. 7. On the same thought, what do you think pay-per-song concepts such as iMusic and BuyMusic.com? Will they succeed? Is this the solution? If not, what is? This seems to be what the public wants, but I still think there should be a division between songs downloaded just to check out and songs downloaded so I can burn them to disc or put on an MP3 player. I don't think I'd want to pay .99 per song if I'm just going to listen to it once and say "nah". BONUS: Why can't we be ourselves like we were yesterday? I was myself yesterday, who were you?

Me & My Cats I'm pretty annoyed. Someone left me a crappy note on my zonkboard, saying that I treat my cats badly (now deleted), and it really pissed me off. I shouldn't have to explain myself to some stranger on the internet, but I can't just let their assumption that I'm some kind of an "animal abuser" slide by without a reply either. So here: I do not treat my cats badly. I feed and water them, care for them, I pet them and play with them, and I give them both plenty of attention, each and every day. They are healthy, happy cats. Do I get pissed off at them every now and again? Absolutely. One of them likes to get into stuff he shouldn't and the other is very destructive (to the point of being anal about it). Should I just let the cat chew on items he finds on the dinner table, when he shouldn't even be on the dinner table in the first place? Should I simply allow the other one to dig all the way through the backdoor frame (I can see daylight through it now) or tear up the carpeting in the hallway completely (he's got the fringes shredded already)? No matter how much you love your pets, you have to stop them from doing shit like that, and sometimes that involves yelling at them, chasing them out of places they shouldn't be, and smacking them. I certainly wouldn't do anything to hurt them though, and I don't appreciate being judged as some kind of animal abuser. I would love it if I never had to do any of that stuff, but sometimes I have to, because they have to learn not to do that shit anymore. I'm also a bit hurt that this person read through several pages of my blog, staying on for more than 24 minutes reading it, and didn't have a single positive thing to say to me, choosing instead to make a negative, ill-informed judgement upon me. That's not cool at all. It's like they overlooked anything good about me to focus on one single incident that I wrote about (I was angry and blowing off some steam), and which they took the wrong way to begin with. Thanks for that.

urlLink Weekly Wrap-Up Topic: Physical Injury 1. Describe a childhood memory in which you sustained a physical injury. It doesn't have to be a serious injury, only one that you remember distinctly. What happened? I remember when I was in elementary school, there was an elevated bar which I was supposed to run up to, jump, and grab. I ran up to it, jumped, and the next thing I know, I'm looking at clouds. I missed the bar and landed, hard, on my back. I had to go to the hospital and get X-rayed. I was stiff for awhile, but the pain eventually went away. 2. If that particular memory was not about your worst physical injury, what was/is? What made it so bad? My worst physical injury involves my back again. I hurt my back at a job when I tried moving a very heavy skid with a palette jack that wasn't designed for that particular type of skid. Someone in the warehouse had used the wrong one, so when I went to pull it, I pulled it with my back rather than with the jack. I had to go to the doctors and missed a bit of work. Eventually I quit that job, but the back pain never fully went away and sometimes it flares up really bad (like now, for instance). 3. How well do you handle pain? Have you always had a high/low tolerance? If so, when did it change? Ok, I guess. I mean, I go on living, dealing with it... what else can I do? I deal with it on an almost daily basis. I should be used to it by now, but it's still an aggravation to me. I think I handle actual pain better than I do the annoyance and inconveniences caused by the pain, not being able to do certain things, limited motion, stuff like that. 4. Do you take external medicines when you are hurt? Why or why not? Do you try/use alternative therapies? Why or why not? Of course! Why suffer when there are products to help you get better or to suffer less? Never tried any alternate therapies though... I wouldn't know what to try. 5. Describe a time when you were hurt and it wasn't as serious as you thought. How did you feel before and after? A couple of months ago I had a terrible, extreme, pain in my side that limited my movement and I was sure it was a kidney or my liver or something like that. After several days, the pain started lessening and eventually it went away. It was probably a puilled muscle. I was concerned, then relieved.

The Friday Five 1. When was the last time you cheated? I don't like cheating, in any form or for any reason. I'd rather win on my own merit, pass a test with my own intellect, and as far as relationships go, cheating is something I simply could not do. I mean, how could you ever face that person again, knowing that you'd betrayed their trust? The last time that I actually did cheat on something was earlier this year, when I was playing a computer game (Beach Head 2000). I used a game cheat for unlimited life, to keep the game going; I didn't feel like starting over again and again, everytime I got "killed". 2. When was the last time you stole? Ummm... about three months ago, when I was still working at Wendys. A chicken nugget here or there, a frosty once in a while, maybe a sandwich on the sly. I have no guilt about it whatsoever. They cheated on their food costs, so the little stuff here and there that employees too was no big deal. 3. When was the last time you lied? I don't know. I really don't like lies and I hate lying to people. Pretty much the only reason I'd lie at all anymore is to protect someone's feelings. 4. When was the last time you broke or vandalized another's property? About three months ago, at the Zebra concert, when I accidentally broke a chair. I was standing next to the chair I had been sitting in before the show started, and I put a foot up on the seat and it busted through. I don't know whether it was half-broken already or whether it was my doing, but either way, I didn't tell anyone about it. Being a fat guy, I didn't want the additional embarrassment. 5. When was the last time you hurt a loved one? I try not to do that ever. I don't think I ever do it intentionally, but a few months ago, I did do it unintentionally, though I wasn't wrong in what I did. My nephew, Austin, who is five years old and very spoiled, tore my Mom's bedroom door off the hinges and I yelled at him over it. His mother, my sister, immediately jumped in with crap like "he doesn't know any better" and "it wasn't his fault". She made me look like a jerk for disciplining him, so he took it that I was being abusive towards him for no reason at all. For a long time afterward, he hated me, said I was "mean" and that I hurt his feelings. I'm sorry, but a five year old kid has no business doing anything that could tear down a bedroom door. I jumped on him because his mother didn't. If he had been my kid, he would've had an ass beating to go along with the yelling, so he'd remember never to do that again. But then, I'm "mean", so, whatever...

This Election May Be Rigged/Vote Kucinich Anyway OK, I had my Mom do the urlLink political candidate test (see the post below) and her #1 match was Kucinich too, which is incredibly unlikely since her politics are much different than mine. Is the test rigged so that Kucinich comes out #1 everytime? Has anyone had a different #1 selection? Regardless, I looked over Kucinich's politics on urlLink his website and I have absolutely no doubt that he is the person we need to lead the country. He says things that the others wouldn't dare and he wants to change things the others wouldn't want changed (because it would affect their own financial interests). Here's what he says about Labor, for instance: "Labor has stood almost alone while corporations have cut wages and benefits, slashed working hours, tried to undermine wage and hour provisions, reneged on contracts, and jettisoned retirements through bankruptcy strategies. The current clamor for corporate accountability calls for honesty in stating the numbers, and faithful custody of shareholders money. Yet there needs to be equal concern for those who created the wealth through their labor because the attacks on unions are a means of redistributing the wealth upwards. As union membership has declined, the disparity of wealth has increased. Since 1973 union membership has dropped from 24% to 14%. Congress has not passed an increase in the $5.15 minimum wage even though the inflation adjusted minimum wage is 21% lower today than in 1979. It's sickening how greedy and hoggish the corporate scum in this country have become, hoarding the majority of the wealth and giving their workers as little as possible. Why not look out for your fellow man, rather than looking into how much you can screw him out of his share of the pie? That shit really pisses me off. I'm going to do what I can to fight for what's right.

Also, there isn't a lot of instrumentation in the song, which would leave a lot of us standing around twiddling our thumbs (we are a sextet right now). Anyway, I worked on learning a ton of cover songs today, played for a couple of hours, and then I sat at the PC and looked up tablature/sheet music for a bunch of other cover songs, stuff I'd like to cover, stuff I think the band could pull off well. Some of the songs I'd like to try are "Bertha" (the Los Lobos version of the Grateful Dead song), "One Time, One Night" (Los Lobos"), "Alone" and Steal My Kisses" (two Ben Harper songs), "32-20 Blues" (Robert Johnson), "Hey Hey What Can I Do" (Led Zeppelin), "What's So Funny About Peace, Love and Understanding" (Elvis Costello), and "She's Tight" (Cheap Trick). I would really like to learn Cheap Trick's "Reach Out " too (I've never seen anyone cover that one), but I couldn't find any music for it. I'll have to learn it by ear. So anyway, I did that pretty much all afternoon. Later on, I scanned a bunch of basketball cards and listed them on eBay. I was interrupted by a phone call from JP, who was returning my call from earlier in the day. I had worked on my solo for his "Promise You The Moon", extended it and cleaned it up, and I wanted him to hear it. He really didn't say much, so I'm not sure what he thought about it. We talked about music and the band for awhile. After we hung up, I went back to listing cards, finishing up around 10:30pm, and leaving me bored shitless. There isn't jack on TV (I had missed "Minority Report" while I was listing cards) and it's too late to practice songs (Mom's in bed), and I've checked all of my usual internet haunts, and now I'm bored to death. Maybe I'll read something. I've been wanting to start on "It" (the Stephen King book), maybe I'll do that tonight. Then again, I should probably just go to bed. Hasta la vista, baby. I'm out like Grandma's teeth.

urlLink The Weekly Wrapup Stormy Weather 1. Do you like stormy weather? Why or why not? I love it. It's very soothing to me. Thunderstorms have a way of bringing things back down to Earth, of reminding me that I'm part of it all, part of the world, part of nature. Plus, the power of nature is awesome to behold. 2. What do you do when a storm breaks in the middle of the night? If I'm up, I will usually grab my guitar and sit out on the screened porch, watching the storm and strumming along with it. If I'm in bed, I will usually lay there and try to enjoy it before I fall asleep. 3. When you were a child, where did you think the thunder and lightning came from? From the sky, the clouds. I don't know that I really gave it much thought though. 4. Describe your favorite and/or worst stormy memory. One of my favorite storm memories was when me and my sister played out in a hurricane. I can't remember which one, it was back in the mid '80's, I think. Anyways, it was pouring , we were completely drenched, and the wind was nearly lifting us off our feet. It was awsome! The worst was urlLink the tornado that hit our elementary school , killing a few children and destroying the school. I didn't like stormy weather for a long while after that, but I learned to love it again.

urlLink The Friday Five 1. Do you remember your first best friend? Who was it? Sure, it was my cousin, Andy. We were born within a couple months of each other. We were the first grandchildren in the family. 2. Are you still in touch with this person? No, unfortunately. With him in Pennsylvania and me in Florida, we lost contact before our teen years and never got back in touch. Just too many miles and years between us now. 3. Do you have a current close friend? I have two. I talk with Sue more often, but I do more stuff with JP. 4. How did you become friends with this person? I worked as a temp with Sue, and JP was my best friend growing up (he lived on the next street from me). 5. Is there a friend from your past that you wish you were still in contact with? Why? I had a friend, Ed, who I loved hanging with. He was a musician too (I never thought about it before, but all of my friends are/were musicians). I used to hang out over at his place a lot. They, him and his roomate, my friend Scott, had their place set up with amps, P.A, and drums, right in their living room (we called their place "Scott & Ed's Rock Palace"). We used to jam all the time. Ed would also come over here and watch "Kids In The Hall" with me, almost every week, which was fun. We'd laugh our asses off. Unfortunately, he betrayed Scott, sending him to prison. Scott had an outstanding warrant on him (he violated his probation, traffic stuff) and Ed turned him in to the police at his girlfriend's urging. See, Ed's girlfriend used to date Scott and after they broke up, she started hating him (it was mutual, I guess). Ed and Scott had been best friends for as long as I've known them, they were like brothers, so it was a huge betrayal. I was shocked. We all were. I couldn't believe Ed had done that. It was unthinkable, and unforgivable. I haven't spoken to Ed since.

Lately I've Been... Listening to: I had my Dave Attel "Skanks For The Memories" CD on yesterday and I listened to my "new" Van Halen (first album) cassette today. Watching on TV: I really haven't been able to sit through much TV lately. I'll start watching a show and then I'll lose interest and go play guitar or play on the computer or something. Downloading: I downloaded a couple of versions of "Feelin' Alright" (Traffic & Dave Mason), to compare them with the Joe Cocker version that JP put on the CD of covers for the band to listen to. Playing: No games, just playing guitar. Reading: Nothing at the moment. Jamming: We practiced tonight, Al, Jimmy, Santana, Ronnie, JP, and me. We played about 3 1/2 hours, til about 10:30pm. It was really hot there tonight, even with the a/c cranking we were sweating our asses off. My fingers kept getting sticky and I had to do "the dirt trick" on them again to dry them off. D'oh! Working: I put an application in at Goodwill (Gandy) today and tried to put one in at Olsten Staffing, but Olsten gave me the runaround. One lady was trying to find me an application and I told her I couldn't do heavy lifting because of my back so she started suggesting some things I could do. I had worked for Olsten for over two years before and I left on good terms with them... you'd think that might have meant something to them, but it didn't. Assholes. Buying: While I was at Goodwill, I spent the last few dollars I had in my checking account and bought 10 cassette tapes for $0.50 each and three paperback books for $0.75 each. The tapes I got were Van Halen (the first album), Van Halen "1984", Stevie Ray Vaughan "Greatest Hits", the Vaughan Brothers "Family Style", The Black Crowes "The Southern Harmony and Musical Companion", the Allman Brothers Band "2nd Set", Eric Clapton "From The Cradle", "ZZ Top "Greatest Hits", Iron Maiden "Somewhere In Time", and Guns 'N' Roses "Use Your Illusion I". All of the tape cases looked shitty, but the tapes and the j-cards inside them looked nice, some brand new. I put new cases on them when I got home. Sweet! The three books I bought were "Moby Dick" (I've never read it), "Interview With The Vampire" (I've read this before, but the book was in nice shape), and "SeinLanguage" (I have the hardback, but I wanted a paperback to enjoy anywhere). Eating: I had Stouffer's Fish Filet with Macaroni & Cheese a couple times this past week, a couple Boston Market Teriyaki TV dinners too. I had ham, potatoes, & green beans a couple times, with some cornbread even. I made breakfast yesterday and had eggs and kielbasa. I had a Bacon McGriddle for breakfast this morning (the one McDonalds owed us from Sunday) and it wasn't as bad as the greasy sausage McGriddle. Still, I don't think I'll order either of them again. I had hoped I could just go to Olsten and be working on Monday. Assholes. Planning: I am planning on getting a job as soon as possible. That's my main focus right now.

urlLink 3 For Thursday Topic: pets 1. Have you ever had pets? If so, name 3 (names and/or types) that youve had. (Pet rocks do not count). My first pet that I can remember was a bunny rabbit named "Charlie", whom I had as a toddler back in Pennsylvania. I still remember feeding him veggies. I've had scores of cats through the years, my favorite of all being Fluffy, who, sadly, died last year of a stroke. I'd had him for more than ten years. He was a good little boy, the most lovable cat you'd ever meet. I had another die on me, Puggy, who was still a little kitten when he died. We had to put him to sleep as he had stomach tumors, cancerous, I believe. I also had a dog growing up, a little mutt named Buster, who me and my sister used to fight over. He was a nut. He'd become "Crazy Dog" if me and my sister goaded him enough, and he'd run like a maniac all over the place, jumping on furniture, zipping up and down the hallway, basically going nuts. When he got older he developed arthritis and dry skin, started losing hair, and was kind of forgotten about, which I still feel bad about. He was a good dog who deserved better, you know? 2. What are 3 things you love or hate about pets? Love: 1) Companionship 2) They're cute, soft and cuddly 3) Fun to play with Hate: 1) They die 2) Fleas 3) Dookie 3. What are 3 types of pets that youd never have? I wouldn't want a snake. They're too damn boring. I wouldn't want a tarantula as a pet either. Ick! Also, some folks have pigs for pets and I wouldn't want one of them. Can you imagine having to clean up pigshit off your carpet? Double ick! BONUS: If your pet had to have expensive surgery or lifetime shots (like insulin for a diabetic animal) would you put your pet through it, or make the hard decision to put them to sleep? We've had to put a few animals to sleep. It's really rough, but sometimes there's no other way. You don't want your pet to suffer, to live in constant pain. If there's a way to keep them around, where they wouldn't be in pain, and could live normal lives, then that's always the first option. Believe me, if I could have saved Fluffy after he had his stroke, I would have done whatever it took to keep him alive and well. You just don't abandon a pet merely because he's old or ill.

Underachiever Blues I just finished taking the Classical Intelligence Test (Revised) at urlLink PsychTests.com and it gave me an IQ of 126. It said that I am smarter than the average person. This is a relief, because as I've gotten older, I was sure I was getting dumber. But it's also a reminder of how little I've accomplished with my life. It also said I should have no problem succeeding in academics or in life in general, but here I am, unemployed, in debt, with success nowhere in sight. I'm smarter than the average person, but I'm not doing as well in life as most of them. There are probably a lot of very stupid people who are making more out of their lives than I am with mine. So what does it all mean? I think it means that it takes more than intelligence to succeed in life. Whatever it takes, I seem to be missing it, so how smart can I really be? It's funny how little 126 means in the light of day, here in the real world.

Reese Witherspoon is much easier on the eyes than Arnold is, but I'd much rather watch "Terminator 3". I'm looking forward to seeing it sometime soon. 3. Hamburgers or hot dogs? I like them both, especially grilled, but I'll usually choose hamburgers over hot dogs. I love a good Chicago dog though. 4. Boating or hiking? I like hiking, as a concept, but I've never really done it. I would like being out in nature, it'd be relaxing, and it could be really fun if I went with someone I liked a lot. But, there's the heat factor and the sore feet factor to consider as well. My Dad made me scared of boating when I was younger, but I have gone on a cruise since then and enjoyed it a great deal. "D.A., Meet The D.A." I am shocked, saddened, and disappointed. My favorite NBA player, Darrell Armstrong, the heart & soul of my favorite team, the Orlando Magic, was arrested last night for assaulting a female police officer. *Sigh* Darrell has always been one of the "good guys" in the league, participating in scores of charity and community events off the court, and giving everything he's got while on the court. He's one of the hardest working players in the NBA. He was a superb role model and he was probably the last NBA'er I'd expect to see on a police blotter. And yet, urlLink here he is . From reading the arrest report it looks like it was a nothing little incident that just got blown out of proportion in the heat of the moment. He's always been a very emotional player, I've seen him cry after tough losses, and it looks like his emotion may have gotten the best of him this time out. urlLink Monday Mission 1. Can you think of one single decision you made that changed the course of your life. A decision where if you had done something else, everything would be different now? I can think of two extremely important decisions I made, less than 20 seconds apart, that, had I not made the choices I did, would have changed my life significantly. In fact, my life would most likely have ended. One night, the restaurant where I was working had just closed and I was in the back cleaning up when I heard a loud crack, glass shattering, and frantic shouting. I ran up to the front to see what was going on and as soon as I came through the swinging door I saw. Charles, our dishwasher (an exchange student from Nigeria) was slowly going down to the floor, dropping the glass plates he was carrying as he when down. I noticed blood pouring from his ear, the one that faced me. I think I started to ask "what happened" before I understood the situation. I saw my manager with his hands up, panicking (I saw real fear in his eyes), I saw an arm over the counter with a gun in it, I saw my co-workers behind the counter (including my sister) and I knew what had just happened. I sized up the situation and made for the back exit before the gunman had time to think about what to do with me. One of the police officers later told me that she was sure the gunman would have shot me (he had murdered several people already, during other robberies). I had made the right decision to head for the back exit. Almost as soon as I started running for the back door, I'd remembered that I saw a car pull up in the back parking lot about 10 minutes before, so I ran for the freezer instead. My gut reaction was "don't go out back". That saved my life as well. As I learned at the trial, the gunman had a partner and he was waiting out back. Two quick decisions, less than 20 seconds apart, not only changed my life, but saved my life as well. 2. Or maybe you think "the fates" have it all planned out for us. Do you think every life has a pre-determined course, that we will wind up at point X regardless of the decisions we make? Who knows, all I can tell you is that I don't feel like a puppet attached to some cosmic string. Life feels random. But I can't rule out anything. It'd be close-minded and arrogant of me to totally dismiss fate and destiny altogether. I don't believe in God, the biblical God, but I haven't ruled out a higher power altogether. We don't know everything, we're but a small speck in a massive universe; all of our learning, our knowledge, our science, may just be a tiny glimpse into what is real. After all, we have a limited perspective, no? 3. Do you think that it is that left up to us and random chance to decide who we are with? Are we are guided to the person we were meant to be with or could you be with the wrong person while "the one" is still somewhere out there? They say that there is someone for everyone, but so far, there's been no one for me. I don't go out very much, never have really, and that, among other things, has cut down on my chances of meeting someone. Meeting people is random, the right place at the right time. No one has knocked on my door guided by destiny. 4. Do you like to drink and get drunk? When was the last time you were drunk or hung over? What was the occasion? How did it feel at the time? How did it feel the next day? I enjoy a drink now and then, but I don't like being totally drunk. I used to drink a lot, back before I turned 21. One night, I drank so much that I passed out the moment I hit my bed. I woke up the next morning, fully dressed still, and covered in vomit. I had thrown up while asleep, which could have killed me had I not been sleeping on my side. I was shocked and angry. That was the end of heavy drinking for me. Nowadays, I'll drink in moderation, I'll get buzzed, but I never get totally shitfaced anymore. I liked the freedom from inhibitions that being really drunk provides, but I hated the hangovers and the loss of control. I like to be in control of my faculties. 5. On the same topic, have you ever done anything you regret while "under the influence?" What happened? Do you remember it or did you have to be told? Hmmmm... I don't know. When I got wasted, I normally wasn't mean or anything, just silly. I remember being told that people had to walk me home before, which I didn't remember. Apparently, I was so drunk I couldn't even stand up straight or walk more than a step or two. Oh! Wait! I regret getting my stupid "Cheri" tattoo. Had I been sober, I would not have 1) started it, or 2) let my brother-in-law finish it (I'd passed out). 6. Were you/are you able to resist peer pressure in school/college? How? If not, what did you do that you wish you hadn't? Anything I did I did because I wanted to, not because of peer pressure. I've always been my own person. I've never really done things to "fit in" or because someone else said I should. I've turned down drinks and drugs on many, many occasions. 7. What things are better left unsaid? Things that will unnecessarily hurt someone's feelings. BONUS: Isn't this world a crazy place? It's crazy! Crazy! Craaaazy! Everything must go!!

I... Am... Spent! Wow. Yesterday was quite eventful. I started my day around 3:30pm, getting out of bed after having slept very little. I'm not sure that I slept at all, actually. I shaved and showered and got dressed and soon afterwards, my sister and her three kids came down. They were having some 4th of July stuff going on up at my neighborhood's Rec Hall (free food, some games) so me, my Mom, and the three kids went up there. The first thing I noticed when we got there is that the people around here, though nice people, really are a strange looking, Jerry Springerish, lot. The boys threw darts at balloons on a board and won some crappy prizes, they took individual rides on a go-kart-type vehicle driven by some pre-pubescent freckled girl, and then Jesse, the older boy threw baseballs at the dunk tank, dropping a friend of my Mom's into the water while she was taunting him. My niece didn't do anything, just sat down and watched. I took her over to get some food and we stood around under the large tarpaulin tent that covered the grill and the food tables and we ate our food. Not long after that, it started raining. It was pouring down hard, complete with thunder, lightning, and huge wind gusts that threated to topple the tarp. It actually lifted it up a few times, so we a bunch of us had to physically hold it down. I had one of the ends and the rain was soaking me. A few times, I had to put all of my weight and strength into it to keep it down! My little nephew, Austin, started acting like a crybaby (my niece is afraid of everything and she gets him worked up too) and I started arguing with him while I was trying to keep the food tent from flying away. Eventually, my Mom went out in the rain and brought the car around and took the kids home. I couldn't leave yet because it was just me and three women on my side and I was the main person holding our side down. I guess I could've just said "See ya!", and gone home too, but I didn't. I waited until my Mom came back, and then I waited until some guy came over and replaced me. I didn't mind helping out, but I was pissed off because I missed my chance to talk to a cute girl I used to work with at Wendys. After we got home, we had dinner. I had just had a burger at the Rec Hall, so I didn't eat much. Me and my niece had Taco sald, and the others had Chicken Cordon Bleu with Stouffer's Mac & Cheese. After dinner, I took the boys outside and we played catch with the mini-football. Austin lost interest and found something else to do, and me and Jess threw the ball around for long time, even after it started raining again. Since it wasn't lightning anymore, I thought of something we could do in the rain: I had them build a dam in our gutter, out front, along the road. They loved it! All three of us were grabbing dirt, rocks, and grass, anything we could find, to hold the water back. The water kept busting over the top or around the sides, so I grabbed some bricks and reinforced the dam for them. It held up well. In fact, it lasted all night long and is still there, holding water tonight. Austin enjoyed it so much, he even built a second dam about 10 feet behind the first one. While it were building the dams, it had grown dark and fireworks were going off all round us. The kids had brought a bunch of fireworks with them, so it wasn't long before we broke them out. They had some really cool ones: roman candles, jumping jacks, firecrackers, and a bunch of large ones that shot up in the air. I had never really done fireworks before. When I was a kid, my Moms idea of "fireworks" was a box of sparklers, and as an adult, I never really had the urge to do them. I got the hang of it pretty quickly and I set them all off without any problem. It was a lot of fun. I even let Jess light some off. Between us, and the guy down at the other end of our street, it looked like war zone, and sounded like it too. The smoke in the air was thick. It was surreal. The boys had a ton of jumping jacks with them, so we took the inside and untangled them, put them in a bowl and went back out to set them off. These work well when you throw them up in the air, sometimes they zoom off in a stream of smoke, so I was lighting them for the boys and they got to throw them. Austin went in after a bit, but Jess and I continued til after Midnight. It it weren't for the stupid mosquitoes, it would have been a totally enjoyable night. Those suckers bit us up! Inside, we all sat around my Mom's room talking and laughing at each other for a long while before everyone went off to sleep. Everyone but me, that is. I was up til 5am (I found some very interesting facts about President Bush and his family), and then after I went to bed, I couldn't sleep. My muscles felt strained, probably from holding down that food tent, my feet were sore from all of the standing I had been doing, and I just couldn't get comfortable. I got up for around 11:30am to take some Aleve, stayed up for awhile watchiong "Changing Rooms", and then went back to bed around 1pm. I was down until almost 8pm tonight. I slept some, but I still feel really tired.

Independance Day Today is the 227th anniversary of our nation's independance from England. This should be a day of national celebration, national pride, but this year, I'm feeling neither celabratory, nor prideful. We lost 2,795 people in the terrorist attacks of September 11th, 2001. Spurred on by revenge, fear, paranoia, and to a small degree, the search for justice, President Bush employed our military in both Afgahnistan and Iraq, killing well over 7,000 civilians in these two countries. That's a conservative figure. It could be well over 10,000 civilians deaths due to U.S. bombing of these countries. This number includes men, women, and children. Our bombs weren't discriminatory. The numbers for non-civilian deaths in these countries is well over 11,000, and could possibly be twice that amount. What possible justification could there be for us wiping out so many human lives? Finding Osama Bin Laden? We still haven't found him. Finding Iraq's "weapons of mass destruction"? Damn! Apparently, we're the only ones with weapons of mass destruction over there! Oops! We accomplished neither of the things the President told us we were over there fighting for ... so how about ... ummm ... giving freedom to the people? Yeah! That'll work! We gave the people freedom, from the Taliban, and from Saddam Hussein. The ones we haven't killed yet are surely enjoying the wonderful freedom that we've given them. What a crock of shit. Who would believe such garbage? The majority of the American public, that's who. Our government has us pegged. They know they can get away with anything they want to anymore. Bail-outs for corporations that lay off their workers while their executives give themselves million dollar bonuses? You betcha! That makes no sense at all, but, whatever! Tax cuts that benefit the wealthiest people in this country more than anyone else? The wealthy have it better than any of us already, but Washington thinks they need more relief? OK, sure, why not! Screw us over all you want Uncle Sam, we've got our beer to keep us stupid and we've got plenty of new reality TV shows to keep our minds off of the things that really matter! Our government has a blatant favoritism of the wealthy and powerful in this country, and for corporate rights over individual rights. Why would our government favor the wealthy? Because all of the seats in our Senate, our House Of Representatives, and in our Oval Office are filled by millionaires. Many of them, billionaires. Who better to look out for the rich and the powerful in this country than the rich and the powerful themselves! If you think they're looking out for we, the people, well then, you, you're stupid. Go back to watching "Fear Factor", Jim Bob, I think they're going to be eating a sheep scrotum next. The few folks who are still capable of independant thought, who try and speak out against what they see wrong with their government, are labeled as treasonous, anti-American, and they often have their livlihoods affected. Bill Mahr had his show cancelled by ABC after making a criticism of our military, and the Dixie Chicks were boycotted by angry Americans because they criticized President Bush. McCarthy-era politics are alive and well, here, in the new millenium. The political atmosphere today is not unlike that era either, filled with fear and paranoia. America is greater than that, or at least, it once was. So our Government is corrupt, criminal, and a vast majority of our people are stupid sheep who do what they're told... boy, does that make me proud to be an American! My eyes are welling up with tears of national pride. America is the greatest country in the world, but it needs a tune-up, maybe even a complete overhaul, if it's going to survive into the next Millenium. We aren't perfect and we aren't indestructible. The Roman Empire was once the greatest nation on Earth too, but where is it today? So today, on this Independance Day, I salute the people who have given their lives to make this country great, I curse and speak out against those who tarnish her greatness, and I say to you: Go and BBQ America, have yourself a beer, watch some fireworks, but please, take a few minutes and think about the state of America today, and then think about what you can do to make America better tomorrow. It's still our country, and we can still take her back from the powers that be and make her great once again. Peace to all.

Last Night I didn't go to bed shortly after writing my last post, in fact, I didn't make it to bed until after daylight. My dumb ass. I did have another weird dream though. I'm sure it's of no interest to anyone, not even me really, but I am compelled to write it down. This one starts off with me and Will Ferrell. He has some sort of vehicle that looks like a lawn mower minus the handle, and wrapped in a loop around it is a colored plastic ribbon, for steering. In the dream, you sit behind it (I'm not sure if you sit on a detached seat, on some cardboard, or on the ground) and you control the direction with the ribbon, like you would a sled. A lot of the dream is fuzzy, I remember riding around the countryside and struggling to steer it, trying to avoid collisions, and I think at some point I was being chased by cops. Then, I remember riding this stupid thing down a highway and up over a huge bridge, high up in the air. As I got over the top of the bridge, I saw the the road ahead is missing a large section and that people are falling in the water below. The next thing I remember, I'm swimming in the water towards a small outcropping of sand and bushes next to the other side of the bridge. Greg, a childhood friend, is with me by then. As I sit on the sand embankment, I realize that it is moving and that I am sitting on top of a crocodile. I grab his jaws shut and Greg stabs him repeatedly until the croc is dead. From there we start looking around the wooded area behind us, looking for a way back to the mainland, and then I saw a skull, sitting up on a tree limb. I started looking around and discovered that there were a lot of skulls, everywhere, some on sticks, like warnings. It's fuzzy here, but I remember making it through to the other side of the woods, back onto the highway. Dreams are weird.

Weirdness Continued I knew it. I fucking knew it. If I went to bed to "nap", I just knew I wouldn't be getting back up around "9 or 10am". I didn't. I got up around 7pm. Big difference. Ugh! I went to lay down around 6am but I just couldn't sleep, just kept tossing and turning in bed. I know I was awake until 8am at least. Then, after I finally managed to fall asleep, I kept having strange, vivid, dreams. I remebered two of them after I got up, but I only remember one of them right now: The Bear Dream: The first one I had involved a giant black bear and some police officers. In the dream, I was walking through a wooded area, like a small park, and I came across a big white ball the size of a basketball that looked like a little powdered donut hole. In the dream I took it as bear poo, an unusually large specimen. I stepped on it and it looked like it was one of those powdered donuts but filled with pecans, nuts, so I knew it came from a bear. This worried me, so I started walking, very cautiously, back to the building I came from, which seemed like a church or a church building. Halfway there, I spotted a humongous black bear at the edge of the woods. The bear looked pretty fake to me, like it could be a guy in a bear suit, but it was drooling and was much larger than a man. Frightened and nervous, I ran for the building. It's a little fuzzy here, but I remember seeing the bear through a doorway, he had entered the building too, so I warned everyone in the "church" and had them evacuate. They panicked crazily. I ran out the front door onto a busy highway and saw a whole bunch of police officers and cop cars gathered somewhere down the road, about to raid some building, so I ran out there and got a few to come back to the "church" just as the raid began. They went into the back room and then I heard gunshots and saw some sort of struggle. The bear was dead. It gets fuzzy again, and then I remember going out back where two policemen, Officers Twist and Connor, are now shooting at birds and whatever creatures they see, somewhere back behind the "church". I recognize that some of the birds they are killing are endangered, so I raise a fuss with them. It gets fuzzy again, but I think they ignored me, and then I remember running down the street and getting another officer, a black one whose name I've forgotten, to come and stop them. He puts three of the birds (2 speckled brown ones and one other) in a plastic evidence bag and we talk about the incident. I want the officers charged fro killing the endangered birds and the black officer explains that they were full of Adrenalin after the bear incident and were just blowing off steam, trying to get me to forget about pressing charges. It's fuzzy here because I remember seeing a warehouse with a stack of huge bean bag chairs and on the top was a dead bird, "a biggun'" I called it, which looked like an ostrich or an emu. I was assuming they had killed it too, but my Mom said it had died last week and I was angry and confused that she had just let it decompose up there. At this point, I'm under the impression that the black officer is going to help me press charges against the other officers as he's carrying the evidence bag with the dead birds in it and I'm following him back to the "church" building. I stop to shut the warehouse door or to get the dead bird down, I forget which, and when I get back to the building, which seems a lot like my own living room, I find the officer gone and the bag of dead birds laying on my dining room table. I took it to mean that the black officer was counting on me to just let it drop, which angered me. I woke up around this point. Very weird dream. I wouldn't even begin to know how to interpret it. Anyhow, I'm going to try and go to bed again soon. I've only been up for 6 hours, but I'm still kind of tired, even though I certainly shouldn't be. The weirdness continues...

urlLink This-or-That Tuesday 1. Lemonade or Ice Cold Beer? On almost all occasions, I'll go for the lemonade. Once in awhile though, a nice cold beer is good. 2. Swimming pool or beach? I really dislike saltwater in my mouth and eyes, sand everywhere, and cuts on my feet from broken shells, so I definitely prefer swimming pools. However, I won't go to either if they're crowded. 3. Long weekends here & there, or a 2-week vacation? You have time to enjoy yourself on a 2-week vacation, but there just isn't enough time on a long weekend. 4. Destination: Acapulco or Hawaii? Acapulco, I suppose. I love mexican food and I love clear blue waters, so that'd be a killer mix. 5. Destination: Mountains or Beach? Mountains. I'm not a beach person at all. 6. Hotel/motel/B&B or camping? The former. I like camping as a concept , but it's never been as much fun as I thought it should be. Maybe I just haven't gone camping with the right person. 7. Carefully planned vacation, or play it by ear? A perfect vacation would combine a little bit of both. It's good to have an agenda, but spontaneity is part of the fun. 8. Sneakers or sandals? I've never worn sandals, so I can't really compare them to sneakers. Sneakers are all I ever wear. 9. Air-conditioning or fans? A/C and crank it, please. 10. Concerts in the park or baseball games? Baseball games are long and boring, so I'd much rather go to a concert in the park. Besides, if you go with the right person, a concert in the park can be fun and even romantic.

Jam Night We got together tonight (Monday) to practice, rather than on Thursday, our usual jam night (Al's going out of town). It went well enough, but it just wasn't as good or as much fun as last time. This time, we had Jimmy (JP and Al's old drummer) on drums instead of Chris (who no-showed at band practice with Santana's band the night before), and we didn't have Ronnie on sax/flute, which really made a huge impact on our sound. I much prefer Ronnie being there. We all missed him. We ran through JP's set list and did covers of "Breakdown", "Before You Accuse Me", "Can't You See", "Feelin' Alright", "Wild Night", "Sunshine Of Your Love", "Stuck In The Middle", "Old Apartment", "Sympathy For The Devil", and "Little Wing", which I threw in. We tried doing "I Got Loaded" too, but it didn't go down too well since Al and Jimmy don't really know it. We also did some of JP's songs: "At Night" (he may change this title), "Promise You The Moon", "Opportunity Knocks", and we also did Santana's "Subway Joe". We didn't do much jamming tonight, sticking instead to fairly straight versions of the songs from the set list. We were there for about 3 hours and played for about 2 1/2 hours. I did ok on lead, but I'm still rusty after having barely played my electric guitar the last 2 months while I was ill. I did ok, screwed up a few times, but most of the stuff I screwed up on is stuff I've never played lead on before, so I had to wing it. Speaking of "winging it", I thought "Little Wing" turned out really well, but the other guys were kind of iffy on it. Of course, I played the Hendrix version and my rythym section played the Stevie Ray Vaughan version, so we weren't all on the same page, plus, we all wanted to hear Ronnie's sax on it. We'll have to try it again with him. I thought Jimmy did a good job. He's not as loose as Chris, but he's a very competent drummer. Besides that, seeing as how Chris didn't show at Santana's practice last night (which pissed off Santana's bassist, causing him to quit Santana's group), we're lucky to have someone dependable like Jimmy. After practice, JP and I worked on figuring out what songs to play, which to try, and which to scrap, from the set list. JP wants to add some more current songs to the mix, which is fine, as long as he doesn't choose crappy ones. He wanted to do a Barenaked Ladies song called "One Week" but I refuse to do that one. It's used on some TV commercial, which is played ad nauseum, and I've really come to hate it. We have a ton of cover songs on deck, songs to learn, so I'll be working my ass off learning 'em until the next practice, which is about 10 days from now. I'd like to finish some of my own songs and add them to the lists too. All in all, I'm not as happy as I was after the last practice, but I'm still hopeful that we'll get it together and make some good music.

Saturday Night/Sunday Santana's party was rough. For starters, we got there about 4:30pm instead of 2pm. JP was running late and then he got lost on the way there. Some fugly chick walking down the road distracted us and he missed his turn. Secondly, the stage wasn't set up very well either. I was standing way off to the right side of the stage and could barely hear the rest of the guys, and to make matters worse, I was positioned right on top of a fire ant mound. Yay! If all of that weren't bad enough, it was hotter than hell out there, and of course, my dumb ass, I wore a long-sleeved shirt and pants. Duh! I thought I was going to have a heat stroke! After we finally got situated, which took awhile (JP kept having sound problems), we began the first set. It was awful. I was awful. We were awful. I completely blew the intro to "Authority Song" (and made a few other boo-boos too), JP's acoustic wasn't coming through the PA, JP forgot the lyrics to one of his songs, Ronnie kept walking off the stage and disappearing (I had to improvise leads that Ronnie usually does), Jimmy's tempo on drums wasn't consistent, and John (Santana's keyboard player) was trying to play along with us and didn't know most of the songs. It was terrible. The people that were there were nice and complimentary though. It took awhile, but I learned to just say "thank you" when people say "you sounded great", when I know we didn't. Between sets JP, Doris (JP's wife), and I went into the house for some chow. The buffet was not impressive. Chicken wings, baked beans, pasta salad, and some kind of goulash. I was expecting mexican food or something. I didn't eat anything anyway. I was too heat beaten, I probably would've puked if I'd eaten anything. Doris was telling me I screwed up a few times during the set and I concurred. She wasn't telling me anything I didn't know already. Eventually, me, Doris, JP, and Al went out to Santana's Florida room and talked and joked awhile before heading back out for the second set. The second set was much, much better. I moved the amp in, closer to the other guys, but I still had to stand off the stage, out in front, plus the fire ants were even worse there, I got bit a few times and was constantly brushed them off my pant legs and shoes. It wasn't an ideal place to play, but I managed. Like I said, we were much, much better during the second set. We wound up skipping a couple of songs from the setlist, since we were running out of daylight. Near the end, Santana had everyone play "Hot, Hot, Hot", and at that point JP and I split from the area. We have a mutual dislike of that song. JP was done for the night, but I got back up and played some more. One of Santana's friends, Mike, joined us on a few more songs. He played Clapton's "I Can't Stand It" (which I'd never really played before, but did ok with) and we did "Mustang Sally" (which sounded pretty decent), then John, the keyboardist played "Proud Mary", which I faked my way through. I had to solo during that one, not sure of what key I was playing in. It wasn't pretty, but I got out ok. I played until it was dark, or more accurately, until John broke into a Richard Marx song. After we got packed and ready to head out, JP, Doris, and I had a talk about the band outside Santana's house. During the party, Rich (Santana's sound guy/brother-in-law) talked to all of use sepearately about having a permanent sound guy, telling us we needed one because of the size of the band. He also talked to Doris and JP and said something to the effect that Santana, Ronnie, him, and John (the keyboardist) were a package deal, which didn't rub either of them right. We came to the decision that we would have to scale the band down to a 4-piece unit, which is fine with me (although I'll really miss Ronnie's sax). A huge band would be too limiting. Most bars wouldn't have a stage that would fit us all. Plus John (the keyboardist) kind of rubbed me and JP the wrong way as well. He's pretty good, but he seems kind pretty arrogant. I feel bad for Santana, putting all of that time in with us only to be discarded like that, but I guess it's his own fault for trying to make Blue Condition into a new version of his own band. I mean, I really don't think Rich was talking to us about all that stuff without Santana's knowledge. Santana had to be behind it. So next Thursday, it will be the four of us, over at Circle once again. To be honest, I prefer playing at Circle, their AC is much better than Santana's. After we split Santana's, we headed over to JP's parent's house. Doris met us there too. We talked and joked for a long while. I've always liked his parents, even after they forbid JP from playing with me when we were kids. They started off here in the park too, but they got out and did well for themselves. They have a really nice home now. I know it's a cliche, but they're good people. I finally got home around 11:30pm and to my surprise, my nephew Jesse was here. I'd suggested he come over earlier and it worked out well. We made paper airplanes and then went to my room where Jesse played my handheld "Yahtzee" and listened to some tapes (Van Halen & Twisted Sister). I was dead tired and got into bed while Jesse played. After a bit, he went to bed (back in Mom's room) and I did too. I slept terribly. I don't know if it was from the heat all day or from my sinuses, bit my head was killing me. I don't know how much, or how little, I slept, but it didn't seem like much. I got up around 8:30am, took some Aleves, and went back to bed. I slept until Mom woke me up around 11:30am. I got up and we ran out to the flea market. I picked up six cassette tapes for $0.25 each (Stevie Ray Vaughan, Chicago, Bill Withers, The Animals, Hootie & The Blowfish, and 1 other), a deck of playing cards (a quarter), that "Russia House" CD (that I'm going to sell on eBay) for $3, and another cassette, Joe Walsh's "the Confessor", for a dollar. Jess bought a handheld "Hangman" game for $2. If he wouldn't have bought it, I would have. From there we ran an errand over to JC Penney's, and then we went to Sonny's for lunch. I chowed down on all you-can-eat pork. We had that jerky waiter again. I don't think he likes me. I know I don't like him. When we got home, Jess and I made paper airplanes, this time out of heavy sketch paper, and we drew designs on them. Jess made an "F-4 Jet" and I made mine the "FART-100" (aka "The Ass Kicker'). We also drew targets for the BB gun too. It was still too hot outside to fly the planes or to shoot the BB gun, so we played Rummy (I creamed him) and listened to music until about 6:30pm. We had a ball with the planes. We had them flying really well. A couple times they flew up on the porch and Jess had to climb the ladder to get them down. Another time, mine flew over in Haggie's yard and Jess retrieved it. Eventually, both of them found their way on top of the house, so we played with the BB gun instead. I hung the targets on the ladder (between the steps) and we took turns shooting. Jess had several bullseyes. His bullseye was a smiley face, mine was an ass, mooning. I got a bullseye too, but sadly, I didn't hit the ass. We did that for a long while. I had Jess check to see if the planes blew off of the roof and they did. he was happy about that. We retired those planes and we made two more. We took them outside, but they didn't fly very well. These two were experiments, we folded the paper side to side, rather than top to bottom. We came in and we made two more "normal ones". We drew designs on these two; Jess called his "The Stealth" and mine was called "The Night Flier". We took them outside and flew them for a long while. We had fun. Jess had his flying like crazy, a lot of hang time. Mine flew long distance too, but nowhere near as often as, or as far as, "The Stealth". We came in, had ice cream, and then I put "The Naked Gun" on for Jess while I played on the PC. He's asleep now, and as soon as I finish blogging, I am heading to bed myself. I guess I'm finished now.
