Eh. I didn't get any (much needed) payments in today, but I did get a cassette tape-filled package. Unfortunately, the condition of the tapes leaves a lot to be desired. Some are just fine, some are so-so, but some are pretty bad, with torn inserts, cracked tapes, sun warped tapes, and water damage. What the hell do these people do with their tapes? I've always taken good care of my CDs and tapes, I don't get why people trash their stuff, especially CDs, which will last a lifetime and beyond if taken care of. Seems like a no-brainer to me. My Newest Endeavor I've been thinking for awhile now about doing something I enjoy for a living, and I've started to act on that idea. I love music more than anything else, and working around music would be heaven to me. I haven't heard of any openings in any of the CD stores around here, but I probably wouldn't enjoy working in them anyway (imagine me suggestive selling Britney Spears or Fifty Cent), so I'm going to try and start my own music-related side business. I'm starting off with cassette tapes. I don't have a job and can't afford to buy lots of CDs or DVDs, so for the last two weeks, I've been buying cassette tape lots on eBay, partly for me, but also to gain some "stock". I bought about 250 tapes so far, at about $0.20 each, and today, I bought about 250 more, also at about $0.20 each. I won four lots of tapes, here's a breakdown: Lot #1 - 35 tapes + 3-drawer cassette case for a total of $10. Includes: The Beatles "1967-1970", The Cars "Greatest Hits", Bob Seger "Stranger In Town", Bruce Springsteen "Born In The USA", Elvis Presley "Number One Hits", Boston "Boston" & "Don't Look Back", AC/DC "Live", ZZ Top "Eliminator", and Van Halen's "OU812", "5150", & "1984". Lot #2 - 26 tapes for $10. Includes: Kansas "The Best Of Kansas", Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young "So Far", David Bowie "Lets Dance", Cheap Trick "At Budokan", Creedence Clearwater Revival "Chronicle", Genesis "Abacab", and REO Speedwagon "Hi Infidelity". Lot #3 - 120 tapes + 3 cassette cases for $14. This is a mystery lot. I have a list of artists, but don't know any individual titles. Contains 95% country music, which may sell well around here. Some of the rock artists included in the lot are: Billy Joel, Bob Seger, Boston, and Fleetwood Mac. Lot #4 - 71 tapes for $14.27. This is another mystery lot. They didn't list any of the tapes included, but from the scan I can see titles by Billy Squier, Joe Walsh, The Clash, Jethro Tull, AC/DC, The Honeydrippers, The Cars, Judas Priest, Foreigner, and Motley Crue. I already ordered brand new tape cases, so the tapes will all look nice after I'm through with them. I figure my costs are about $0.33 per tape ($0.20 per tape + $0.13 for a new case), although it's likely a little higher since some of the tapes probably won't be sellable (I think I can count on that). I'm thinking I can start off by selling them for $1 a piece at the flea market (or wherever). I'd like to sell some of the better ones for a little more, but then I think that having good titles in there will draw people to my table, so I might be better off selling them all for $1 each. I'm just worried I'll get "cherry-picked" and have a table full of crappy ones. In the beginning, I will also be selling used paperbacks (Stephen King books mostly), basketball cards, and eventually, I would like to have some CDs and DVDs to sell as well. I will probably offer trades for that stuff at first and keep an eye out on eBay for deals. If I'm successful with it, maybe I'll be able to do it full-time someday. That's my dream anyway. In all honesty, I'd probably consider it a minor success if I could sell enough to pay for the stuff I buy on eBay. I could put together a great collection for myself and sell off what I don't need, or don't want, to pay for them. I could certainly live with that. In the meantime, I've got a shitload of tapes coming (about 400 due in after I pay for them all) and I'm really looking forward to their arrival! I will sort through them, put them in new cases, chuck the bad ones, and try to listen to them all. That is my idea of great fun. How sad is that?

Blues On Tuesday I don't know what's going on here, but for the second night in a row, I don't think I slept more than an hour or two. I tossed and turned for hours, totally awake, before finally getting out of bed around 8am this morning. Just like yesterday, I had had enough. I hope my insomnia isn't coming back, especially not now, when I've finally got a normal sleep schedule. I had it for several months last year and it was a really tough time for me. Yesterday, I happened to look in my blogger archives to see what I was doing the same time last year and coincedentally, I was struggling with insomnia. I wonder if it's something in the air this time of year that does it to me (I have allergy problems). Whatever the problem, I am up... tired as hell, but up. I started moving the little TV from my room into Mom's room (hers quit working) when JP called me back. We're not practicing on Thursday this week, but on Wednesday instead, and practice for Tuesday is off. We started tallking about transportation again (it may be a problem this Saturday), and he wound up brow-beating me for awhile about my job and transportation situation. I don't think he understands just how incredibly screwed up my situation is. For instance, he's talking about me taking a bus over to Tampa for work at a bank. I had to explain that 1) getting from here to Tampa via the bus would be a major task involving several bus transfers, and it would take a lot of time and money to get back and forth each day. In fact, to catch the bus in the morning, I'd have to be up by 5am, and if we're playing until 11:00-11:30pm at night, it wouldn't give me much time to sleep, not enough for me to function on. 2) I don't have any clothes suitable to wear in a bank and it would require hundreds of dollars for me to get some. 3) I don't have any job experience that make me desirable to a bank: Wendys and production work. In other words, it'd be an unrealistic situation for me. He said Al knows of a job opening in telemarketing, but there's no way in hell I would do that, no matter how much I need. I need a job and I need money, but I refuse to surrender my principles for either. He doesn't understand that, but then, he works in telemarketing himself. He says I should just go back to fast food then, for some quick cash, but I said "no way". My resume is crap as it is, if I get another fast food job on there, it's going to push the one "good" job I had, Evatone, off of many job applications. We've had the same conversation a few times before, it's always the same: he says I make too many excuses, I say I'm just being realistic. I've neglected myself for two decades, twenty years of not taking care of myself, of choosing "easy" over "smart", and it's not going to change overnight. I'm moving forward and I'm going to try to do it right this time and I will not settle for less. Back to Mom's TV...

Mo' Monday Blues My Mom just emailed me and told me that my (Great) Uncle Bob died today. Apparently he died a week ago, but no one bothered to tell us until today. We used to be pretty close, but my Dad drove a wedge between us and the rest of the family. In the last 20 years, I think I've seen him maybe three times, just randomly, when we happened to run into each other at the flea market or wherever. Uncle Bob was my Dad's Uncle, my Great Uncle, and he was a pretty neat guy back in his day. He raced cars, was in the Navy, built model airplanes, and played guitar. Eventually, Uncle Bob gave me his acoustic guitar, the same guitar I always got in trouble for playing with (when I was a kid, visiting over there). I think it may have been my first acoustic guitar period, but I'm not sure anymore. I certainly played it a long time and I learned a lot on it. I've always been happy that he saw to give it to me. I've always wanted to show him what I did with it, how much I've learned, but like I said, my Dad caused a rift in the family and our families have never been as close as we once were, so that never happened. That's too bad. So long, Uncle Bob, and thank you.

Jam Night Last night's band practice went ok, I guess. I was pretty tired going in and didn't play very well, but strangely, no one else seemed to notice much. Everybody seemed real pleased with the practice. Maybe it's just me. Before we got rolling tonight, we goofed off a bit. Just for fun, I threw out "You Shook Me All Night Long" by AC/DC and we played it a little (we sounded like shit) and then I threw out War's "Low Rider" and we jammed on that a bit too (which sounded pretty good). We had the full band there last night, all six of us, and we ran through set 1, set 2 and part of set 3. Here are the set lists as they stand now: Set 1 "Old Apartment" by Barenaked Ladies "Wild Night" by Van Morrison "What She Loves" an original by JP "Opportunity Knocks" an original by JP "All For You" by Sister Hazel "The Way" by Fastball "Promise You The Moon" an original by JP "You Can't Run" an original by JP "American Girl" by Tom Petty & The Heartbreakers "Crazy Little Thing Called Love" by Queen "Stuck In The Middle With You" by Stealers Wheel Set 2 "Had A Girl" an original by JP (we may alternate this with U2's "One") "Love The One You're With" by Stephen Stills "I Wanna Be Sedated" by the Ramones "Authority Song" by John Mellencamp "Sleeping Forever" an original by JP "Little Wing" by Jimi Hendrix (alternates w/ Marshall Tucker Band's "Can't You See" & Eric Clapton's "Wonderful Tonight") "Before You Accuse Me" by Bo Diddley (as done by Eric Clapton) "The Middle" by Jimmy Eat World "We Don't Need Much" an original by JP "Sunshine Of Your Love" by Cream "Go Your Own Way" by Fleetwood Mac Set 3 "Blister In The Sun" by Violent Femmes "Feelin' Alright" by Dave Mason "Steal My Kisses" by Ben Harper "The Curtain Falls" an original by JP (alternates with JP's "Something More") "If It Makes You Happy" by Sheryl Crow "Circle" an original by JP "The Difference" by the Wallflowers "Rock This Town" by the Stray Cats "You May Be Right" by Billy Joel "Subway Joe" an original by Santana (may alternate with Carlos Santana's "Oye Como Va") JP threw "Before You Accuse Me" back in the set list on his own and I'm not real happy about that, especially in set #2, where we already do two Clapton songs. We will likely replace it with Stevie Ray Vaughan's "Cold Shot" and we're also talking about doing Steve Miller's "Jungle Love", so "Before You Accuse Me" may well be history. I really don't enjoy playing it anyway, which is odd, because I love playing the blues. We added Ben Harper's "Steal My Kisses" to the set lists tonight, and we wound up working on that for awhile. Al, JP, and I had our parts pretty much down (there's one small bridge that we need to figure out though), but the other guys hadn't heard the song before and weren't sure what to play. It didn't have the energy it should have. We'll have to work on it more. It appears we're going to go ahead and get booked at some places. Everybody else seems to think we're about ready. I still think we need more practice. We're going to play at a party at Santana's house on the 30th (8 days away), so that should be a good gauge of where we're really at. I really need to get some money and fast. My equipment just isn't good enough. I need a bigger amplifier, my guitar needs work done on it, and I would like a back-up guitar on hand. I'm going job hunting on Monday, but I'm considering selling off part of my Jimi Hendrix CD collection for some fast money. I just know I'll regret it later though. I'll need to figure out something soon though, if we're going to be playing out very shortly. I played JP's Eric Clapton model Strat tonight. I hadn't played it but once before, and wasn't impressed with it then. But tonight, after playing mine and then his, I think I like it a lot. It's very crisp and biting and it's louder than mine (it has a built-in pre-amp). It also stays in tune much better than mine. I had tuning problems all freaking night. I had to drop out of one song because it was way off. I think the battery in my tuner died and it gave me the wrong tunings, so I replaced the battery and re-tuned... all in the middle of a song. Ugh! I hope that doesn't happen when we play live, that would suck . We practiced until 11:30pm last night, and by the end of the night, I was dead tired. My feet hurt, my back ached, and I was drenched in sweat. I should've taken a nap before practice (I tried to, actually) because Early Rising and Late Night Jamming do not go hand-in-hand. Before we left for the night, Santana wanted to try out some lyrics he had for one of my songs (the E9 one with the bass lines), so we worked on it a bit. I didn't really like what he was doing. He sang something about a woman getting naked in front of a mirror and then him rubbing oil all over her... that was in verse 1. There's no telling where it went from there. We're practicing again on Thursday, and JP and I will probably get together on Tuesday, possibly with Al.

Another Day In Paradise I was in a really good mood all day today... until Mom got home. We got into a huge argument tonight. She ran two errands for me in the last week and both times, she screwed them up. We need ink for the printer and Office Depot is right next to where she gets her hair done, so on Saturday (when she was getting her hair done), I asked her to pick the ink up for me and I wrote the type I needed down for her: "BCI-24". She came home with BCI-21. She said they didn't have BCI-24's, and she wasn't sure whether or not my "4" was really a "1" (the extra lines would have clued me in). She called me from her hair place before she went to Office Depot, so I really don't understand why she didn't call me from Office Depot if she was unsure, rather than buying the wrong ink. I tell her all the time "if they don't have exactly what I need, don't buy anything at all", so it frustrates me that she went ahead and bought it anyway. I still have no ink and now she has to make another trip to return the wrong kind. Obviously, I wasn't very happy about it and we got into a small argument over it. Somehow, it's my fault that she bought the wrong thing, because I should have done it myself. You can't argue logic like that, so whatever... I just let it go. Today she ran another errand for me: she was supposed to pick up a few card supplies I need (she works right by the card shop). I called her this afternoon at work and had her write down exactly what I needed (jersey-size top loads and team bags). I even gave her my last two team bags to take with her so she'd get the right thing. She didn't. She got the top loads I'd asked for, but instead of team bags, she bought the much larger (and more expensive) graded card sleeves. I needed the team bags badly. I need them to package up the cards I sold on eBay, to mail out tomorrow. I really wasn't very happy about this, not at all. We wound up getting in a huge argument over it. She just will not admit she's wrong. Even after I tell her over and over "if they don't have exactly what I need, don't buy anything at all", she still buys the wrong stuff and then she gets all defensive and angry when I get mad at her for buying the wrong stuff. And I was pretty angry. I need to package up the cards I sold so I can mail them out tomorrow and now I can't, which may cause me some trouble with the auction winners. I'm also angry because whenever we argue about this, Mom uses driving against me, like a weapon. See, I don't drive. I never have. When I was 16 my Dad promised to get me a car and teach me how to drive, but he never did. Then, my younger sister got pregnant a year or two later and my Mom got her a car and a license, but she never got me set up. I was forgotten, neglected, in that area. Years later, when I really wanted to get a car, my Mom told me I'd have to move out if I did because if I had a license and lived with her, it would raise her insurance premiums. I couldn't afford an apartment and all of the expenses that go with that, so I had to forget about getting a car. Eventually, a friend of mine taught me how to drive her car and I eventually got a restricted license, but by then, I was deep in debt and couldn't afford to get a car. I'm still in debt, so I still don't drive. It's a sore spot for me. I feel utterly helpless at times, like I'm stranded, like the whole world is moving and I'm stuck in one spot. It makes me angry too, because everyone else I know is driving but me. I also didn't think it was fair that my younger sister got a car before I did, got put on the right path, while all I got was put off to the side. Like I said, it's a sore spot for me, a vulnerability. But that's where Mom always hits me in these arguments: "I just won't run anymore errands for you, you can go do them yourself!" In boxing, that would be considered a "low blow". You see, to get to that card shop myself would require 4-6 buses (4-6 bus tickets: $5-$6.50) and at least 2 1/2 hours of travel time. Not to mention standing out in the heat and/or rain at the bus stops waiting for the buses. Sure, I can do this stuff myself, but it's a major pain in the ass for me. It takes her just 10-15 minutes to run there after work, so I don't see it as a big deal to ask for her help. Don't get me wrong, I'm not a total jerk, I know it's still an inconvenience for her to run errands for me, and I try not to ask her to do it too often. I certainly wouldn't ask her to run back and forth to the same places over and over again, but now she has to. She's got to take the wrong things she bought back for refunds, which is why I tell her all the time "if they don't have exactly what I need, don't buy anything at all". I feel bad because now she has to make these extra trips and I'm not happy because I didn't get the things I needed. I'm not quite sure why she got so angry though. To me, it's simple: she screwed up. If it was me, I'd have just acknowledged that. Instead, she immediately starts getting defensive (passing the blame from her to me), then she starts yelling at me, and then she got nasty and vindictive (with the driving stuff). After that, it was straight on to totally irrational (complete with tantrum). All the while, the only thing I got as to why she is angry is that she's tired of my complaining when she screws up, although she completely refuses to acknowledge that she screwed up at all. Irrational and illogical. After an hour, I went back to try and talk to her again, to reason with her, hoping she'd calmed down, but she was fast asleep. Maybe she was just tired and cranky today, who knows? But now I am in a really bad position. I have one more errand I need her to run for me. She usually mails stuff for me on Wednesdays, but she was going to do it on Thursday this week...tomorrow... and I have no idea if she's going to do it now or not. Of course, I have no money for busfare either, so even if I want to go do it myself, I can't. I'm pretty much screwed. Damn, I was in such a good mood today too. I even took some time this morning and hooked up Mom's new VCR for her. I was hoping to surprise her. I guess I got the surprise.

It's happened so many times, the incidents have all blended together to become the continual letdown that is my life. 2.Have you ever been told about a wonderful present that you were never given? Maybe they went as far as telling you exactly what it was, how wonderful it would be and how much they would have loved for you to have it, but for whatever reason, they wouldn't be giving it to you after all? How did you feel about that? When I was a teenager, around 16, and lived with my Dad, he told me he was going to get me my first car and teach me how to drive. "A Mighty Wind": My Review When "A Mighty Wind" first came out earlier this year, I'd wanted to go see it very, very badly. Unfotunately, no one else I knew wanted to go see it with me. Also, it was only playing in out-of-town theaters (it had a limited release), so I wound up missing out on it altogether. Until now. I'd downloaded it awhile back and finally decided to watch it tonight, instead of doing the smart thing and going to bed at a decent hour. I'm glad I stayed up. What a great movie! Christopher Guest did it again! Bravo! He is the absolute master of the "mockumentary" (a term I hear he detests). After co-starring in (and co-writing) "This Is Spinal Tap" (the original "mockumentary"), he went on and co-wrote (with Eugene Levy) and directed "Waiting For Guffman" and "Best In Show", two highly enjoyable movies. And now, he does it again with "A Mighty Wind". Like all of his films, the humor is laid back, subtle, and very clever. "Sublimely hilarious" would be an apt description of all three films. As always, this movie features a talented ensemble cast, bringing to life a host of fresh, funny, and often, wacky characters. Fred Willard, in particular, had me in stitches ("Wha' happened!?!). Besides all of that, this movie features some truly great folk music as well, created by, and performed by, the cast members themselves. I've been wanting to pick up the soundtrack for this film since it first came out. There are some really nice, catchy folk songs on there! Eugene Levy and Catherine O'Hara's folk ballads are especially good. They made some gorgeous music together, folks. When I get a DVD player, this is a definite purchase. I'd highly recommend this movie to anyone who can appreciate subtle humour, but if you're looking for dick jokes and wisecracks, this one ain't for you.

Just Say No... To Howard Dean I've come to the conclusion that Howard Dean is definitely not the right person for the job of President of The United States. I looked into his positions on the issues and I was turned off right away at his pro-gun, pro-NRA stance on the gun problem in America (a non-issue to Dean). Over 30,000 Americans die because of gun-related deaths every year but Dean doesn't even consider it a real issue. It's disgraceful, if you ask me. Then, the other day, he was caught in a blatant lie, a blatant attempt at telling people what they want to hear just to get their votes. He tells union supporters that he has no interest in raising the retirement age, but that doesn't jibe with what he's said in the past. Here is what he said to the union folk: "I have never favored Social Security retirement at the age of 70, nor do I favor one of 68." - Howard Dean at the AFL-CIO Democratic presidential candidate forum, Aug. 5, 2003 And here's what he's said in the past: "The way to balance the budget, Dean said, is for Congress to cut Social Security, move the retirement age to 70, cut defense, Medicare and veterans pensions, while the states cut almost everything else. 'It would be tough but we could do it,' he said." News story on a breakfast meeting Dean held with reporters by Miles Benson, Newhouse News Service, March 3, 1995 And more of the same: "I absolutely agree we need to reduce theI mean, to increase the retirement age. There will be cuts and losses of some benefits, but I believe that Sen. Packwood is on exactly the right track." Howard Dean on CNN's Crossfire, Feb. 28, 1995 And the not-so-past: "Just six weeks ago, Dean told NBC, 'I would also entertain taking the retirement age up to 68.' " Deborah Orin, "Is Dean Being Honest? Well, Define 'Honest,' " New York Post, Aug. 8, 2003 Besides all that, he seems to support prayer in public schools, something I am dead set against, and he is wishy washy on a lot of issues, preferring to let the states handle the problems themselves, which isn't always good. Is this the guy we want as our leader? I don't want him, that's for sure. I'm still very much for Dennis Kucinich, but I had considered Dean as a "backup", in case Kucinich can't garner enough support to win the nomination. Now I'm going to focus more on Bob Graham or Dick Gephart as my backup candidates. Howard Dean may be the Democratic frontrunner right now, but for me, he's out of the running. Of course, if I had to choose between him and having Bush back in office, he'd be back in the running again. Sometimes, you just have go with the lesser of two evils.

Hypocrisy, Arrogance, & Death I went to urlLink FARK today and saw urlLink yet another infuriating article that makes me even more angry with my government (if that is even possible at this point). Apparently, the U.S. used "napalm-like" firebombs over in Iraq, and our military has the gall to defend their usage. Freaking napalm... unbelievable. Don't get me wrong now, I understand that war is hellish by nature, it's not a pretty thing and there are plenty of horrible deaths incurred in any war, but napalm? Come on! We make a big deal out of the way Saddam Hussein tortured people and yet, it's ok for us to use a weapon designed to cause the most extreme, excruciating pain imaginable? For those who don't know, napalm is a gooey mix of melted styrofoam and gasoline. If you get hit with napalm, you burn.... and you burn, and burn and burn. It doesn't come off you and you can't really estinguish it. It's a horrific way to die, and for those who aren't lucky enough to die right away, it has to be the worst pain imaginable. I just don't get it. How can we, as Americans, as people who are supposed to be concerned with Human Rights, allow our military to use such nasty weapons? The hypocrisy is maddening. I am totally understanding why we are so hated in the world. We tell nations to do as we say, not as we do. We punish other nations for breaking the rules while we do as we damn well please. America is the most powerful nation on the face of the Earth, but we are also the most arrogant. And it just isn't the napalm, it's many things. For instance, the massive bombs that were dropped (also during the war), on a crowded restaurant in hopes of nailing Hussein. It took awhile to sink in before I realized just what that really meant. We wiped out a lot of civilians in the hopes of killing one man. Wiped them out. Killed, injured, mutilated, maimed, burned, destroyed... men, women, children, babies... to get one man... who, as it turned out, wasn't even there when the bombs fell. How arrogant is that? Terrorists kill our civilians and it's a worldwide tragedy, but we killed Iraqi civilians like they were nothing, like they didn't even exist, like their lives didn't matter because they weren't Americans. It's sickening. I'm sickened. I have never been more ashamed of my government, of my country, than I have since Bush and his fascist cronies (don't even get me started on Rumsfeld and Ashcroft) took over. I love America, but I do not like what we are doing or the direction we are headed.

urlLink The Friday Five 1. What's the last place you traveled to, outside your own home state/country? Unfortunately, the last place I traveled to was the 1982 World's Fair in Knoxville, Tennessee. It's unfortunate because I love traveling but haven't done it for over 20 years. Man... just thinking about that makes me sad. 2. What's the most bizarre/unusual thing that's ever happened to you while traveling? One year, when I was a kid, we went up to Pennsylvania during Christmastime. One day, during that vacation, I was outside, all by myself, sitting in a tree at my Grandparent's house, just looking at the asnow on the hills and cornfields and enjoying the solitude. When I tried to get down from the tree, I slipped and my foot got caught between two limbs and I was left hanging upside down. I couldn't quite touch the ground below, and, because of the winter clothes, I wasn't able to reach back up to the tree limbs. I tried to get myself out of this situation for awhile, but it was hopeless. I was helpless. Everyone else was in the house and there wasn't anyone around to help me, so I did the only thing I could do at that point and scream for help. I really felt stupid having to do that, and I felt even more so after my Dad had to come outside and rescue me. I had yelled for awhile before he came out and was starting to get worried, so I was quite relieved when he came out and freed me from the tree, even though I felt like a moron. Everyone got a good laugh out of my dilemma, including me. 3. If you could take off to anywhere, money and time being no object, where would you go? Europe. More specifically, I would love to visit Italy (Venice, Rome, and Florence), England (London), Ireland, Scotland, and Greece (Athens and Crete). I don't care much for France, but I would love to see the palace of "The Sun King" in Versailles. I think I'd have to hit Amsterdam, and there are places in Spain I'd like to visit as well. Hell, if money and time we no object, I'd want to see it all, baby! 4. Do you prefer traveling by plane, train or car? One of the best things about traveling is getting to see the places you're traveling through firsthand, up close. Cars are the best for doing that, so I'd say car travel would be preferable. I've never traveled by train, but I'd like to, someday. 5. What's the next place on your list to visit? I'm someone who would go anywhere, anytime, if given the opportunity. However, at this time, I have no car and no money, so I have no list.

Why The RIAA Sucks Ass: A Breakdown Rather than going to bed early, as I'd planned, I went and downloaded a bunch of music instead; music that they don't play on the radio (in my area, anyway), and music I wouldn't have been able to hear otherwise. To me, the fact that the RIAA wants to stop me from doing what I did is proof that they are a bunch of total nimrods. It's a great tool for consumers to discover new music and every argument against it is just arrogance and/or ignorance. Let's face it, most radio stations suck and you will hear more music during an elevator ride than you would in a whole night of watching MTV. Hell, had it not been for word of mouth between fellow music lovers, I probably wouldn't have ever discovered these bands in the first place: The Mooney Suzuki and Queens Of The Stone Age. My friend Rob told me about The Mooney Suzuki and I downloaded stuff from them before and liked what I heard, but it's been so long since I heard them, I felt I had to give them another listen. I am definitely going to be buying their CD "Electric Sweat". It rocks. I heard my bandmate Al mention Queens Of The Stone Age tonight (we were talking about Dave Grohl) and then I found that Mark Lanegan (from The Screaming Trees) sang on some of their stuff and I had to have a listen. I've only listened to 2 songs so far, but I like what I've heard and may buy eventually buy all of their CDs. See that, RIAA? See how it works? It's to your benefit , you ignorant a-holes. More namecalling? Ok: the RIAA are a bunch of stupid arrogant turds. There is no reason a CD should cost nearly $20. None whatsoever. If they would only take their heads out of their asses for a moment, they would see that they could cut back on certain expenses and pass the savings on to the consumer. What costs am I referring to? How about the free CDs they send to every record store for "in store play"? I have several friends who work in record stores and they've all told me what I already knew: the vast majority of those CDs do not get played . They get sold on eBay by the people who work in those stores. Cut those out, and then, how about this idea: stop the lawsuits against music lovers. They could save tons of money, money that would have been spent towards pointless litigation. Pointless, because it will not end filesharing. In fact, in the end, it will only serve to strengthen public hatred towards the Recording Industry. I think it's safe to say the RIAA is already on shaky ground with the public anyway. People are tired of being gouged for music that they love. Charging $18 for a single CD is ridiculous. You should be able to buy a whole CD for $10 (or less). Also, I've heard a lot of people complain that most CDs today suck and aren't worth the $18 price tag. There are also a ton of people out there who only like certain songs; they're not going to buy whole CD no matter what, and the RIAA is completely ignoring them... ignoring an entire market! The "singles" market in America seemed to have faded away with 45's and "cassingles", but the demand for "the hit song" did never went away. The RIAA doesn't listen to consumers and now they're paying the price for their arrogance and/or ignorance. They don't seem to be willing to make any compromises with the CD buying public, so the CD buying public has made their own changes. Enter CD-Rs. Personally, I don't support people who make burns of CDs they like instead of of buying the CDs they like. I do think it's ok to download a CD in order to listen to it a few times in order to see whether it's worth buying or not, but ultimately, you have to buy the CDs of bands you like in order to keep those bands signed to a label. If they don't sell many CDs, they won't be putting out too many more records. It's very simple to understand. Call it a Catch-22. People want to support their favorite artists, but many, myself included, would rather not support the RIAA anymore. They've made it abundantly clear how they feel about we consumers. Unfortunately, the RIAA holds the copyrights, so no matter how much people hate the RIAA, they have to be included in any viable solution. If they choose to hear the public finally, they would cut the costs of CDs in stores an they would create an inexpensive download site so people could download individual songs if they choose. Hell, they could even have a machine in every record store that would burn and properly label CDs filled with songs of the buyers choice. All they'd need is a music database to select from and a professional quality CD burner/packaging machine. It's quite clear to me: the RIAA should be investing their time and money in computers and fresh ideas, not in lawyers and pointless lawsuits. As rich and as powerful as they are, they should be on top of the technology game, not impeding it's progress. But hey, it's like I said before: the RIAA are a bunch of stupid arrogant turds. And that's probably an understatement. So endeth my rant for today. Onward, to bed...

urlLink Wednesday What-Ifs 1. What if you were offered the opportunity to have an operation that would increase your intelligence, but noticeably decrease your level of happiness? No thanks. I'd rather be happy and content than a super genius. 2. What if you had to choose between an operation that would leave you without hands, or an operation that would leave you with no feet? I need my hands to play guitar, to type, to use the remote control... for almost everything. All I use my feet for are for walking and playing "this little piggie". 3. What if you had to decide whether to risk your life and give a kidney to a dying relative whom you've never met, but whose kidneys match yours exactly? Hmmm.. that's a toughie. I'd probably say "no". Voluntary surgery like that isn't something you do for just anyone. I mean, there are people out there now who need kidneys and I'm not standing in line waiting to give one away. 4. What if you could have an operation that would allow you to morph into any animal at will, but would steal your ability of human speech? That sounds like a fair trade off. I could soar like an eagle as an eagle, but I couldn't talk? Sign me up. I would probably be a bird right off the bat, but then I'd want to be a cougar for awhile. 5. What if you could have an operation to change one thing about yourself -- what would it be? I'd request a reverse-cashectomy, where the surgeon would implant loads of cash into my checking account. Actually, if I could have an operation to change one thing about me it would be a stomach staple operation, to make me lose weight.

"Inside The Actor's Studio" - Questionnaire Here are my answers to the set of questions originally put together by Bernard Pivot and asked by James Lipton at the end of every episode of "Inside The Actor's Studio": What is your favorite word? Peace. Strangely enough, my second choice was "fart", because it's a silly word and it makes me laugh. What is your least favorite word? Nigger. It's an ugly word no matter who uses it or how it's used. What turns you on creatively, spiritually or emotionally? Intelligence, beauty, and laughter. What turns you off? Hatred, negativity, and greed. What is your favorite curse word? I don't cuss a lot, but I do use "the F word", with it's many wonderful variations, from time to time. What sound or noise do you love? Rain on the rooftop, laughter, the sound of a Fender Strat played through a large amplifier (with minimal distortion). What sound or noise do you hate? The sound of a ringing phone, plus anything that keeps me from sleeping: the lady next door hammering in the morning, the lawn getting mowed, booming car stereos, etc... What profession other than your own would you like to attempt? I would probably enjoy being a writer of some sort. I think I could be a decent school teacher though. What profession would you not like to do? Telemarketing. If Heaven exists, what would you like to hear God say when you arrive at the Pearly Gates? "Hey, given what you had to work with, I wouldn't have believed in me either!"

The Blues Airing on PBS all week is a terrific series about Blues music called " urlLink Martin Scorsese Presents The Blues ". I caught the first episode yesterday and I watched the second one tonight. Well done, and well worth watching for fans of the blues or for anyone wanting an introduction to the blues. Besides getting to see some great archival footage and hear a lot of great music, each episode is directed by a different director, so each episode has a different feel to it. Sunday's was directed by Scorcese, my favorite so far, and tonight's was directed by Wim Wenders. My only complaint thus far is the editing in of newly recorded performances of modern artists. It seems pointless, or more accurately, it seems like a blatant attempt to sell the new box set, featuring these newly recorded tracks. Now, don't get me wrong, I loved seeing Los Lobos doing J.B. Lenoir's "Voodoo Music", but not spliced in half with J.B.'s original song so that you only get a partial performance from either. It's kind of annoying. "Martin Scorsese Presents The Blues" airs all week this week on PBS, and repeats three times per night. For my fellow Jimi Hendrix fanatics, the episode that airs on Oct. 2nd will feature some Hendrix blues performances! Sweet!

"You'd Better Not Call Me" Three posts below, I wrote about the ridiculous Oklahoma federal court judge, Judge Lee R. West, who blocked the National No-Call list that prevents solicitors from calling you at home (who is now being hounded at his home and his office by non-stop telephone calls from angry Americans), and I'm glad to report that Congress took over and, in effect, reversed his reversal. Excellent job, congressmen and congresswomen, but it's not over yet. Tonight, another ridiculous federal court judge, this one in Denver, Judge Edward W. Nottingham, has blocked the No-Call list again, and this time , it will have to be decided in court. This judge says the No-Call list is, get this, a free speech violation: "The Federal Trade Commission has chosen to entangle itself too much in the consumers' decision by manipulating consumer choice and favoring speech by charitable (organizations) over commercial speech." He's saying that telemarketers are having their speech rights violated because they aren't allowed to call us in our homes but charitable organizations are. So freaking what? What about our rights, the individuals who are being pestered in our homes? Why are our rights, individual rights, less important that so-called corporate rights? What is our society coming to? I think we, the people, have lost hold of our country. It has slipped from being about our rights to being about corporate rights. It's us versus them and they are winning. Or have they already won? By the way, the reason the title of this post is in quotation marks, is because it's a song title, from the band Zebra, a totally rocking, kickass song, but I'm sure very few, if any, got the reference.

Very Disturbing Apparently the whole suing-our-customers thing wasn't working for them, so now the RIAA is urlLink going into our schools . Instead of suing 12-year olds, they are going to try and get to them in their schools, as authority figures, teaching the impressionable youngsters about what is right and what is wrong. This is seriously disturbing to me. How in the hell does a corporate entity, a trade group, gain access to our school systems, to our children, and why the hell are we letting it happen? This is wrong on so many levels. Here's a few choice bits about the RIAA's school program: "As early as next month the industry will begin promoting a "stealing is bad" message in schools, teaming up with Junior Achievement on an hourlong class for fifth- through ninth-graders on the history of copyright law and the evils of online file sharing. The effort includes games like "Starving Artist," in which students pretend to be musicians whose work is downloaded free from the Internet, and a crossword puzzle called "Surfing for Trouble." Junior Achievement is projecting that the lesson, which will be taught both in school and after school, will be used in 36,000 classrooms nationwide and has the potential of reaching 900,000 students in grades five through nine, or about 10 percent of all students in those grade levels. In the role-playing activity Starving Artist, for example, groups of students are encouraged to come up with an idea for a musical act, write lyrics and design a CD cover only to be told by a volunteer teacher their work can be downloaded free. According to the lesson, the volunteer would then "ask them how they felt when they realized that their work was stolen and that they would not get anything for their efforts." That is fucking sickening . Most artists do not care about filesharing, they just want their music heard, in fact, many artists fully support filesharing. Recording artists make their money from concerts and merchandising, not from CD sales. It's the greedy record company weasels who are pushing this issue, not the artists. They want to keep their big, undeserved bucks to keep flowing in, consumers be damned. They don't listen to consumers (and artists) when we tell them CD prices are too high, they ignore a large consumer base who are willing to pay for downloading services, and instead of changing with the times, they bully and sue their customers. Any other business who behaved like that would go under, and deservedly so, so why is the RIAA being coddled then? It's ridiculous, and who knows how far they will go with this. I think they've gone too far already. In my opinion, allowing them to push their agenda in our school system is going too far. Something must be done to stop this.

I Might Have My #2 Man Ok, I'm still pulling for urlLink Dennis Kucinich to get the Democratic nod to run as our next President, but as I've said all along, I don't think he's got much of a chance. He's too extreme for most people (which is why I like him, he'd make some real changes), he doesn't have a warm and fluffy public image (he's very businesslike, which is also good, he wants to get things done), and then there's his name, Kucinich, which sounds too... European, let's say. See, I don't have a lot of faith in the average American voter. I don't think most will make the smart decision based on the candidate's politics. I think most Americans vote for our President the way High School kids vote for the Homecoming Queen. It's a big popularity contest, but on a grander scale. Anyway, I've looked into several of the other candidates, trying to choose a decent "back-up candidate" to support if Kucinich should drop out, but I've had problems with most all of the folks running. For example, Howard Dean, the current front-runner, is too urlLink Pro-NRA (he received an A+ rating from the NRA), and he has flip-flopped on important labor issues (he said he'd raise the working age, and then said he wouldn't). Besides that, his personality and TV image won't be winning him many votes. He comes off as a little... weird, kind of doofus-y. I think he'd guarantee Bush another four years if he gets the Democratic nomination. So, as I was saying, I looked around for a suitable back-up candidate and I have finally found someone I like, someone who not only could win the presidency, but who could also be a good leader: urlLink Wesley Clark . I first heard of him during the recent War in Iraq, where he was positioned as CNN's main military analyst. I thought he was a well-spoken, intelligent, and likable man. I was surprised as can be to find out that he was a Democrat, and I was even more surprised to hear that he has joined in the running for the presidency. I checked out urlLink his website earlier today and read up on urlLink where he stands on the issues of the day . I'm impressed with what he has to say so far, although he hasn't covered everything I want covered yet, plus I understand he made some questionable calls during his time as NATO Commander in Kosovo and has said some questionable things in the media, so I still need to do some more research on the man. urlLink The Friday Five 1. Who is your favorite singer/musician? Why? Of all-time, it'd have to be Jimi Hendrix. I can relate to his words and music, the rhythms, his singing, and I really enjoy his creativity. He was one-of-a-kind, a truly amazing musician. Of current musicians, I like David Hidalgo a lot. He's the lead singer of Los Lobos, but he's been involved with a few great side projects too (notably, The Latin Playboys & Houndog). He's a great singer (with a unique voice), a great guitar player (can seamlessly go from rockabilly to traditional Mexican music to Hendrix), a versatile musican (plays guitar, accordian, and various Mexican instruments), and he is also very inventive, creative. I have a lot of respect for the guy. 2. What one singer/musician can you not stand? Why? Geez, just one? There is so much bad music being made today that it'd be impossible to single out any one. I like real music, from the heart, not the phony-baloney plastic garbage that tries to pass for music. 3. If your favorite singer wasn't in the music business, do you think you would still like him/her as a person? Absolutely. Hendrix was a pretty funny guy, he enjoyed Sci-Fi, he was a music lover, and he was carefree and easy-going. Hidalgo is another music fan, very open-minded, and is a pretty laid back guy. 4. Have you been to any concerts? If yes, who put on the best show? Yep, in fact, I have a section of my blog devoted to the concerts I've seen. Of all the ones I've seen, Crosby, Stills, and Nash may have been the most enjoyable, but Stevie Ray Vaughan was the most impressive. he left me awestruck. 5. What are your thoughts on downloading free music online vs. purchasing albums? Do you feel the RIAA is right in its pursuit to stop people from dowloading free music? I've written about this several times on my blog. I don't think there's anything wrong with downloading music for free. I think it allows people to listen to a lot of different music that they'd never hear otherwise and can be a great benefit to the artists and their record companies. However, if the music is readily available in stores, I don't think people should be burning it to disc. It's a fine line between sampling and stealing. As far as the RIAA is concerned, they can kiss my ass. If there was a way to cut them out of the picture all together, I'd be all for it. Suing their customers rather than adapting to change shows just how much they care about money and how little thay care about consumers. As a musician myself, I think what they are doing is shameful. If they really wanted to stop filesharing, or reduce it anyway (filesharing will not be going away anytime soon), they need to reduce the prices for CDs. They should cost no more than $10 each. In fact, Tom Petty wanted to name one of his CDs "$9.99". I think if most people had to choose between a burned copy or the real thing, they'd want the real thing, but at $18 a pop, it's just not worth it. The problem is, the RIAA is a monopoly and they want to continue making us pay $18 because it's more money for them. They don't want to change the way things have been going, apparently feeling that it's not to their benefit. Unfortunately for us, there is no alternative to RIAA products, which is why people are burning downloaded music or buying everything used. If they'd lower their prices, make them more realistically priced, people would burn CDs less and buy more new product. Very simple solution, but the RIAA must begin adapting, changing. Unfortunately, with these ongoing lawsuits, they have shown no willingness to do so. So screw 'em.

R.I.P Johhny Cash The world lost a great one today, a giant. I first heard Johnny Cash when I was 12 years old. I was on vacation up in Pennsylvania, staying with my maternal grandparents, and my Grandmother had a bunch of Country Music 8-track tapes. I've always been a music lover, always been interested in hearing new music, plus, I think I was bored up there, so I wound up playing a bunch of her tapes. I didn't like most of the tapes she had, but I did like the ones by Johnny Cash. His music was different than any other music I'd ever heard, and with his voice, you almost had to listen to him. I think it's a tribute to his greatness that his music was able to get through to a 12 year old rock & roll fan. Johnny Cash walked the line. He appeared to be an outlaw, always dressed in black with his tough as nails exterior, a badass for sure, but you knew he was really a good guy down inside, where it really mattered. He was dark and mysterious and his music was simple and eloquent. He could break your heart just as easily as he could kick your ass. I'm really not much of a country music fan, especially this crap that passes for country music nowadays, but I've always loved and respected Johnny Cash. He will be missed. If you're so inclined, there is a nice urlLink Johnny Cash thread over on a FARK , a great tribute to the man and his music. I got teary-eyed reading it myself, so be forewarned. Incidentally, this is the second day in a row that a Fark thread has had that effect on me. Yesterday, being the 2nd anniversary of the Sept. 11th attacks, FARK re-published urlLink their original thread from Sept. 11th, 2001 . I felt all the same emotions come back again reading it. It puts you right there again, in all of that day's surreal violence and intense sadness.

urlLink Tuesday Chooseday Would you rather: Marry a complete stranger and spend 18 hours a day with them OR marry your soulmate and best friend, but never get to spend more than 2 hours a day with them? The complete stranger thing could be interesting, if we got along well and learned to love each other, but if we didn't... In truth, I value and respect marriage too much to jump into it with a total stranger. If I'm going to marry someone, it's going to be someone I really love and want to be with, a soulmate and best friend, someone who loves me and wants to be with me too. Have lice OR tapeworms? Lice. Long ago, I saw a documentary about the terrible health conditions in parts of Africa and I saw one person hold out their arm and you could see a long worm wriggling under their skin , another had a tiny one moving around in their eye ... it totally freaked me out. There were some even more disgusting ones too, but I don't even want to think about them. I mean, just the thought of having worms moving around inside my body... (shivers). So yeah, lice would be better. They are external and I could kill them easily enough. Be known as a mean drunk OR a complete prude? I'd rather be a complete prude. A mean drunk is hurtful to people, a prude isn't. Have both big toes cut off with a hacksaw OR slam your finger in a car door ... 15 times? I don't gamble with the Mob, so there's no reason to pick either of these options. However, if I had to choose, I'd go with slamming a finger in a car door 15 times... just as long as I get to choose which finger (because I'm a guitar player, with few fingers to spare).

Not good. I think the reason I slept so long today was because of Jimmy (one of my cats) waking me up last night. I was dead asleep last night, and suddenly I was woken up by Jimmy jumping up on my bed, or more accurately, jumping up on top of me while I was lying in my bed. He's not a lightweight. He walked up my back, settled on my shoulders, and started meowing. I was half asleep and was trying to figure out whether he just wanted some attention or if there was something wrong. He just wanted some attention. I scratched his head a little and started falling asleep again, but he wanted more attention and began sticking his face in mine, which is irritating as hell. I can't stand cat whiskers tickling my nose. I got him to lie down for a minute, but then he was off, getting into stuff in my room. Jimmy doesn't come into my room much, but when he does, he always makes a nuisance out of himself. He doesn't know how to just chill, like his brother does; Jimmy's always doing something, getting into something. In the dark, and half asleep, it is particularly annoying because I can't see what it is he's doing, I just hear things. Luckily, he didn't stay too long last night. Got off on a bit of a "cat tangent" there, but anyway, I do need to get back to last week's schedule: in bed by Midnight, up by 8am. I need to keep it that way so I can get a job, and for when I go set up at the flea market (I'll have to be up by 6am for that). Speaking of which, I got a little more "stock" in today. A lot of 26 tapes arrived, mostly easy listening/soft rock, but there are a few good ones in there that I will keep for myself. I paid $11.31 for the lot, here is what I got: Bryan Adams "Into The Fire", Air Supply "Greatest Hits", David Bowie "Let's Dance", Bread "Anthology", Peabo Bryson "Straight From The Heart", Cheap Trick "At Budokan", Phil Collins "Hello, I Must Be Going" & "No Jacket Required", The Commodores "Nightshift", Creedence Clearwater Revival "Chronicle", Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young "So Far", Bryan Ferry "Street Life: 20 Greatest Hits", Genesis "Genesis" & "Invisable Touch", Gold and Platunum "Vol 2.", Elton John "Leather Jackets", Kansas "The Best of Kansas", REO Speedwagon "Hi Infidelity", Lionel Richie "Cant Slow Down", Simply Red "Picture Book", Barbra Streisand "Memories", Toto "TotoIV", Pete Townsend "White City: A Novel", Yes "90125" One other tape I got was bad, Genesis "Abacab", which sucks. I was looking forward to hearing that one again. Someone taped some crappy dance music over it. Moron. The Cheap Trick tape may be bad too, I will have to play it later. I put it on for a few seconds earlier and I thought I heard some tape flutter. I paid a little more per tape than I normally would (about .45 each), but I had planned on keeping about 8 of them for myself, so a little extra was ok. Besides the tapes, I got two payments in today too, $25 worth, which will go to Mom. Oh, I won another tape auction today. Kind of a mistake though. I opened it with 40 seconds left and, panicking, put a quick bid in without reading the description well. It was a 55 tape lot, but only about 25 of the tapes even have cases (I don't know whether that means they have cases and inserts, or just cases), there's another 20 tapes with no cases and presumably no inserts, and the rest are just homemade copies. Not a great auction. I probably shouldn't have bid at all, but as I said, I panicked. I won the whole lot for $7.29 (includes shipping). Not a great buy, but i will live with it. I think that's about all I had posted before. Man, that was annoying. Weird too. I posted my blog but instead of going through, I got a log-in page. Then, I hit the back button and I got someone else's blog screen ("Welcome back, Gilda"). Of course, me being me, I left a little message there for her, just to make her scratch her head. That's kind of scary though. I mean, if I were a malicious person, I could've deleted her whole blog, just to be a dick. I wonder if mine was open to someone else. (shivers) Anyway, I hope this one goes through.

urlLink The Friday Five 1. What housekeeping chore(s) do you hate doing the most? I hate washing the dishes. I always wind up splashing dishwater on my belly, soaking my shirt, and I can't stand that. I also hate trying to fit my hands inside of cups. I know, I know... I could just get an apron and they probably make some gizmo to wash inside of cups, but I don't have them and I'm not looking either. It's kind of weird, I didn't mind doing dishes when I worked as a dishwasher (as a teenager), but I've always hated doing them at home, even as a kid. 2. Are there any that you like or don't mind doing? I don't mind vacuuming, doing laundry, or taking the trash out. Sweeping the kitchen or the porch is ok too. 3. Do you have a routine throughout the week or just clean as it's needed? I need a routine. The amount of cleaning I do depends heavily on 1) if company is expected or 2) where or not I can stand looking at the mess anymore. Sad. 4. Do you have any odd cleaning/housekeeping quirks or rules? No, not really. 5. What was the last thing you cleaned? Probably the kitchen counter. I always make a mess with tea bags and empty Equal packets (but I do clean them up).

I put it on as I was lying down to sleep and I wound up listening to it twice! I've got Pat Benatar's "Live From Earth" tape on right now. Watching on TV: In the daytime, I'm getting in the habit of watching "Quincy M.E." from Noon-1pm, then "Columbo", from 1pm-2:30pm (sometimes 3pm). Playing: I played Rummy with Jess when he was down, but that's about it. Nothing on the computer. Reading: Nothing still. I have to get into the habit of reading during the day. Grumblings I know I've been doing a lot of grumbling here lately, it's probably not much fun to read, but it's true reflection of how I'm feeling: angry and frustrated. I hate owing people money and I hate not having money of my own. I hate all of this sitting around waiting for things to happen. And most of all, I hate the helplessness I feel, feeling like I can't do anything on my own. I'm one messed up, unhappy puppy. I got just one payment in today. One. For $5.00... a far cry from what I need. I have about $150 due in, that's how much I need. No tape-filled packages for me either. I have about 10 of those due in. Very frustrating. I played a few tapes in my room, checking them out, and found several that look perfect but work like shit. They screech very loudly in the player. Yay. I guess I'm going to have to check out all of them before I sell them. Speaking of which, I called the USA Flea Market to get prices and they're a bit higher than the two down here, about $18 a day, which means I have to sell 18 tapes just pay for the table, and another 5 tapes just to break even. I definitely will need to bring my best tapes along if I'm going to be able to do that, so I'll have to put off the flea market for another week. Hopefully some of my packages will have arrived by then. I called my bank today, the International Money Orders I got in are ok, no $15 charges, because they're drawn on American Banks. That's some good news anyhow.

Wednesday Night I just got back from the band meeting (we met over at The Wing House). We sat around talking and drinking most of the time. The guys had wings and bought beer and of course, I had no money for anything. I totally felt like a jerk. The odd man out. They bought a couple pitchers of beer and I had some too. I hate that. I felt like such a leech. We did get some work done, we got a few new cover songs chosen (JP wants more modern songs) and we talked over the Ronnie/Santana situation and talked about some songs that we need to tighten. We were there for over three hours. Afterwards, JP came over and we worked on a couple newer songs that we're going to cover. He didn't stay long. We're going to practice next Thursday over at Circle (three hours), just the four of us, so I really need to get practicing daily again. By the way, I got absolutely no mail in today... nothing. Dammit. I'm getting very frustrated. Speaking of frustrated... the system restore I did earlier appears to have removed a Norton Anti-Virus file somehow, and after I re-started my computer, it wouldn't start-up again. I kept getting a "NAV Auto Protect" message telling me a NAV.dll file was missing. I kept having to go into safe mode to get to my desktop, every time I booted to normal mode, I got the NAV warning. I took Norton off my start-up list and then I kept getting the Microsoft Blue Screen Of Death. It took me over two hours of struggling, but I finally have it up and running, with everything back to normal again. To fix the problems, I had to undo my sytem restore (I did a system restore initially to get rid of whatever that last Windows Update did), then I re-installed Norton (over Norton), but that didn't work, so I had to unistall Norton altogether, and then I re-installed it all over again after I did a new system restore. What a pain in the ass!

Sitting Around, Waiting That's my day so far, just sitting around waiting on mail and phone calls. I was up by 10am, which is good (I was afraid I was going to sleep until Noon... or later), but I still haven't done jack all day. I played around on the computer and did a system restore to fix a problem I was having (when I'd open a 2nd window, it wouldn't open full size, but as a minimized box) and then I watched half a "Quincy M.E." and a whole "Columbo". I have a lot of stuff I can, and should, be doing, but I'm trying to stay out in the living room so I don't miss the mail or UPS or Fedex if and when they come. Like I said, no mail yet. I'm anxious to get these tapes in, maybe over-anxious. I don't have a lot of patience anyway, and what little I do have is being tested. I want to put together a nice table full of items (for the flea market this weekend) but the majority of the tapes I got in so far aren't top-notch. I can't make definite plans to do the flea market if I don't have enough decent merchandise to sell. I'm also worried about the money that's due in. One guy, in particular, owes me $50 still. I sent out payment reminders to him last night, but he still hasn't made any contact with me yet, which worries me. I may or may not have a problem with my bank too. In my auctions I clearly state "PLEASE, NO INTERNATIONAL MONEY ORDERS!", in all caps, just like that, but this week I got three of them in, all from American buyers. My stupid bank charges $15 to cash each International Money Order, but it's not altogether clear which ones they charge for and which ones they don't. You know, they actually charged me $15 to cash a $12 check before. How ignorant is that? Whatever happened to common sense and courtesy? People just don't care anymore. I guess I'm going to go make some tuna. Come on, mailman!

Late Tuesday I should have been in bed about 3 hours ago. Not good, I'm slipping back to my old ways again. I will be heading to bed soon, but not soon enough. I was up late packaging eBay stuff to mailing tomorrow (today). I should've started on it sooner, but I kept putting it off all night. That seller I was angry at earlier met me halfway and is only charging $1.50 handling rather than $3.00. We had a very civil disagreement and compromised on it. It's nice when things can be settled peacefully like that without resorting to name calling and nasty comments. JP called me back tonight, Santana and Ronnie are definitely out. JP wants us to do some different covers, but he wants them from 1990 to present, nothing older, which I find pretty ridiculous. He says he doesn't want a classic rock band. Me and Jimmy are big classic rock fans, Al too, and there just isn't that much good music being made these days that we could cover. I think this is going to be a problem for me. This guy had three lots on and I wanted them all, but the one I wanted most, which had tapes in it that I wanted for myself, I lost. I got outbid a lot today, which sucks, but which also good because I really can't afford them anyway. I've been trying to get enough "stock", so I can start doing the flea market soon. Tomorrow, I expect a lot of tapes and payments in (as I have been), I'd like to do laundry and clean house too, and I need to look in the paper for work. I may shave too. It's 3am now, and I'm going to try to be up by 10am, but most likely I'll be up around 11 or 12.

Labor Day I had trouble sleeping again last night, luckily, I was up by 11am anyway. Jess got up about 1/2 later. He'd fallen asleep on the couch last night and I let him sleep there, but around 3am, he got up and went to my Mom's room. He was in a weird mood all day today, not a lot of fun to be around. I don't know if he was bored or tired or what, but it was very frustrating. I'd talk to him and he'd ignore me, like he was zoning out (or tuning me out). I think he was just ready to go home. We made new paper airplanes today and tried flying them, but there was barely a breeze and the heat outside was intense, so we came back in. He had a bad attitude outside anyway, complaining about how much his plane sucked. I cooked hamburgers for all of us (Mom made potato salad) and we chowed down. Jess pepped up a bit after we went to my room and played cards again (Rummy), but I think it's because he got off to a good start and was beating me. I came back and won the game and then his attitude came back. We listened to tapes awhile and he traded his Hangman game to me (he said it was too hard for him) for 4 cassette tapes, which he picked out (Twisted Sister, Van Halen, Nirvana, and Great White). Almost as soon as we finished trading, his Mom arrived with his brother. It wasn't long before he smarted off to my Mom (he called her a "moron"), in front of my sister, and she bawled him out, left him crying in the kitchen. He never learns. Before they got here, I made a plane for Austin, Jesse's brother, and Jess and I drew designs and stuff on it. As they were all leaving, sometime around 5pm, the boys took the planes outside and played for a little. Jess still had a bad attitude on him, complaining about his plane. Heck, he didn't say goodbye to me or my Mom until my Mom said something to him about it, and by then, it meant nothing. I don't know what his problem was, but it was a pretty rude way to end his stay here. The skies started getting dark and the wind picked up, so they took off for home. Mom and I went in and watched TV while it stormed outside. On a positive note, I paid for all of my outstanding auction wins this weekend, but I still need about $80 in my checking account (ASAP) and I owe Mom $40. I should be getting a lot of payments in tomorrow. I'd better. I'm beat. I need to take a shower and go to bed.

Lately I've Been... Listening to: My ears have been sore all week, so I haven't been listening to much music, but I did listen to the Pink Floyd tape I got at the flea market last weekend, "A Momentary Lapse Of Reason", which is incredible. Watching on TV: NBA Season has started, so I'm watching a lot of basketball. I watched the Magic play the Knicks last night (the Magic came back and won in OT) and I watched the Cavaliers/Kings game as well, in which Lebron James made his NBA debut (he looked very good, very well-rounded). I'm planning on watching the Magic/Hornets game that comes on in an hour or so. It's the first meet-up between Darrell Armstrong and the Magic, his former team. Darrell had always been my favorite Magic player and I was very disappointed that they let him go. Other than basketball, I've been watching a lot of "The Simpsons" this week. They've been playing double doses of the Simpsons' Halloween specials all week long. I'm still getting my daily double dose of "Everybody Loves Raymond" as well. I've been watching "Columbo", "Trading Spaces", CNN, and "Tough Crowd with Colin Quinn". That's about it. Downloading: Nothing. Reading: I finished "Carrie" a few days ago (great book), but haven't started anything new yet. Jamming: We were supposed to practice tonight but Jimmy, the drummer, cancelled. He had a death in his wife's family. I'm not too disappointed about not playing tonight. In fact, I was thinking about cancelling all day today myself. My ears are really sore and I have a constant headache. I was going to make it to practice regardless. I am disappointed that Jimmy can't play next week either. He has something going on at work. This is not good. By the time we get together again, three and a half weeks will have passed without a practice. That's no way to get tight as a band. In the meantime, we just have to make sure we practice at home, and JP and I are going to try to get together next week and get a demo CD put together (for club owners/bookers). Working: I was going to do some looking today, but that didn't happen. I'm feeling under the weather. Buying: I treated Mom to a birthday lunch today, Dino's pizza and wings (which I really couldn't afford). I am flat-broke and in debt, so I'm not buying much of anything right now. Selling: Sold a few cards on eBay this week, but it's still really slow going. I'm only making half of what I'd normally make. I need to move those cassette tapes I bought (the ones I didn't keep for myself). I've got over 600 of them just sitting here taking up space. Eating: Pizza and wings today. I'm still eating too much bread and cheese in my diet. I've been eating a lot of sandwiches, too many sandwiches really (turkey and cheese, peanut butter and orange marmalade, cheese). I have been eating pork loin and white rice more often, which is better for me. I need to eat more veggies too. The only veggies I've eaten lately are tomatoes and lettuce... in my turkey sandwiches. I have been drinking OJ every morning, so that's good, and I've started using decaffeinated tea bags in the evening. I'm trying to change what I eat, but when I don't do the shopping or the cooking, it's hard to maintain a proper diet. Feeling: Mentally: Frustrated. I need money. A lot of it. Physically: Blah. My ears hurt, my head hurts, and my neck hurts. Planning: To have a better life... someday.

Feeling Blah Ugh! I feel like crap today. I went to bed at an acceptable time last night (1am, I was up talking to Mom), but it took me forever to fall asleep. I got up at 9:30am, not having slept very much, and felt ok for awhile, but then I gradually started wearing down and feeling crappy. I went to take a nap around 1pm, stayed in bed until 3pm, but I had the same problem as I did last night in taking a long time to fall asleep. I think I may have napped for half an hour. It was really comfortable in bed, so I should have fallen asleep quickly, but I didn't. I don't know why I can't just fall asleep when I'm tired, like a normal human being. I wanted to run out to the post office to do my mailings after I got up from my nap (I got everything packaged this morning) but Mom is still in her nightgown and I'm feeling like crap so we put it off until tomorrow (her birthday). She's looking to buy a new car, her bank approved her for a loan, so we may do some car shopping tomorrow as well. A nice little birthday present for herself. Of course, I'm broke and have nothing to give her for her birthday, and nothing for (my nephew) Austin's the following day either. I feel terrible about that. I hate not having money. I really need a job. I was going to go put an application in at Arbys today, but I haven't gone (for the same reasons I haven't gone to the post office). I'm also really hesitant about taking another fast food job just because it's what's available. I want a good job, with benefits and insurance, but if I keep taking fast food jobs, I may never get a good job again because prospective employer's will look at my resume and see nothing worthwhile there. Another problem is that, once I get into a new job and start working day shift, when would I apply for this new job? When would I interview? If I already have my days booked with the fast food job, I really won't be able to apply at another 9-5 type job unless I take time off from my fast food job to do it (which is a good way to lose the fast food job). I'm hoping to hit that production place tomorrow (if I can figure out where it is). If not, I will wait until the ads come out on Sunday and see if they're hiring. I looked up a couple places on the internet to see what jobs they have available, but have had no luck finding anything yet. I am going to look for better jobs the rest of the week and if I find nothing in Sunday's want ads, I'll relent and go to Arby's. *sigh* Of course, being a fat guy, there's no guarantee I'll get hired there either. Looking for a job really sucks ass.

JP's Visit He didn't stay very long, but we got a lot done. We went over a bunch of songs mostly making sure we in agreement with the arrangements and changes we've made to certain songs over the past few months. He was fine with the changes I made to the arrangement of his song "Yesterday's Girl" and he also liked the riff and the solo I added to his "There For Me" as well. This Thursday we're working on our third setlist, which contains a bunch of songs we haven't played in a long time, so it was good that he came by like he did. He said he's going to try and come over a little early on Thursday too. He told me that Jimmy got his electric drum kit for home! This is very welcome news. Hopefully he'll refresh his playing skills and get back to his previous level of play. Before JP left he played a little bit of a new CD he bought, The Peter Malick Group featuring Norah Jones, which sounded very good. he asked me if I knew about the "Martin Scorsese Presents The Blues" series, and I whipped out the Jimi Hendrix CD I have from that series and played him a couple tracks. He was pretty impressed. I don't think he's ever heard Jimi play with an organist or sax player before. Afetr he split, I got online and saw that I received a new Paypal payment so I sent eBay some money and listed and re-listed a bunch of auctions tonight. Hopefully I will make some money with them. I guess I'd better get to bed; I want to get up in the morning and get my mailings done and get looking for a job.

Monday/Tuesday Over the weekend I gradually started going to bed later and getting up later, not good. I also started reading Stephen King's "Carrie" over the weekend and I stayed up late last night finishing it up (it's a very hard book to put down). It was almost 3am when I finished, and it was much later than that when I actually fell asleep. I got up at Noon. Hopefully, I'll get back to "normal" again tonight (bed at Midnight, wake up at 9am). Besides reading, I've been going through my cards pulling them for a small side deal and pulling some to sell on eBay. It took a lot of time, and I'm not sure it's even worth it for what I might get for them. urlLink Monday Mission 1. Have you ever had your work (online or off) used without your permission? What was used and how did you resolve it? Not really, no. One of the guys I play in a band with played me a song he wrote that had a section that sounded a lot like an old song of my own that he'd heard long ago, but that's common with music. You can take someone else's idea and change it enough to make it something new. 2. Have you ever copied somebody else's work into your own without requesting permission? Did you feel OK about that? How did things turn out? Like I was saying above, sometimes I'll come up with a new riff or something that might sound familiar and if I figure out what it is, I'll either change it enough to make it my own or I'll abandon it altogether. Plagiarism is not good. 3. Are there any similarities or differences (in general) to someone using my work without permission or compensation and downloading and sharing music without doing the same? Can you justify one and not the other? I think they're very different. Passing off your work as my own is blatant plagiarism, it is definitely theft, but with downloading music, what's being stolen? If I download a song, I'll listen to it, just like I can do on the radio, sampling it, just like I can do at many CD shops. If I like It, I'll buy it, so where's the theft? You might say downloading is different because I can possess the track in my home and can make copies, but am I stealing the song if I go to the library, borrow the CD and play it on my PC (where I can easily burn a copy)? I didn't buy anything, the artist isn't making a cent on my checking it out, so is that stealing too? To me, it isn't stealing until you burn it to disc, which is a way to own the complete product without having to pay for it. The only reason it's even an issue is because the RIAA is a corrupt, greedy organization that doesn't want to adapt to the changing technology. 4. Do you have "Daylight Savings Time" where you live? Do you like it? Does your body adjust well to it? Yes, we have it. I hate losing an hour, I love gaining an hour. I'm a mess anyway, so it doesn't affect me much. 5. Do you shave? When did you start? Do you use a blade or an electric? What do you shave (face, chin, legs, ears, etc)? Do you shave in the shower/bath or at the sink? I hate shaving! I shave only when I have to (my face). I think I started around 16-17? No idea. Don't really care. I don't think I've ever shaved more than 3 times a week, ever. When I do, I shave at the sink. 6. What do you think about the religious groups that get so upset when everyone celebrates Halloween? I could care less about what any religious group has to say. Religions are archaic and outdated, totally uneccessary in this day and age. 7. Are you dressing up for Halloween? If so, as what? And If you do, email me a photo and I will create a Gallery with everyone who sends one. Nah, I'm way too old for that. Though, I did trick-or-treat one house last year just to amuse my nephews. BONUS:How can I explain when there are few words I can choose? Learn more words.
