I was hoping to find a good job, full-time with benefits, but the way things are going, I may have to take what I can get, while I can get it. Mom said Arby's is hiring. Goddamn it. You know, some folks say "Generation X" is an overgeneralization, an oversimplification, but it seems pretty clear-cut to me. My generation has been sytematically screwed and I, for one, am feeling it and have felt it all my grown life. And let me tell you: it's not a pleasant screw, but a massive anal rape. Thank you, Baby Boomers. Thank you, Reganomics. Together you helped to produce a generation of educated, but poorly employed fast-food workers and slackers. It would have been nice if you'd had the same dream your parents had, and their parents before them, and their parents before them, and on and on and on: to make sure your children had a better life than you did. But that wasn't your dream, was it? Your dream was to have your cake and eat it too. You got it all and you kept it all, making sure very little "trickled down" to the next generation, my generation. Thanks for that. Thank you and fuck you.

A Fun Saturday I was out of bed at 10am this morning after lying in bed for half an hour listening to Pink Floyd, and then the Rolling Stones, play on my radio/alarm clock. I got up, finished last night's pizza, got my mailing ready, got dressed and headed out to the flea market with Mom. While I was there, I picked up four paperback books (Stephen King's "Carrie" & "The Green Mile", Bram Stoker's original "Dracula", and Thomas Harris' "Red Dragon", the first of the Hannibal Lechter books). I also bought two cassette tapes, Stone Temple Pilots "Purple" & Pink Floyd "A Momentary Lapse Of Reason". Everything I got was $0.50 each... sweet! After that, we ran some errands (Post Office, Home Depot) and decided to head up to my sister's house. We stopped at a few yard sales along the way (one of the benefits of being up early). I bought Jesse a Hardy Boys book for $0.10 at one of them, and at the last one we hit, Mom bought herself a computer. It's an e-Machine, the kind with a separate tower (CD-Rom, floppy) and monitor, Windows 98 software, and has 2 hard drives. It was in really nice shape and the guy even had the original boxes, paperwork, and software for it. He also threw in an Epson printer, a power strip, and a mouse pad. The total price for everything: $125. The guy had it hooked up in his garage for the yard sale and it looked like it worked just fine. I think she got a really good deal. After I got to my sister's house, my Mom and niece ran out to Philly's and brought us all steak subs for lunch. They were pretty good, but the gravy fries I ordered (to share with everyone) weren't very good (the gravy was fine, but the fries were awful). My sister wasn't feeling well, she was in bed most of the day, so I kept the boys occupied while my Mom helped my niece, Dana, with her school project. Besides my two nephews, Austin and Jesse, I also had Jesse's friend, Zack. We played catch with the football for awhile, which turned into keep away, which turned into ball tag (like regular tag, except you use the ball to tag the person "it"). Jess and Zack went off together and my other nephew, Austin, and I played catch for awhile. We were getting bored of throwing the ball around, so I started acting goofy, throwing the ball like a girl and blowing him kisses. And thus, "Gay Football" was born. When Jess and Zack came back we were all playing Gay Football. I'd throw the ball with one hand and have the other one hanging limp while the boys would skip down the street to catch the ball (yes, I said "skip"). Austin would throw me the ball and blink his eyelashes at me, and when someone would make a good throw or catch, we'd say it was "fabulous". I kid you not! Gay Football eventually morphed into Retard Football and Jess and Zack had me laughing my ass off. They both wear baggy shorts and they pulled them up to their chests. looking like total nerds. Zack started walking like Jerry Lewis and Jess pulled his shirt over his head, along the the shorts up to his chest, and started doing Cornholio. It was hilarious. Austin was trying to think of something funny too, but being a 5 year old (six next week), all he came up with was to pull his shorts down to his ankles, standing in the middle of the road in his underwear. I don't know about that kid... Jess and Zack split again and Austin and I played ball tag a little. It was hot outside so I turned the hose on and soaked him. I hosed my head and chest too. Man, the cool water felt good. I would have loved to have been able to jump in a swimming pool right then, but they don't have one. The boys came back and we played catch for awhile more before they all had to go in and get ready to go out (the boys went out bowling tonight). After they left, I wound up spending the next several hours working on my niece's computer and watching "Jackass" with my Mom and sister while I was downloading various good stuff for her PC. She has dial-up, so it took a long, long time to do what I wanted done. Firstly, I deleted a bunch of Gator and other garbage from her system before I was able to find a workable version of Ad-Aware to clear the rest off. I downloaded that and I downloaded almost every update Windows Update had. I also upgraded her Kazaalite to the ++ version and installed a Lava Lamp screensaver for her. I did a few other things as well, there's more I probably could have done, but by the time I finished all of that, it was about 11:30pm and Mom was well ready to go home. I'll tell ya, I'm a bit disappointed; all of that work and I didn't even get a "thank you" for it. Kids these days... Before Mom and I got home, we stopped off at McDonalds and I bought a McRib and some Chicken McNuggets. I got so wrapped up with the computer, I never had dinner. I'm not hungry anymore, but I am flat-broke again. I guess I'd better get to bed. Even with the extra hour tonight, it's way past my bedtime.

Humankind At It's Finest Folks, this is special: What's in a name? Everything when it's Butt LONDON (Reuters) - A couple have been forced to move house because of the shame caused by the name of their street -- Butt Hole Road . Paul and Lisa Allott sold their 150,000 pound bungalow in Conisbrough, northern England after living there for just 15 months, fed up with the constant leg-pulling. Taxis and pizza delivery men would fail to turn up, thinking their order was just a prank, and they grew tired with groups of youths posing for photos by the nearby street sign with their buttocks bared. "I like a laugh, but it was beyond a joke," Allott told the Sun newspaper on Friday. Attempts by Reuters to contact the new residents were unsuccessful -- they have taken a confidential ex-directory telephone number. "Butt Hole Road"! Haaaaahaaaahaaaaa!! I absolutely love ridiculously stupid stuff like that! And yes, I would move there if I could.

urlLink 3 for Thursday 1. What are your 3 favorite scary/thriller movies? (You know like that great classic thriller Psycho) For me, the top three are probably "Psycho" (the Hitchcock original), "The Shining" (the Nicholson one), and "Silence Of The Lambs". I've always loved "Dawn Of The Dead" and have enjoyed all of the "Alien" movies too. 2. What are the 3 stupidest scary movies you've ever seen? (So bad they're funny) I tend to stay away from overtly dumb movies, but when I was a teenager, my sister and I used to go over to my Dad's and watch movies with him and his wife. Usually we just watched movies my Dad taped on the VCR, but one time my stepmother rented a movie for us to watch, "Basket Case", and it was so stupid that we had to shut if off about 20 minutes into it. I saw a movie called "The Stuff", which was pretty bad. I thought "The Blob" was a pretty dumb idea for a movie too. 3. Who are (in your opinion) the 3 best thriller actors/actresses? I don't think I can answer this one. There are just too many actors who've done "thrillers", but aren't known as "thriller actors". For instance, Jack Nicholson kicked ass in "The Shining", but I wouldn't call him a "thriller actor". To me, the term "thriller actors" refer to folks like Lon Chaney, Bela Lugosi, Boris Karloff, Vincent Price, and Robert Englund; folks who made their careers from those types of movies. Bonus: Has a scary movie ever given you nightmares? If so, which movie was it? I don't remember any having done that to me, but my sister used to have nightmares about the kid scratching at the window in "Salem's Lot" and I used to tease her about it.

Band Practice/Meeting Another very loose practice, but we did go over a lot of the songs we needed to work on and we discussed some things after practice, which is good. JP recorded us again, but he just let it run for the most part. We worked on a lot of originals and covers, making adjustments here and there, trying things out, or just refreshing our memories. There are some songs we go a month or more without playing at all. We also goofed off a lot between songs, mostly me and Al, and we jammed on a lot of songs that are not part of our setlists ("Should I Stay Or Should I Go", "Crosstown Traffic", "Red House", "Eighteen"), which is my fault. I love throwing things out there to see how they play. After practice, we talked a bit about the band, what we're doing, where we're going, what we need to work on, etc... It's always good to discuss that kind of stuff, to make sure we're all on the same page. Al and I want to practice twice a week. JP and Jimmy just can't do it, so we're going to start having four-hour practices rather than three, to make the most of the one day a week that we get to practice. We are all in agreement that we need to cut down to two setlists and get them nailed before we start working on set three and four. I told the guys that we all need to practice at home as well. I'm guilty of slacking in that area myself, but Jimmy, the drummer, isn't able to do it at all. He's been talking about buying a practice kit for home, but he hasn't gotten one yet. His drumming is still a problem. I don't know what happened to him in the time since he left the band and returned, but he's not playing at the same level at all. When I used to watch the band play, back before I joined them, he used to be the strongest part of the band, just a monster on the drums, but right now, he's the weakest link. The other guys have said pretty much the same thing. Hopefully he'll listen to the CDs that JP is making of our practices and hear it himself, and hopefully, he'll get the practice kit so he can play at home and get back up to his previous level of play. Jimmy talked to one of the clubs they used to play at, about getting us in there, but they have new owners/management and they don't seem interested in paying us what the band made last time they played there. I guess he or JP will negotiate something with them. They're really jonesing to play out, especially JP. The money thing doesn't really matter too much to me. I'd play just to play, pay or not. The other guys have said that they won't play for free though, unless the free gigs lead up to a better-paying gig. I can see how playing for free could be bad when it comes to negotiating for paying gigs though ("Well you played there for nothing, why should I have to pay you to play here?"). I think I'll just go along with whatever they decide when it comes to money. We're practing again next Monday, same room.

The Anal Musician Reigns Supreme JP and Jimmy were running late tonight and JP called up Circle and pushed our band practice to 7:30pm instead of 7pm. Unfortunately, he never told me or Al. We ran through a lot of songs, covers and originals, tightening up the loose ends, and making changes here and there. Al took notes on what needs to be worked on with each song. We did some jamming tonight too, much more than usual. We played bits and pieces of "American Woman", "Purple Haze" (with JP on drums), "Killing Floor" (with Al and me on guitar), "Centerfold" (J.Geils Band), "Don't Bring Me Down" (the ELO song... Al sang it), and "Rock N Me", the old Steve Miller song. Everyone seemed to enjoy playing "Rock N Me" a lot and it looks like we'll be adding that to our enormous stockpile of songs. Some of the songs we did tonight, we haven't played in a long while: "Cold Shot" (we played this only once before... I need to work on the solo), "Rock This Town" (I got lost at first, we hadn't played it for well over a month), and "Before You Accuse Me", which I loathe playing (too many pointless solos in it). We also tried-out Ben Harper's "Steal My Kisses" again, but Jimmy still hasn't progressed with the drumming on that. Oh, and we tried doing "Wild Night" my way, the right way, and, strangely enough, it worked out just fine . Duh! It's a classic song, so when you play it the way it was written and recorded, it should sound just fine! JP seemed very pleased with it, even more so than I'd expected. I'm just happy to be doing Van Morrison some justice. We played too long tonight, going 10 minutes into the following band's time. I felt pretty bad about that. We have the same room next Wednesday, 7-10pm. Sweet!

The Anal Musician No, that doesn't refer to anything rectal. It refers to me (well ok, maybe it does refer to something rectal after all) and my tendency to try and do things "the right way" with my band. JP, my bandmate is really getting frustrated with me correcting things when I find "errors" with them. I talked to him last night and we argued about one of the songs we're covering, Van Morrison's "Wild Night". He thinks the way we play it is just fine, good enough, but we're cutting the chorus in half and we haven't been doing the bridge part where Van Morrison stretches out the word "wild" with the sax mimicking the vocal part. We've also made the solo section twice as long as it should be. We started playing that song when we first jammed with Santana and Ronnie, we kind of threw it together on the spur of the moment and have been playing that way ever since. I'm going to try to get them to do it the right way tonight. JP said he thinks the reason the band isn't making progress faster is because we keep changing things and the guys have to constantly re-learn the songs, which I find ridiculous. I've only made slight alterations to four or five songs: I put the F#m chord back in "You May be Right". They weren't playing it at all. I corrected the bridge on "Old Apartment". They were playing it exactly like the other mellow part of the song. I corrected the solo section on Queen's "Crazy Little Thing Called Love". They were playing it like the bridge section, which doesn't match with the leads at all. I changed the arrangement on one of JP's songs, "Promise You The Moon", and added a post solo section to which JP added to. And now, I'm correcting "Wild Night". If those few, minor, changes are enough to throw off the band, then we aren't very good musicians to begin with. Besides, I know why we're not progressing quicker, and I told JP as much: we don't practice enough; separately, or together as a band. Jimmy, the drummer, doesn't play at home at all. He plays once a week with us and that's it. If changes don't sink in completely that one day that he plays, he forgets them by the next week. I don't know about Al or JP, but I've been guilty of slacking off on practicing at home too and that's why we're not progressing quickly. That's the main cause, but there are other factors that contribute to our slow developement: the quantity of material we're working on and the fact that the setlists aren't "set" lists (as in "set in stone"). Right now, we have three main setlists, which include about 35 songs. That wouldn't be too bad if the same songs appeared on the setlists week to week, but we add songs here, delete songs there, we have a different set list as a quartet than we did as a sextet, we went through a period where we were working heavily on covers, but then we started focusing more on JP's songs, and now we're half and half... ugh! We probably should have started with just one list at a time, nailed it, and then moved on to the next one and then continued like that. But we didn't. We have three setlists set before us, with three more setlists on the backburner, and we're expected to know everything all at once. Learning them isn't so hard, remembering them and making them sound good everytime you play them is. Repetition will help with that, but as I said, we aren't playing enough to do that, and since there's so much to learn and refine, we're spreading ourselves very thin. Anyway, to make matters worse, I was practicing this afternoon (I played about 4 hours this week) and I found that the guys were playing another song wrong, "The Difference" by the Wallflowers. They play the wrong rhythm during the first part of the verse. They essentially play the main riff throughout the song insted of breaking it up a bit. Everytime I've played it with them, playing it the way they showed me, I thought "it just doesn't sound right playing the riff here, when he starts singing and all", and sure enough, it wasn't the right way. It may be a tense practice tonight.

PC Shenanigans I went to get online this afternoon, but lo and behold, I couldn't get online again. Dammit. After all that work I did getting things straight again... grrrr!!!! I played around with it for about two hours before I finally said "screw it" and wiped my whole hard drive. I spent pretty much the whole night erasing my hard drive, formatting it, and re-loading everything. I managed to do almost all of it myself too. I followed a list that I wrote down the last time I had to do this, but I forgot to write down a couple things at the end and wound up having to make a call to Gateway technical support. While I was on the phone with a Gateway tech I brought up the problem with my motherboard again and raised a little hell over it. See, back in April, one of their tech people had me take my PC apart and I located a blown capacitor on the motherboard, she said she'd be sending out a replacement and would have someone come out and install it for me... all free of charge. Well I waited two weeks, three weeks, still no board, so I called Gateway and asked where the motherboard was. They told that the order had been cancelled. Nice of them to let me know about it... not. I talked to several people after that, trying to go up the chain, and they told me that the blown capacitor wasn't enough of a problem to merit replacing it, which really pissed me off. My warranty covers all parts and labor, there was no reason to let a problem stand just because it wasn't a huge problem, but they disagreed and I hung up angry and bitter. "Fuck Gateway", I said, I'll buy a Dell in a few months and be done with them." Unfortunately, I didn't get a job as soon as I'd hoped and now it looks like I'll keep using my Gateway for at least six more months. So tonight, I asked the tech person I was talking to if I could speak to a supervisor. I decided to get this situation fixed to my satisfaction once and for all. I'd discovered that my warranty ran out last month, but I made the initial complaints about the motherboard while my warranty was still good, so they should'nt be able to blow me off because of the warranty. I was prepared to argue my case. I was put in contact with a senior tech person who not only understood my problem, but was sympathetic to my plight. He took care of everything himself, ordered me a new motherboard, and gave me his phone number so he can help me install it once I get the new motherboard in (3-5 days). Wow! Now that's service! I'm glad that this is finally getting resolved, but I'm still a little sore with Gateway because they should have taken care of my problem the first time around. While I was on the phone with them, I wound up adding a few purchases to my Gateway credit card: Windows XP software (full) and the 2004 Norton internet tools. After the new software and motherboard are installed, this sucker should run like a dream. It'd damn well better.

urlLink 3 for Thursday 1. What are your 3 worst fears/phobias? Being out on open water makes me nervous, especially at night, but I don't think I'm afraid or phobic enough to prevent me from going out on open water, even at night. Same thing with heights; I may get nervous peering over the edge of a tall building, but I still went up there and peered over the edge. It bothers me when people stare at me, I'm very self-concious, but again, I still get up on a stage, in front of people, to play with my band. 2. What are 3 fears/phobias that you've overcome? Well it's like I just said above, I may have fears or phobias, but they're not so bad that they can't be overcome. I think all fears can be overcome or at least, dealt with. 3. What are 3 fears/phobias of others that you think are plain silly? My niece is the Queen of Silly Phobias. She went through a long period when she'd wake up every night afraid that a giant meteor was going to hit the Earth. Then I think it was rain or lightning that freaked her out. I remember we were playing frisbee out in the street one night last year and there was some lightning in the sky, far away from us, but as soon as she saw the first flash, she went running into the house. Then she moved on to fearing tornadoes. OK, so tornadoes are not uncommon here in Florida, but she has actually grabbed her two brothers, took them and hid in the bathroom during a recent summer thunderstorm. She had the boys upset and crying over nothing but her own fear. She's like Chicken Little. Bonus: Have you ever had a really bad experience with one of your phobias/fears one that youll never forget and possibly has scared you for life? I've had two experiences with the same thing that has made me wonder about myself. One time, when I was a kid on vacation up in Pennsylvania, I rode a bike straight into a brick wall. I was traveling really fast down a hill and I just froze, didn't turn, didn't jump off, nothing. Whammo! Then, several years later, I did almost the same thing again. I was riding my bike, pedaling as fast as I could and I ran right into a cement street light. I flipped over the handlebars and flew through the air before landing on my back. Again, I froze up. It's made me worry about how well I handle speed. I don't think I'd ever trust myself on a motorcycle.

On Stage We got together at Circle for band rehearsal tonight, but this time we played in a different room, the "Stage Room", so-called because of the 2-foot high wooden stage that takes up most of the room. It sounded much better than the room we've been playing in, and we seem to have had more energy and better vibes in the different room tonight. We booked the "Stage Room" again for next Thursday. I thought we were going to be going through our set lists tonight, but JP had other plans. He made arrangements with his wife (Doris) and a friend of hers (Emily) to come and record us on his digital 4-track. His idea was to make a demo to give out to club owners/bookers so they'll have an idea what we sound like before they book us. First of all, it would have been nice if he'd given me some warning. If I had known we'd be recording demos tonight, I certainly would have practiced at home beforehand. No one else seemed to know we would be recording tonight either, and none of us, including JP, were prepared for it. It was all terribly unplanned, un-thought out. He didn't even have a list of what songs we'd be recording. Secondly, if he'd have discussed this with us beforehand, we could have made a better demo for about the same cost as practice tonight. Circle has a studio right there. We could've decided which songs to record and then we could have practiced them tonight and recorded them next week. He's too gung-ho on playing out. He wants to play out immediately , the sooner the better, but we really aren't ready yet. I think a lot of it is pressure from his wife. She thinks that rehearsal is pretty much goofing off, hanging with the guys, but playing out is actually doing something . We wound up wasting a lot of time tonight. It took them awhile to get the 4-track ready and get the levels set, but that worked out well for me because it gave me a chance to play some of my own songs with Al and Jimmy. We jammed on three or four of my songs, which is unheard of. I'm lucky if I get to jam on just one of my originals during a band rehearsal. We also wasted a lot of time because we had to do some of the songs over and over again. We were all making mistakes, and JP was having equipment troubles too. I wasn't real happy with my solos for some of the songs either. For instance, Ronnie always did the sax solo on "Wild Night" and we really haven't played the song since we played it with him and Santana, Labor Day weekend, so I had to improvise the solo and I know I didn't get it quite right. It's hard to say whether it was a productive night or not; I guess that'll depend on how well the recordings came out, and if we've got enough usable material for a demo. It's good that we played the songs we did, but with all of the mistakes we were making, it also showed me that we just aren't playing enough. Myself, I'm going to have to get back into the habit of practicing at home everyday. I know Jimmy's talking about buying an electric drum kit so he can play at home finally. If we could play twice a week, we'd get stronger, tighter, and better a lot quicker, but I'm the only guy in the band that can do it. *Sigh*

After they got bored with that, I took them outside to throw the Frisbee, but the wind was too strong, so instead, we had a pop rock fight and I lit off a pack of jumping jacks. It was getting pretty cold out, so we came in and I had them color in some shapes I'd drawn for them. They seemed to enjoy that a lot. After the coloring, we took turns drawing goofy pictures. I think it was shortly after that when Austin went to bed. Jess and I stayed up late watching "Alien Resurrection" on AMC (edited). We didn't get to bed until about 2:30am. I had a hell of a time sleeping, in fact, I hardly did. I had the heat on in the house and I was too hot and uncomfortable in bed. I was out of bed around 11:00am and I don't think I got more than a couple hours sleep, if that. Mom had just made waffles for the boys, so I had waffles for breakfast... good stuff. After breakfast, I took the boys outside for awhile. We blew up anthills, and then grapefruits, with firecrackers, then we shot my BB gun at a cardboard box I'd set up out by the fence. After a while, we started shooting grapefruits too. I had to go in and do some eBay stuff and packaged cards to be mailed, while the boys watched "Jimmy Neutron". Mom ran out to the post office for me while Jess and I ate lunch, then we went outside again and played football for a long time. We tried Frisbee again after we were done playing football, and I picked up another boy, some young kid named Sean (sp?) from down on the corner. They all threw the Frisbee together, but they weren't throwing so well (kept hitting the house) so I ran inside and grabbed the paper airplanes Jess and I made the last time he was down (I saved them) and the boys threw them around for a while. We tried playing football again, but Sean had no clue how to play, so we played Capture The Flag instead. Mom made hot chocolate for everyone between football and Capture The Flag, which was cool of her to do. After Capture The Flag, Jess went in to watch football and I stayed outside with Austin and Sean and played catch with plastic Hai-Alai scoops and a ball. Eventually, Sean went home and Austin and I played with the scoop/ball thing. Jess kept running in and out of the house and I'd let him play until he split again. Finally, the boys and I went inside for the night. I put on the music stations on the cable box and we laughed and joked about the Opera one a lot and the boys did goofy dances. We had dinner, and then we went into my room and I went through my the stuff in my black hassock, looking through old family photos, old drawings the kids did, and I showed them my dad's painted soldiers. We looked through the Christmas catalog after that, and then we went out and watched TV the rest of the night. I dug out an old video I'd taped for Austin long agao that he'd never seen, "MicroCosmos", a documentary about insects and various life in a French field. They loved it. I tried another nature video after that, but they were getting goofy (Austin was tired) so I put on Animal's Funniest Videos. Austin kept closing his eyes, starting to sleep, but refusing to go to bed, so I finally had to make him go to bed. He wasn't happy about that at all. Jess and I stayed up and watched "Naked Gun" and laughed our butts off. He just went to bed abouit an hour ago and I'm heading there soon. I think I have a cold.

A Return To Lameness I was doing so well here lately, going to bed at a decent time and sleeping throughout the night, but these last two nights have sucked hard. I don't know if I even got an hour of solid sleep last night. I went to bed too late, 1:30am. I stayed up late watching "The Blue Collar Comedy Tour" with Jeff Foxworthy, Bill Engvall, Ron White and Larry The Cable Guy (absolutely hilarious) and then half of "Saturday Night Live" with Matthew McConaughey, which I'd never seen. After I went to bed, I just couldn't get comfortable enough to fall asleep. It didn't help that I never ate any dinner last night either; it's not easy to go to sleep hungry. Anyhow, I finally had enough of the tossing and turning and uncomfortableness, and so around 9am, I just up and got out of bed. Not a great way to start the day. I talked to Jesse this morning, he's coming down with my Mom tonight and spending the weekend with us. I have no idea what I'm going to do with him; both Mom and I are flat broke. Mom said the weather is supposed to be pretty shitty tomorrow too. Not good. Mom said she didn't know when they'd get here tonight, or whether they'd bring supper home with them, so I have no idea whether I am supposed to make my own dinner or eat with them and I won't know until they get here. Nice. I've been struggling with my stupid computer all freaking day . I am so sick of this thing. The problem is, I don't really know if it's the computer at all. It may well be that the problem is the cable modem. I have two big problems right now, or I did anyway. For the last week or two, everytime I would start up the computer I'd get The Blue Screen Of Death. I'd have to re-start it a couple of times before it would finally start up normally. Then, the second problem would start: internet connectivity. When I click on the explorer icon to get online, it usually doesn't work until I re-start the computer a couple more times. It says "Detecting Proxing" or "Trying to find.." then I get the "Can Not Be Found" page, which means "no internet for you!" I solved the first problem by doing a sytem restore, but I created another problem with Norton when I did that. I could only start-up in Safe Mode or else I'd get a NAV alert and wouldn't be allowed to procede. I finally had to un-do my sytem restore, uninstall Norton, and do a nother system restore. I re-loaded Norton again (with my new updated version) and now I can start up with no problem. I still have trouble getting online though. I'm on now, but it took an hour to get here. I finally called my ISP and asked for help. They had me do the same things I've been doing, but this time, of course, it worked. Man, I hate when that happens! I don't know what this weekend is going to be like, but I hope it'll be better than these last two days.

Wednesday I slept in late today, til after 10pm, but I'd tossed and turned a lot during the night, so I guess I was making up for it. After eating lunch, I got my mailings packaged and then Mom and I went out on the road. We went to the bank and I made a tiny little deposit, then we went to the Post Office and I mailed my stuff out, then we went up and down Ulmerton Road and then 66th Street looking for places that were hiring. I had no luck. Every place that was hiring was hiring for jobs I have no experience doing. I haven't found a single job yet that I thought I could get. It's very discouraging. We stopped at two thrift stores while we were out and I bought a Pat Benatar tape at one of them for $0.25, but when I got home and tried to play it, it was crap. It sounded like shit (not the music on it, but the tape itself). I had band practice tonight and I sounded like crap again. I don't think being a day person is good for my guitar playing. I got tired early on. It seemed like I lacked my usual energy. It doesn't help that I haven't practiced all week either though. We sounded pretty rough again, a lot of being me. Part of the problem was with JP. His amp was too loud so I wasn't always hearing everything right and I was having to turn up a lot to meet him and turn down again when he switched to acoustic, so my sound was uneven; sometimes too loud, sometimes too low. We jammed a little tonight, did some B-A thing I made up (one part with a melody line, the other part with riffs) and we also jammed on another of my unfinished songs. Al sat and listened to me playing another of my songs while the others went out for a break and suggested that I record a handful of them on the 4-track and let him see if he can add anything to them. That's cool, because I was wondering if he'd want to do something like that since JP has his hands full with his own songs. Now I just have to go through all of my tapes and pull a handful of the better songs to work on. I've been meaning to do that for a long time anyway. After practice, we sat around bullshitting until 11pm. I had asked the guys earlier if they wanted to play an extra hour tonight, but like last time, they all said no, they couldn't (their wives would be pissed). But, for as long as we sat there talking, we could have gotten that extra hour in. JP was willing, but the otrher guys weren't. I guess I'm heading to bed in a few. I don't really want to go up to my brother-in-law's parents's house for Thanksgiving, but my Mom's pressuring me to go. Oh well. I guess I'll try to make the best of it. Happy Thanksgiving, everybody!

Random Monday-ness I went to bed late last night (around 1am) and was out of bed before 9am (no alarm again). I didn't get a whole lot done today. I ate half a pecan pie. First I made a large goatee (going past the chin down to the neck, which I liked), then with with a little "3 Musketeers" goatee (which I didn't like), then went with the David Crosby-style moustache (uhhh... no), then the basic police officer/science teacher mustache (lame), then on to the Hitler/Chaplin 'stache (really funny looking), before finally shaving everything off. I took a nap on the couch for about two hours (from 4:30pm-6:30pm) with Stevie sleeping on my legs. It rained while I slept. I watched the Iowa Democratic debates on TV tonight. I still think Dennis Kucinich is the best person running, but I just don't think he can get elected, which is too bad for all of us. I hope he stays in the race though, his voice should be heard. Carol Moseley Braun and Al Sharpton can't get elected either. They are both intelligent people, but they have no chance of winning and are in effect watering down the candidate pool. John Edwards reminds me of TV evangelist, or more accurately, a cross between a TV evangelist and John Davidson. He seems like a Clinton wannabe, a political slickboy. I wasn't impressed. Wesley Clark was my second choice, but he's losing credability with me. He said something tonight about it being ok that software companies outsource jobs to India. I don't find that ok at all. I don't like his stance on flag-burning (he wants to make it illegal). He's kind of flaky and not in a good way (like Kucinich). I do not like Howard Dean. No, sir, I don't like him. From his forced goofy smile to his pro-NRA stance on gun control, he rubs me the wrong way. John Kerry and Dick Gephart ganged up on Dean a lot. I thought Kerry was pretty impressive though. I may consider him as my second choice. Joe Leiberman, it turns out, was not invited to debate tonight, which is strange. I'm going to bed a bit earlier tonight. I want to get somthing done tomorrow besides eating pie and napping.

I even asked the other guys about playing an hour longer (no one else wanted too). I don't know what happened to me last night. It was like I suddenly got tired, mentally. I completely forgot the intro to "The Middle", and then I kept blowing "Wild Night", jumping into the solo section too soon... something I'd never done before. I love jamming more than anything else, JP seems to like it too, but I'm not sure about the other guys (they seem to get bored with it). Buying: Nothing this week, but I would like to pick up that Beatles CD while it's on sale. Selling: I have no auctions running and still don't know what I'm going to list this week. Very frustrating. I made a flyer for it and put it up on the board at Circle. I asked $200 for it or else a combo amp in trade. Eating: I'm eating too much breakfast food: eggs, kielbasa, hash browns, toast. I'm eating less bread and cheese, no soda, no pudding, a lot more rice, more pork and chicken, but no veggies or fruit... I'm going in the right direction, but I'm still not there yet. Feeling: Mentally: I'm feeling a little more hopeful about the future, but I still have a lot of money worries. Physically: I woke up a few minutes before my alarm went off this morning, with a terrible headache that hasn't gone away yet. I think my ears are causing the headaches, they hurt still. My sinuses are still a mess as well. I think I've torn something in one of my calves too. I get charlie horses frequently and I think something happened during the last one (a week or two ago) because it just doesn't feel right anymore. It feels strained. Planning: I plan on being employed soon.

My hotel room this past weekend was on the 8th floor. I rode the elevator a LOT. There is a lot of unspoken elevator etiquette, you know? Here are some of my observations (this is freestyle here - add to them or just tell me what you think) When to hold the door, when to let it shut. Do you put your hand in to re-open it if you are too late to get in? Do you hit the "open" button if you see someone running to the door? Do you press the numbers for everyone? urlLink 3 for Thursday (from last week) Getting in Trouble 1. What are 3 things you did growing up that you always got in trouble for, never learning your lesson? Being the class clown, or, as the teachers would call it, "disrupting class". I got laughs, so I always went back for more. I couldn't help it. In my circle of friends, the other kids usually would follow my lead and I was always finding fun stuff (also known as "trouble") for us to get into. To me, I was just being a kid and doing what kids do, but to parents, I was always being an "instigator". Staying up too late and missing the bus/school. During Middle School and High School I was very bad in this way. I used to stay up until 1:30am every weeknight watching "Late Night with David Letterman" (which was a must for me), even though I wasn't allowed to be up that late and was constantly being yelled at for it. Because I'd stayed up so late, I'd often sleep through my alarm, sleep through Mom yelling at me to get up (sometimes pouring water on me or beating me with a clothes hanger), and would then miss my bus and often miss school altogether, but I usually showed up around second or third period. I got in big trouble over truancy, but I just had to watch Letterman. It was a revelation to me, fresh and inventive, brilliant and silly, totally inspirational stuff to me. 2. What are 3 things you did growing up that you did learn your lesson and never did again? Shoplifting. Drinking to excess. Getting tattooed. 3. What are 3 things you did growing up that you never got caught or in trouble for? Wow. There's really too much there to list. I was a very naughty teenager. Drunken parties, more shoplifting, smoked weed, turn-out-the-light groping sessions... you name it, short of rape or murder, I probably did it. Bonus: Share a story of something funny or terrible you did growing up. I think I've told the "dog-crap-on-the-trailer story" enough, so let me think here... hmmm... well, believe it or not, but I have another dog crap story I can tell (you lucky reader you)! I must have been around 11 or 12 at the time, and I was across the street with my friend Eric (he was my "last resort" friend: ok if no one else was around) and we were throwing the football around in his yard. Behind his house lived Jenny, a friend of my sister's who I was always really mean to. I used to call her "Piglet" and torment her endlessly. I have no idea why I did that now. She's actually pretty cool, and was always pretty cute. I guess I didn't know anything about love and romance then, so I picked on her mercilessly instead. Anyway, Eric had a very large dog at the time and there were piles of dog shit all over the yard, so when I saw Jenny coming I rubbed the ball in a pile of shit and booted it toward her... a direct hit! She just stood there, mouth agape, completely shocked. So, being the wonderful kid I was, I grabbed a stick and dipped it in a pile of poo and chased her home with it. She ran home screaming and Eric and I laughed our asses off. The end. I suppose that probably wasn't a very good story to tell about myself, kind of makes me look like an asshole, but it does lead me into yet another dog crap story (a third one... imagine that)! Shortly after that incident, another friend of mine, Greg, came over and we told him about Jenny and the football and the poo-stick. Much like yourself, he didn't think it was very funny, so he made his own poo-stick and chased me and Eric into Eric's house with it. At some point, he actually chucked a dog turd at me and it hit me (i think it was fairly dry), which pissed me off so bad I ran after him; I was dead set on beating his ass. I chased him over to a neighbor's yard and he hid behind their pick-up truck and I went around that truck repeatedly trying to catch him. Finally I got so mad, so frustrated, that I picked up the truck ! I lifted it clean off the ground. I think he uttered "Holy shit!", and then he ran straight home. The end. I didn't think I'd actually lifted the truck up off the ground, but he swears to this day that I did. I guess that just shows how powerful Adrenaline can be. You know, that story really didn't do anything to make me look like less of an asshole. However, I did get hit with a dog turd and I didn't beat anyone's ass, Jenny is happily married, and I'm a miserable fat bastard. Score one for Karma.

Halloweeny Birthday Bash Mom and I headed up to my sister's place around 2:35pm. I had been totally engrossed in Nova's special about "The String Theory", a unifying theory of .. well, everything. I hope I can catch it again. We got up there around 4pm (we hit a lot of traffic on the way up). Austin, my youngest nephew, had gotten a mini-air hockey table for his birthday (today, he's six now) so I played that with him awhile before we (me, Austin, and Jesse) went outside and played catch with the football. We were having a good time until Austin thought it'd be funny to flip off his grandmother and point at his weiner with the birds. She was heading out to 7-11 and I told him he wasn't allowed to play football with us until he apologized to her. He pouted for a while and when she got back, he decided not to apologize, but rather pout some more about it. I had to tell his Mom and she eventually made him apologize, but, needless to say, it wasn't very heartfelt. He was still grumpy as hell when we started talking about Halloween costumes. He wasn't happy with being a football player anymore, not since his brother said he was going to be a vampire. I was teasing Jesse about going as a gay football player (a la last weekend) and his sister went nuts with the idea. Both boys wound up going trick-or-treating as girls.... the worst looking girls you've ever seen. Jesse had on his sister's thong underwear and had it pulled up high, sticking out the top of his pants and I drew a little heart on the skin that was showing. He had on a pink top (tied up to expose his belly), we drew a little butterfly below his navel, a stuffed bra, pink sweatpants, a pink bandana, and white and pink sneakers. Austin had on a dress at first (he later went with a purple top) and a pink visor, his sister's shoes and her underwear. Their sister applied a ton of make-up to both of them (eye-shadow, white face powder, rouge, lipstick, mascara), and I suggested beauty marks, which she added as well. They didn't really think things out very well though; they did all of this before dinner. Since it was my Mom's birthday yesterday, my sister made stuffed cornish hens, mashed potatoes, and broccoli in cheese sauce for dinner. It was very good. Austin didn't eat though. Too much candy beforehand. Dana, my niece, surprised everyone by dressing up at the last minute. She went as a dude, wearing sweatpants and a hooded sweatshirt with freckles and a mustache drawn on her face. Not to be outdone, I surprised everyone by going as a zombie. I threw white powder on my face and painted dark circle below my eyes and colored my eyelids black as well. I took a red marker and drew on a long scar on my forehead and drew blood coming out the corners of my mouth. I took a blue marker and colored my lips blue. Jesse found some ugly plastic teeth that completed my attire. When Austin saw me he started complaining that my "costume" was better, until I started chasing him in proper zombie fashion. That shut him up :) Dana's boyfriend, Ricky, went trick-or-treating with us as well. He wore no costume other than a black bra. Not very imaginative. I told Austin, jokingly, to tell them it's his birthday, maybe he'll get more candy. He did, and apparently it worked out well for him. He got out of hand with it after a while though. He started going up and saying "give me extra candy". No "trick-or-treat", no "hello", no nothing. Almost everyone who saw Jesse and his thong busted up. I had the most fun watching people's reactions to him. Austin got a few laughs out of people as well. After we got back, the boys threw their candy off to the side, Jesse took a bath, and Austin argued about taking a bath. I rested. My feet were sore from all of the walking. This is the part where I know I am going to sound like an old man talking about "kids these days". You know, back in my day, when we'd come home from trick-or-treating, we'd immediately get down to the business at hand: candy. My sister and I and several of our friends, we'd dump our candy on the floor, we'd each have our own pile, and we'd go through our piles to see what we got and then we'd begin making deals with the other kids, trading the stuff we didn't want for stuff we did. For me, the candy corn and the peanut-shaped orange-colored crap had to go, but the root beer barrels and chocolate bars were golden! But these kids today... I don't think they even opened their bags after they got home. They threw them to the side and went on to other stuff. Where's the joy in that? What will their fond memories consist of? "I remember when we'd come home on Halloween and throw our bags of candy off to the side... had to get back to Playstation, you know?" It's sad. After awhile, the boys went outside with their Dad and played with one of Austin's new birthday gifts, some remote-controlled thingy that flip flops and rolls around. After we finished playing with that, we went back inside and had some ice cream cake (Carvel... yum). Before Mom and I headed home, I had Dana and Jess locate Dana's guitar (the one my Mom bought her a year ago). Neither had any idea where it was. It took some hunting to finally track it down. One of the things we told her when Mom bought it for her was that, if she wasn't going to take care of it, we'd take it back. So I did. I got the tuner back as well, and I got most of my guitar stand back (this wasn't hers, it was lent to her). One piece is missing. The stand was stuffed in Jesse's closet, the guitar was under some clutter in Dana's room. I also took back a stack of books I'd lent her. She wasn't reading them, and she certainly wasn't taking care of them either, all strewn about on her floor. (kicking back into "old man" mode) Kids these days just don't have any respect or consideration. I always took care of my stuff, and I always took proper care with other people's belongings. If not out of respect, then because I didn't want to have to replace it if I broke it. These kids... they just don't give a shit. Their parents will pay for it... or maybe not. They could care less either way. Besides the guitar, I left with a TV set too. Some lady gave my brother-in-law a small color TV and he had no use for it, so he gave it to Mom and I. A while back, I gave her my small TV, so I'll probably hook this one up to my Nintendo (not that I really ever play video games). My sister gave us a bag of Reese Cups as well. She bought a ton of candy ($40 worth) and almost no one came to her door. I told her it'd have helped if they'd put a lightbulb in the light that lights up the walkway that leads to their door. It was just too dark. I'll bet people thought no one was home. Mom and I left around 10:30pm, got home about 11:30pm. Mom went to bed, I'm writing this. So that's my Halloween. I hope everybody had a good one (and you know who you are).

Books Read in 2003 I was hoping to add a couple more to this list before the year ended, but I've given up hope of doing that since I've been busy house cleaning all weekend. I still have more cleaning to do and I also have band practice on Tuesday, so I don't see any reading time anytime soon. So, without any further ado, here is the list of books I've read in 2003: 1) "Helter Skelter" by Vincent Bugliosi Very good, very interesting book. Recommended. 2) "My Point...And I Do Have One" by Ellen Degeneres Hilarious book! I laughed a lot while reading this one. Recommended. 3) "The Sheppard Murder Case" by Paul Holmes It's a well written and interesting book, but it's outdated and slanted too much in favor of Sam Sheppard's innocence. I did a lot of research after reading it and found that the book left out a lot. I think Sheppard did it. Not really recommended. 4) "The Stand" by Stephen King Very good book! It's a long one, but it held my attention throughout. I read the regular version, not the even longer unedited version. Recommended. 5) "Death Of A Salesman" by Arthur Miller It's a classic American play. Recommended. 6) "Once A Warrior King" by David Donovan Very interesting book. It's the Vietnam war through the eyes of an American "Advisor". Recommended. 7) "Proof" by Dick Francis It was like reading a TV murder-mystery. I didn't like the ending much, but otherwise, it was a fairly enjoyable read. Not really recommended. 8) "Frankenstein" by Mary Shelley Much different than I'd seen in the movies. Frankenstein's monster is more human here. Very good book. Recommended. 9) "The Amityville Horror" by Jay Anson I did a lot of reserach on the story while reading it and learned that the whole story has proven to be fraudulent (no surprise there). It's all one big con. The story is pretty creepy though, and if you can overlook the fact that the story is a crock, it might be worth reading. Still, not really recommended. 10) "Les Miserables" by Victor Hugo I have a tough time with this one. I saw the film before I read the book so I was expecting to read about the relationship between Jean Valjean and Fantine but there was nothing there. In the film, they had a relationship, in the book, they really didn't. To me, the relationship is a necessity because it explains why he did what he did for her (rescued and cared for her daughter). I don't know whether or not to recommend the book. It's a definite classic, it's a great story, and it's a very well written book, but if you've seen the movie, you may be left scratching your head like me. 11) "Lord Of The Flies" by William Golding This is another classic and deservedly so. My niece read it shortly after me and she hated it. Of course, she was expected to pick out and understand all of the underlying subtext whereas I just read it for the story. It's good story. Recommended. 12) "Miss America" by Howard Stern I read "Private Parts" a few years ago and I got a lot of laughs from it. I hardly laughed at all reading this one. It seems like nothing more than an ego-trip and a cash-in on the success of the previous book. Not recommended. 13) "Different Seasons" by Stephen King I loved this book! Great stories! How many books out there have inspired three different movies ("The Shawshank Redemption", "Apt Pupil", and "Stand By Me")? Definitely recommended. 14) "No Shirt, No Shoes... No Problem!" by Jeff Foxworthy I was expecting a lot more laughs from this one, instead I get more info than I need about his sexual adventures. Not recommended. 15) "Carrie" by Stephen King Good book, very well written. Recommended. 16) "Dracula" by Bram Stoker Like "Frankenstein", it wasn't exactly what I'd expected. It was pretty neat how it was written, as a series of diary entries from the primary characters. Dracula himself was different than expected too. Very good book. Recommended. 17) "Bury My Heart At Wounded Knee" by Dee Brown Very good, very moving book. It made me sad, but the stories are important and I think this should be a mandatory read in every high school. Recommended. I have a ton of books on deck for 2004 already, now I just have to set aside the time to read them all!

Christmas Re-Cap I'd gone to bed about 10pm on Christmas Eve, but I just could not sleep. By 5:30am I was wide awake in bed, not having slept for more than an hour or two, and I layed there until 6:30am when I finally got up. I got showered, got dressed and got everything that was going with us to my sister's house moved out to the car. Before we left, Mom gave me my present from her: 3 new DVDs ("Caddyshack", "The Life Of Brian", and "The Shining") and 2 outdoor fun kits (horseshoes and an assortment pack with badminton and other stuff). Cool! Around 7:30am, we were on the road. We got up there around 8:30am and no one was awake yet. I woke up my sister and brother-in-law and then moved the stuff we brought up from the car to the house (all by myself, as usual). After that, I went in and woke the kids up. All three were all sleeping in my niece's bed, so I went in there screaming at the top of my lungs "AAAAAHHH!!! WAKE UP!!! THERE ARE PRESENTS OUT THERE!!!"). Dana (my niece, 16) and Austin (my younger nephew, 6) popped up immediately, Jesse (my older nephew, 11) continued sleeping. It wasn't long before I had them all up and out of bed to open presents. Austin had a ton of presents to open, but the other two had very little. Dana had gotten a big present earlier, a Golden Retriever puppy she named Toby, and Jesse's main present was a surprise (to him, anyway). I was teasing him about how little he'd gotten ("Man, all you got was a shirt and some pants? That sucks, dude.") when his Dad brought out the motor scooter he'd wanted. His eyes nearly popped out. He was in total disbelief. Between the scooter and his video games, I didn't see much of Jesse the rest of the day, which sucked, because I was hoping he'd be coming back home with us (I needed someone to play horshoes and badminton with). He was kind of snubbing me anyway (his Uncle Doug took him and Austin to go play basketball and Jesse didn't even ask me along), so I guess it's a good thing he didn't come home with us after all. As I mentioned in a previous post, I gave each of the boys a 50 piece glow-in-the-dark Supermags magnet set. Austin played with it a bit, so did I , but Jesse pretty much ignored it. Dana's boyfriend, Ricky (who showed up shortly after the presents were opened), played with it more than anyone. Dana had a hell of a time opening the present I gave her, with the crazy wrap job (she had a semi-horrified look on her face when she first saw it). She got her hair stuck to it at one point, but she really liked the presents inside though (lotions and stuff) and couldn't believe that I'd actually gotten her "chick stuff". Mom made my niece very happy with her bags of snowman and reindeer poop (snowman poop = marshmellows, reindeer poop = chocolate chips) and original poetry to go with each one (Mom wrote a funny poem for each person). My sister and brother-in-law really didn't say much about the DVDs I got them, but my sister really liked the book I won her (that Mom paid for). I gave my brother-in-law a KISS ("Greatest KISS") CD to go with the DVD I bought him, so even though I got shorted money by certain eBay bidders, I ended up ok. I even added some extras, some stuff I had around the house. I gave my sister an Anne Rice paperback ("Interview With The Vampire"), my niece a Stephen King paperback ("Carrie"), my brother-in-law a video ("Vacation"), my older nephew a bunch of tapes (several Ratt, Scorpions, Dokken) and my younger nephew I gave a brand new whoopie cushion. My sister and brother-in-law gave me a new DVD player, but it's an off-brand I've never heard of, Entiveo, and I'm a little wary of it. I'm not really complaining, I'm happy to have gotten anything, but... if it were me, I wouldn't have given my loved ones electronics of lesser quality than I'd settle for myself. They have Zenith, Panasonic, and Sanyo stuff themselves. They gave my Mom a new 20-inch TV, an Apex, which is also an off brand. Mom surprised me with several more DVDs in my stocking: "Minority Report", "Terminator 3", and the whole first season of "Sanford And Son", plus a CD I've been wanting, the soundtrack to "A Mighty Wind". The DVDs were used, from pawn shops we hit. She made a trip back to Pawn Depot for the first two movies, but she said she bought the Sanford and Son DVD right under my nose (I never saw her do it). Unfortunately, because she did it that way, she didn't look it over before buying it and the discs are pretty thrashed. It's the thought that counts, but... she knows I am extremely picky, anal even, about my CDs and how much I hate scratchy and even finger-printed discs, so I don't know why she spent her money on something like that without checking it over first. She knows me better than that, or so I thought anyway. She did several things that boggled my mind this Christmas. For starters, what I wanted more than anything was two new Jimi Hendrix CDs that have to be ordered from the Experience Hendrix website or phoneline (they're not available in stores). Awhile back, I gave her the catalog and circled the two I wanted but she never bothered to order them. Then, after it was too late to order them in time for Christmas, since she said she still had stuff to buy for me, I gave her a list of DVDs I wanted and put 4 or 5 Hendrix DVDs at the top of the list, what I wanted most, and she bought none of them. As far as I can recall, this the first year since I was a teenager that I haven't gotten any Jimi Hendrix stuff for Christmas. It's a bit disappointing to me. It's the end of a tradition. Another tradition ended this year too, she had been buying me a can of Poppycock for Christmas for several years now and this year she didn't do that. I don't mean to sound ungrate-ful for what I did receive, but I really liked having certain traditional things remaining intact The other thing she did that puzzled me was buy me a Bass Guitar magazine. You know, whatever, it's not a big deal, but it makes me feel like she didn't care enough to even look at what it was she was buying me ("Eh, guitar in the title, that's good enough"). I mean, she knows I'm not a bass player, so what the hell? It's useless to me. I'd have preferred she just saved her money. Regardless, I'm thankful for what I did get for Christmas, I'm happy to have been able to buy what I did for everyone, and I am grateful for the time I got to spend with my family. My sister cooked up a killer breakfast for everyone (omlettes and hash browns) after the presents were all opened. She and I sat on the couch getting some of the kids electronic toys opened and running. One of the toys was a Pixter, which is really cool. I spent time with my niece in her room, playing with her puppy (he's a cutie). I layed in my sister's bed with my brother-in-law and nephews, watching my nephews play video games while listening to the KISS CD I bought. My younger nephew was singing along with KISS' "Do You Love Me". Later at night he was singing AC/DC's "T.N.T." ("Oy! Oy! Oy!"). I played outside for a long while with my younger nephew and brother-in-law, throwing the football around and later, my niece brought the puppy out and I watched him and Austin play together. They were funny. My sister cooked up a huge dinner (ham, stuffed chicken, macaroni and cheese, some awesome green beans (with bacon and onions), and squash. Mom supplied cheesecake for dessert, which me and my niece "fought" over. We were all stuffed. By the time dinner was over, I was really getting tired. The lack of sleep had caught up to me in a big way (my sister said my eyes were bloodshot). Before we left, me and my brother-in-law playfully annoyed my Mom (she hates the F-word) by cussing like sailors. After we got home, I unloaded the car, got on the PC for a few minutes, then went to bed, beat. Overall, it was a really good, enjoyable day.

First Gig Out Well, I tried to nap this afternoon, but I was thinking about the gig and the music too much. It didn't help that Stevie, my loveable-but-dumb gray cat, kept licking my head. JP came over a little early and we had turkey sandwiches and talked over some of the changes I made. He didn't like the idea of changing things on the very night of the gig, but after we got to practice at Circle and played the songs, with the changes I made, no one had any complaints. We sounded pretty bad at Circle. Part of it was nerves perhaps, but a lot of it was the room and the P.A. system there. Whatever it was, we weren't gelling and on one song, "Rock This Town", I completely blanked out, forgetting almost all of of the parts to it, everything. Luckily, that was just an alternate song that we weren't going to play unless we needed to stretch it out more. Little did I know... We played there for about two hours and then headed over to Gasoline Alley, where we were booked to play. We were supposed to start loading our equipment onstage around 10:30 so we could take the stage at 11pm, but they had some difficulties earlier in the night with a previous band's electronic drum kit and we were delayed about 45 minutes. When we finally got everything set up and ready to play, there were only about 6-8 people in front of us and maybe another 6-8 at the bar, not a big crowd, which was just fine with me. I was sweating profusely and my hands were sticky/sweaty, which is really bad for me because my fingers can't slide over the fretboard as smoothly, they stick. I should've put new strings on my guitar, that would've helped out a lot, and some fret polish would've been a plus as well. You live and learn We did a soundcheck before we started, to set the levels on the equipment; I thought we were all set to go, so I kicked off the show with "Love The Love You're With". It didn't sound too bad from where I was standing, though it wasn't my best performance ever (my fingers stuck on one part of the solo), but as soon as we finished, the sound guy had to have me turn my amp down because, apparently, I was way too loud . I just knew that was going to be a problem (Al's amp has to be loud to get decent feedback), but I thought, since it wasn't a problem at soundcheck, it wasn't a problem at all. Again, little did I know... The next couple of songs were fine, but the sound guy was adjusting and re-adjusting our sound and it was a bit distracting. I thought he turned me down too much and brought JP's acoustic way too high, and then he threw a bunch of reverb on JP's vocals on one song, but finally, about half way through the set, he got the sound down and we did fine. The sound guy said we, the band, progressively got better through the set. We had a lot of people at the bar rooting for us, and even had some folks dancing on the floor in front of us near the end. JP skipped over one song, "Calling All Angels", and then he did the unthinkable: he introduced "Rock This Town", the song I completely butchered at practice earlier that night. Somehow, don't ask me how, but I fucking nailed it. I think it was probably the best performance of that song that I'd ever given. Go figure! None of us really screwed up too badly tonight. My fingers stuck on one chord change and on the solo to "Love The One You're With", and I slightly flubbed the solo to "Wild Night" (barely noticeable), JP mangled his solo on "Promise You The Moon" (he covered ok though), also, his acoustic guitar disappeared during that song as well (the sound guy's flub). JP played one wrong chord, one time, on "Circle" and I did the exact same thing, one time, on "Sleeping Forever", and I think that's it. Al and Jimmy were great, I don't think they messed up at all. And man, Jimmy sounds so much better live, behind his own drum kit. Those kits at Circle do nothing for him at all. We played about an hour and then we hung around after the set, talking to the manager, trying to get a booking for January. It looks like we got two nights, and one of them sounds like it's going to be an absolute blast ! Not long after I first started playing guitar, I occasionally jammed with Jim Fagan, a really good drummer I met while working at Chilis (back in the mid-late '80's). He went on to join/form a very popular Grateful Dead cover band called "Uncle John's Band", and that is who we may be opeing for on one of those gigs! Stylistically, it'd be a great fit for us (tonight we followed a very heavy Heavy Metal band), plus they draw a large crowd, so we'll get more people, music lovers, listening to us. We'll probably throw in a blues number, maybe a jam, some Neil Young perhaps, and I'd really like to do a Hendrix song as well, to play a little more to their crowd. So anyhow, that's how tonight went. Not a bad night overall! And now, I have to go and take the trash out, then maybe grab a bite to eat, and then I'll likely chill out a little, until I can sleep. I'm wide awake.

Just Woke Up & Need A Nap I stayed up almost all day and night yesterday, finally hitting the sack near 1am. I slept pretty good last night, staying in bed until 11am. I got up, watched TV, ate lunch, set up my music gear in my room and practiced for an hour and a half with Al's amp. Now, just three hours after getting out of bed, I am very sleepy. Plus, I want a smooth tube sound, not too bright, which is a slight problem playing with a Fender Strat and a Fender amp. I just have to keep playing with the controls. I also changed the music slightly on one of the covers we're going to be playing tonight ("Love The One You're With"). I like it a lot more now. I just hope the guys can adapt to the change quickly. I'm going to go and throw some clothes in the washing machine and then I'm going to go take a nap.

urlLink Monday Mission 1. What in your life used to be fun, but eventually just became a chore that you didn't enjoy? Right now? Christmas. It'd probably more enjoyable if I had a job and steady income, but all of the money I have due in comes from eBay auctions and I am waiting on a lot of people to make good on their purchases so I'll have some Christmas cash, but it looks like some of them aren't going to pay up (at least not before Christmas), which really fucks up my Christmas plans. Ugh! And then there's my sister, who had money to buy a DVD player and some DVDs a couple of weeks ago, but is talking now about how they barely have any money for presents for the kids (which is her way of saying "you're not getting anything this year either"). It's just a huge fucking hassle. 2. This weekend, US Troops captured Saddam Hussein and now have him in custody. How did you feel when you heard the news? Did it change your mind about the War in Iraq? Did it change your opinion of President Bush? I thought it was great that he's been captured; now the Iraqis can put aside any fears of him re-gaining control after we leave there. I still think the war was unjustified and handled horribly by the Bush administration. As soon as I heard he'd been captured, I started worrying that Americans will celebrate his capture and forget that we were lied to about why we were going there, that Bush alienated us from former allies with his arrogant foreign policy, that his policy of pre-emption is wrong and illegal, and that our soldiers continue to die there almost every day. 3. What do you think, should US Troops have taken Saddam alive or just killed him when they found him? What would be the pros and cons of either? They should not have killed him immediately, no. That would be cold-blooded murder since he was unarmed and did not resist. Having him alive allows Iraqis to see him, and believe that he truly has been captured, and allowing them to try him will give them some closure to his bloody reign and a sense of freedom. It's also better for Bush's approval ratings to have him contained. I'm worried by that a bit. I mean, if we manage to find Bin Laden before the next election, I think Bush stands to be re-elected. People forget too easily. 4. What kind of things at Christmas time just scream "tacky" and "White Trash" when you seem them? The "Jesus Is The Reason For The Season" bumper stickers. 5. Suppose you had a dear friend who calls you in tears because her boyfriend had just left her. They'd been together for nearly 5 years, and one day he announces to her that he is leaving because she had gained too much weight. They were in love, or so she thought, and then out of the blue, he bails and blames it on her weight. What would you say to her about this man? If you love someone, you look past the other person's faults, you don't abandon the person because of them. It sounds like she's the only one that's really in love. 6. Suppose this same friend of yours still thinks she and her ex have a future. She says that she wants another chance, that if he will make some changes, she will to. She really does love him, and assures you that he loves her, even though he wants to "take a break and see other people, but if we were meant to be together we will be." There is even a hint of marriage in their future if they get back together. What advice would you give her? Pick up the pieces of your heart and move on. 7. Have you ever had to tell a lie to get out of a date or when you were breaking up with someone? What did you tell them and how did they take it? Did they ever find out the truth? I don't know that I ever lied to get out of a date (a boy/girl date, that is) and I've never broken up with anyone. BONUS: Where are you, Christmas? Right around the corner.

What is your ideal holiday celebration? How, where, with whom would you celebrate to make things perfect? It'd have to be back up home in Pennsylvania, preferably at my Grandfather's house, with my whole family gathered around, and a light snowfall outside. 3. Do you do have any holiday traditions? We go up to my sister's house usually. My own tradition was getting to wake the kids up, but last year, the boys were already up. 4. Do you do anything to help the needy? I donate clothes and stuff to Goodwill and the Vietnam Veterans of America, but that's about it. It's not that I wouldn't want to do more, but I haven't been financially stable for years, so when I get any extra money, it usually goes to bills and spending a little on me and my family. I haven't had a job since April and I'm not far away from being needy myself. 5. What one gift would you like for yourself? A job and/or an amplifier.

Band Practice I felt weird going into tonight's practice, almost dreading it. I don't really know why either. I think it's bad business, totally unfair and unethical. But whatever... It was a pretty good practice, we got a lot done and we didn't screw up too much. We ran through sets 3 and 1 and did some jamming in between and at the beginning of the practice. I started with my Blues in F, which I normally play slide on, but it kind of went nowhere since JP didn't try making up lyrics and sing on it. I threw out a new one I came up with as well, it's a rock song in E (E-D-w/riff E-G-A). I had the riff already, but I made up the chorus for it on the spot. JP came up with some lyrics and a melody for the Chorus which sounded pretty good. We need to work on this one some more, add one more section or something.
