Enough Already Man, I am sick of being forcefed advertising. I am sick of opening my private email to find spam emails, the same ones, each and every day, sent from a different account each time so that I can't block them. Idiots... if I don't bite the first or second time, why would you think I'd bit the 203rd time? Enough already! But just when you think that advertisers/marketers could be no more agressive or intrusive, I see this: Colossal ads block view of Rome's gems By Liz Sly There's a lovely 16th Century church at the top of the Spanish Steps--Rome's premier gathering spot for tourists--but if you're visiting Rome this summer you won't be able to see it. That's because it's been draped in a giant advertisement for L'Oreal beauty products, the latest in a series of controversial advertisements that obscure the ancient city's monuments. There's also a big bottle of shampoo covering up one end of the 15th Century Campo di Fiori, an outsized Vespa scooter zooming across a facade behind the Piazza Navona, and the Piazza di Spagna is dominated by a banner promoting coffee. Soon, Rome's beloved Pantheon, the former pagan temple that has survived through the ages in the heart of the city, will become the first Roman antiquity to be covered by ads. Cellular phone companies have expressed great interest in the prestigious advertising space, according to Interpromos, the agency that has signed a six-figure deal to promote the marketing merits of the 2,000-year-old domed structure. How sick is that? Is nothing sacred anymore? I read a while back that some "advertising geniuses" (read: "assholes") are actually trying to cover the moon with ads (with a laser light projector of some kind) and now, I think it'll only be a matter of time before that becomes a reality. Imagine looking up at the moon and seeing the Nike Swoosh smack dab in the middle of the moon... disgusting. It seems like people are getting so much more selfish and greedy than ever before... or maybe I'm just now realizing how greedy and selfish some folks are. I mean, who are these people to think they're entitled do what they want with the moon? Or with the Pantheon? Or with my private email, for that matter? Bastards...

Direction Unknown I went to bed late last night and then I started reading "The Hobbit" after I got into bed. After I finished Chapter 1, I tried to get to sleep. I had a lot of trouble sleeping and wound up in bed until 1pm this afternoon, way later than I would've liked. I watched TV a bit ("Celebrity Poker"), ate lunch, and played around on the PC all afternoon. I talked to Mom sometime around 3:30pm, when it looked like a storm was imminent, and she said she could leave a little early to take me in to my Arbys interview at 5:15pm. I got showered, got ready to go, and waited for her to get here. A few minutes after she got home, we left for Arbys. When I arrived, I asked the girl at the counter if I could see tghe manager, she left and said he wasn't there. I saw the manager I interviewed with on Friday, Don, out back when we pulled in so I asked to speak to him. She went back and said he wasn't there. She was no help whatsoever and couldn't of cared less. I went out back myself and asked Don when the other guy was due in. He said he was due in at any moment and that I should wait for him. Ten minutes later, still no manager. Don came out again and said he'd call the guy I was waiting on, he did that, came back, and said it'd be another 15-20 minutes. I said I'd wait. All the while I sat there I was thinking about how much I really didn't want to work there, trying to think up ways to get out of it. I realized that since I got my guitar money refunded, I was ok (moneywise) for another couple of weeks. I also realized that I'd only have another $400-something to pay on my bank loan and I could probably come up with that on my own, selling on eBay or at the flea market or whatever. Still, I waited patiently for the manager to arrive so I could be employed again. I noticed while I waited, that none of the employees smiled, not once in the whole time I worked there. It really didn't look like a happy, enjoyable place to work. I finally had enough waiting, got up and told the assistant manager at the counter that I had to go, to which she replied (in broken english) that the manager I was waiting for was gone for the day anyway. That was it for me. I was out of there, having decided I no longer wanted to work there. I felt a little bit of freedom and pride in having left there, but I also felt a lot of doubt and uncertainty about leaving as well. From there Mom took me to Costco where I tried to apply, but they only accept applications on Tuesday and Thursday, so no luck there. I looked over the want ads while we drove towards home. I saw a couple things nearby I'll need to check out. We wound up at Denny's, where we had dinner. I had their turkey sandwich, which is not something I'd ordinarily order. I kept second-guessing myself about the Arbys job all through dinner. It's a quick job, but I really think taking it would do me more harm than good in the long run. Still, I need money now . Like I said before, it's a real dilemma for me. When we got home, I looked at the phone messages and Arbys had not called. I'm thinking that either the manager never did come in or else he did and said "screw him" when told I left. I'm pretty sure it's the former, and I think I can still have the job if I want it. I just hope they don't contact me in a moment of weakness or I just might take the job after all. Pathetic, huh? After we got home and got settled in, we ordered another movie from Movies On Demand, "Welcome To Mooseport", which was a huge piece of shit. I didn't laugh even once during the entire movie! It was awful, horrendous! What were they thinking? I don't know who I hate more, the guy who wrote this steaming-pile-of-shit or Ray Romano for having betrayed comedy itself by taking the role. Ugh! Do yourself a favor and stay as far away from this movie as you can, unless you enjoy wasting your life on crap. I'll be heading to bed within the hour. I'm going to read some more, and hopefully, I'll get to sleep at a decent hour tonight. I need to start getting up early again so I can start looking for a good job.

She bought a 2004 Toyota Camry (gold/beige)! She came in and ate lunch and then we decided to head up to my sister's house. Very smooth car, plenty of room, ice-cold A/C, and best of all it plays CDs and cassettes! Sweet! I brought along a bunch of CDs to play, plus the tapes from last night's gig. After we got to my sister's, her and the two boys came out to see the car and then took a short ride with Mom and I. After we got back, we all decided to go up to my sister's in-law's house to do fireworks. Austin (my 6-year old nephew) rode up with Mom and I. We laughed and joked all the way up there, trying to out-gross-out each other. After we got up there, I took Austin out in the yard and showed him those mushrooms that you step on to make the "smoke" come out. He was entertained by that. I chastized my niece for not bothering to come see me last night. She knew I was counting on her, she told me she'd be there when I talked to her last week, but then she went and blew me off (which does not sit well with me at all). Nobody ever calls her on that shit when she does it, so I made a point to do just that. She was supposed to be getting her hair done, that was her excuse for not coming, and then it turns out she didn't do anything with her hair at all. I just hope she doesn't turn into one of those self-centered people who never considers other people's feelings. Anyway... it was hot and humid up there and I wound up outside playing with the boys, sweating my arse off. I played basketball with they boys and their dad (I mostly passed the ball) then we went in for chow (Publix chicken, mac & cheese, baked beans, and corn). After dinner, everyone went outside to do fireworks, but they only did a little bit because it wasn't dark yet. I showed the boys how to make whips out of this one long weed (I don't know the name of it) and they played with their whips awhile, weed-wacking tall weeds. Meanwhile, my sister went looking for skinks. She may be even nuttier I am. When she came down last night, the first thing she did was hunt through the planter out front looking for lizard eggs. She said tonight that she wished she had a place like her in-laws so she could hunt for lizards and skinks all the time ! I got a kick out of that. I went in after a bit to cool off and wound up playing some of the tape of last night's gig for Doug. He knows JP and said he couldn't imagine him singing, plus he's never heard me play guitar, so I played some of it for him. He liked it a lot. He said "I Had A Girl" reminded him of Led Zeppelin or Pink Floyd. We sat out there until it got dark enough to set off the rest of the fireworks. The sunset up there was beautiful, with pinks and blues jutting out from behind tall trees... really nice. Most of the fireworks were pretty boring, but the boys had fun doing them with their dad and grandpa, and Doug and I had fun teasing Dana (my niece) and joking with the two grandmas. After the firework show was over, we went in for a little bit to cool off, and soon after, we all decided to head home since it was getting late. Jesse (my older nephew) wanted to spend the night, but I didn't think it'd be a great idea since I have a job interview tomorrow and since it'd be harder for my mom to drive him home during the week. We told him he could come down next weekend, then my younger nephew said he wanted to come too. I don't know if I want both boys down next time, even though my sister is pushing for that. It's too limiting and I get worn out too fast. The drive home was both awesome and a pain-in-the ass. The pain-in-the-ass part was that Mom took a different route home and there were toll booths up the ass. I shelled out $3 for those stupid tolls. Bastards! The awesome part was the fireworks. It seemed like every direction I turned, there were fireworks going off in the sky. On one side of the road, I counted seven different fireworks shows going off. There were more on the other side of the road, as well as some straight ahead. It was awesome! Almost all the way home there were fireworks going off on every side, near and far. Awesome, just awesome. I had a really nice day today, I hope everyone else did too.

The Gig My sister came down, alone, for the show. My niece was too busy getting her hair done to come down. My sister, my Mom and I ate Chik-Fil-A "sammiches" for dinner and then we headed over to the club. The first band was just finishing up when I arrived, so I had to start loading up almost as soon as I got there. My guys had been there for awhile. We only had about 20 people there to see us this time out, although we managed to keep a good portion of the first band's people there until the end of our first set. My friend Rob was supposed to have been there tonight but he backed out again. This time he said his wife was ill, last time it was him that was ill. Here was our first set: "Opportunity Knocks", "Stuck In The Middle", "Promise You The Moon", "Love The One You're With", "The Authority Song", "You Can't Run", "Had A Girl", "Wild Night", "Safe In My Arms", "There For Me", "Steal My Kisses", "The Breakup Song", and "The House Is A-Rockin". Everything turned out pretty well, except a few notes here and there (no major disasters like last time). During the break I went and sat with my Mom, my sister, and a few friends from my Mom's work. I had Mom tape the show for me tonight. For me and for Al, who has a friend over in Iraq that wanted to hear what Al's band sounded like. I'll make a copy this week for Al to send to the guy. Here was our second set: "(What's So Funny 'Bout) Peace, Love & Understanding", "Sleeping Forever", "Badge", "Better", "Yesterday's Girl" (I didn't fare too well on this one, neither did JP on vocals), "Cold Shot", "I Got Loaded" (probably the best we've ever sounded this one), "Come On Let's Go", "Feelin' Alright", and "Fell In Love With A Girl". Other than "Yesterday's Girl" being a bit sloppy, we did pretty well on this set too, no major disasters yet again. We cut the second set short by three songs because the manager told us he needed us off by 11:15pm, rather than 11:30pm as we were told. That manager... The last time we played there he tried screwing us on the money but he eventually made good. Tonight, he split before we were offstage and then the owner wanted to make a new deal with us, less money for us, of course, disregarding our agreement with the manager who booked us. After some discussion, he finally made good too, but man, how uncool and unprofessional. JP had even given the manager a chance to negate our agreement last week, after he found out that we wouldn't have very many people there, but the guy said "no, that's alright". I don't think we're going to play there again. I know I said it before, but this time I think it's definite. I stayed late there with JP, until about 1:15am. I watched the band that followed us for a bit (Spot Lucy, good band) and drank a Heineken. I forgot that JP and his wife bought us each a shot during our first set (Lemon Drops?), and man, was it strong! JP also brought some cokes with rum in them for him and I, which I worked on during the first set. I was feelin' alright tonight. I'm listening to the tape of the show tonight and it sounds pretty good, quality-wise and performance-wise. Cool. I'll be heading to bed shortly. I guess I need to start becoming an early riser again. Costco is open tomorrow, so I think I'm going to go and apply there before I totally commit to Arbys. Truthfully, I'm not looking forward to working at Arbys at all .

Pre-Show Stuff I woke up around Noon again today, then Mom came in and told me Arbys had called. I got up, called them back and agreed to come in for an interview in 45 minutes. I showered, dressed, and headed over. I interviewed with the manager there and he said they needed a prep person Monday through Friday, full time. That's the good part. The bad part is that I'd have to be in at 8am everyday and I wouldn't even be making $6.50 per hour. No word on benefits or anything either. I have to go back on Monday for a 2nd interview (a lot of hassle for a low-pay job), but it looks like they'll hire me. I have mixed feelings about working there. I need the money, that's for sure, but I'm not sure I want to work for $6 an hour, especially after making $10 an hour at my last job. I also wouldn't be able to look for a better job if I'm working there 8am-5pm all week long. I'd be locked into the job. Plus, another fast food job on my resume won't help me any. However, the schedule works well with the hours I'd need for my band and I'd have my weekends off to do whatever I wanted. I could always do the flea market thing on weekends to earn extra money. I'm torn. From there we headed over to Sam Ash, so I could find out what my options were regarding my guitar layaway (that I haven't been able to pay on for over a month). To my surprise, they were extremely understanding and accomodating. They refunded me every penny I paid on the guitar, no hassles whatsoever. I was really impressed and will definitely return there when I have money again. I got over $388 back from them, so now I can pay Mom back what i owe her and should have a little left over to get me by until I start working. I wasn't happy to lose my guitar (it was a beauty), but at this point, I need the money more. After tonight, we won't be playing out again until September, so the 2nd guitar wasn't a necessity right now anyhow. After we left there, we went up to a Salvation Army store we hadn't been to for awhile. They had a "now hiring" sign on their door with a list of four positions they were hiring for so I asked for an application there. I was told they had none left. Nice. I bought a baseball and 2 tape storage cases (a 3-drawer case and a carry-case) there. It was $4 for everything. On the way home from there, Mom asked what I wanted to do for chow and I suggested Lone Star, again, and that's where went. I had my usual, jalapeno poppers and a cup of chili, followed by a Texas Ribeye and fries. Man, was that good. Holy shit. I had water and sweet tea to drink with the meal. The waiter we had this time wasn't as good as the waitress we had last time, less attentive, but that was our only complaint. Everything else was superb. I stopped in at Walgreens on the way home and bought two more cassette storage cases (the 3-drawer kind). It's almost 5pm now, I have to be at the gig around 8:45pm, so I guess I'm going to go try and take a nap. More later.

Band Practice JP was a bit late arriving to pick me up tonight, which kind of sucked since we only had a two hour practice tonight, instead of our usual three. Needless to say, it went by very quickly. We didn't do any jamming, just straight down to business. We worked on tightening up "Badge" and "Safe In My Arms", which we badly needed to do. Hopefully tomorrow night will be a good night for us musically, we're certainly due for one. I taped tonight's practice, which was good because I think I nailed one or two of my solos, did them exactly how I they should sound. Now I can go over the tape and get them ingrained in my mind. I need to get as many solos down as possible, and soon, because we're going to start making our demo next week. That's the plan anyhow. We're supposed to go over to Jimmy's so he can lay down his drum tracks (on a digital 4-track) and then in August, the month Jimmy is taking off, Al, JP and I will finish the demo. Since we're going to be doing all of this recording, it looks like we're not going to be playing this other gig we had lined up (for late July) now. JP and Jimmy said we'll just do it in September. I'm not really unhappy about it. They want a four-hour set from us and that's about all we have right now, so we'd have to play pretty much our entire repertoire, like we did the last time we played there. What sucks about that is, if we get people dancing on one song, we can't really move songs around to keep them there or else we'll end up with a very slow last set. Honestly though, I'm divided by the whole "dance thing" anyway. To me, getting people dancing is cool and all, but so is getting them to sit there, really listening to the music. You can get to people through their minds as well, not just their booties. I think that appeals to me much more, which leaves me at odds with the other guys. Whatever. I'm rambling now, so I'm outta here.

Thrift Stores I woke up around Noon today, much later than I would have wanted. I slept badly again last night, up several times to pee (I am getting old), and tossing and turning all night long. I got up, ate, watched TV a little, then showered, got dressed, and was out on the road with Mom by 2:30pm. First stop was Second Image, a thrift shop down the road from us. I saw online that they were hiring for cashiers so I put an application in there. While in there, Mom started a debate with one of the employess about how expensive their books were compared to Goodwill. I couldn't believe it. From there we went to Arbys, where I also turned in an application. The manager was there, but he didn't interview me, just accepted it and said "we'll call you". After Arbys, we headed over to the Salvation Army on Missouri where I found several tapes I wanted. I borrowed $5 from Mom and bought: The Cure "Boys Don't Cry", "Encomium - Tribute To Led Zeppelin", Pearl Jam "Vitology", The Police "Regatta De Blanc", R.E.M. "Life's Rich Pageant", Scorpions "Love At First Sting" (censored cover), Paul Simon "Rhythm Of The Saints", 'Til Tuesday "Welcome Home", U2 "Under A Blood Red Sky", and ZZ Top "Tres Hombres/Fandango" (2-on-1)... sweet! Mom wanted to hit this other thrift store down the road from there, so we went there next. I found 29 tapes there, some killer titles, but the most awesome part was that they were only $0.25 each! Here's a list of the tapes I bought (a few I have already and bought to re-sell): The Gregg Allman Band "Laid Back", "I'm No Angel" & "Just Before The Bullets Fly", The Allman Brothers Band "Win, Lose Or Draw/Idlewild South" (2-on-1), "Seven Turns", "An Evening With The Allman Brothers Band - 1st Set", "An Evening With The Allman Brothers Band - 2nd Set", George Benson "Shape Of Things To Come", "Billboard Top Rock 'N Roll Hiits - 1964", Jim Capaldi "Some Come Running", George Carlin "Toledo Window Box", Derek & The Dominoes "Layla & Other Assorted Love Songs" (remixed version), Joe Ely "Dig All Night", Ben Folds Five "Whatever And Ever Amen", Genesis "Abacab", Buddy Guy "Slippin' In", Daryl Hall/John Oates "Abandoned Luncheonette", Journey "Departure", Don McLean "American Pie", Monthy Python "The Final Rip Off" (2-tape set), Robert Palmer "Sneakin' Sally Through The Alley", Bonnie Raitt "Luck Of The Draw", REO Speedwagon "The Earth, A Small Man, His Dog And A Chicken", Boz Scaggs "Middle Man", Smashmouth "Fush Yu Mang", Bob Welch "French Kiss", and Sonny Boy Williamson "Sonny Boy Williamson & The Yardbirds With Eric Clapton"... wow! I put them on my debit card this time, along with a purple hat I bought for Mom. The total for everything, including a paperback book I'd found (Mario Puzu "The Godfather"), was under $10.00! How cool is that? OK, I'm off to chow now, leaving for practice within the hour.

Misery And Worry I went to bed too late last night and got up too early this morning... I'm very tired, mentally and physically. Physically because of the lack of sleep, but mentally because of my finances and my job situation. I called the spa place today and found out the hours are no good for me. I'd have to be up at 6am everyday, way too early for me. If I had a gig on a Friday night, I'd be going onstage at bedtime. Same problem with practice nights. So now I'm debating whether or not I should quit my band and get a good job or stick with my band and get a crappy job. It's a real dilemma for me. Mom is off tomorrow so we'll probably run around to a few places so I can put an application in (still no reply from HSN), but my choices are very limited. I'll probably end up at Arbys or Burger King... fast food... just what I want to be doing at 35 years of age. I think I'm going to try for Costco first though. It's a 15-20 minute walk to the bus stop every day and then a 20-30 bus ride, but I hear they are a great company to work for, that they value their employees and care about them (take a lesson, Wal-Mart), so it's worth it to me to at least try and get in there. In "Roadhouse Blues", Jim Morrison sang "The future's uncertain and the end is always near"... and that's exactly how I feel right now.

Sleep Deprived, But Still A-Rockin' I went to bed last night around 1:30am, read in bed for awhile, and then tried to go to sleep. It didn't happen. I laid there for a couple of hours before finally getting out of bed. I don't know what's wrong with me, as poorly as I slept the last few days, I should have been out like a light as soon as my head hit the pillow. Instead, I got up, ate, watched TV, and then, around 7:30am, I went back to bed and read some more. It rained a lot today and I managed to fall asleep, but then the thunder started up and I was back out of bed around 12:30pm. I tried to watch TV, but wound up sleeping on the couch. I slept until 4:30pm. I woke up tired still, even though I should be plenty rested. I just can't get a solid night's rest anymore, where I sleep straight through the night. I get my sleep in bits and pieces, like tablescraps, which only leaves me hungry for more. Something's not right with me. I did nothing worthwhile all night. I didn't pull, scan or list any cards. I didn't do any cleaning, vacuuming, laundry, nothing. I ate, watched TV (I finally saw "Road To Perdition" tonight, good movie), played guitar (while watching TV), and bid on some eBay auctions. One of the auctions I won is a 10-tape box set of standup comedy (David Letterman, Richard Jeni, Brian Regan, John Pinette, and more) which sounds awesome: It cost me just $9.99 (shipping included) and the seller says the tapes have never been played. Nice! I won a few other tapes today too, a 2-tape set, "The Very Best Of Meat Loaf" (one of the tapes appears to be unopened), for $1.21 and a sealed Billy Joel tape, "Streetlife Serenader", for $0.01. I got them from the same seller so shipping on the three should be about $1.50 (since it's listed as $0.95 each and the seller combines shipping). I've bid on three others from this seller as well (they've got another day or two left on them though). Last night I picked up a Wilco tape, "A.M.", which is very hard to find on cassette. I paid $2.75 for it, which is probably more than I should of (since I already have the CD and all), but the seller said it was like new and I love Wilco, so... What can I say? I love music.

Lately I've Been... Listening to: Very little this week. Watching on TV: About the same as last week and the week before. Poker shows: "Celebrity Poker", "World Poker Tour", "The World Series Of Poker"; Judge shows: "The People's Court", "Judge Mathis", "Divorce Court", "Judge Judy"; and of course, comedies: "Everybody Loves Raymond", "The Simpsons", "Seinfeld", "The Daily Show", "Tough Crowd", "Curb Your Enthusiasm", "Da Ali G Show", and "Real Time w/ Bill Maher". I also watched some "Fear Factor", and I watched "Fahrenheit 911" twice this week. Reading: I finished reading "Cannery Row" by John Steinbeck last night. I'd seen the movie version a long time ago (back in the mid-late '80's, I believe, at my Dad's) and it seemed a bit different than the book, more of a love story, if I remember right. The book is great though, a great story, great characters, and very well written. I'm not sure what I'm going to read next. Playing I've cooled it on the games lately. Downloading: "Fahrenheit 911". Jamming: I practiced with The St. Pete Project again tonight (Santana's band). We went over the three Santana songs we worked on last week ("Black Magic Woman", "Oye Como Va", and "Evil Ways"), "3 AM", "Long Train Running", "Blues Before Sunrise", "Proud Mary", "Old Time Rock & Roll", "Feelin' Alright", "Wild Night", "Moondance", "Message In A Bottle", "Crossroads", and "Every Breath You Take". I threw out "Fire", "Daytripper", and "Sunshine Of Your Love" and we played a little of each. I taped most all of tonight's practice. During the break, a friend of theirs came in and played drums. He jammed with Jon, Page, and I for a bit. It was nice to be able to improv again and most of it sounded pretty good. Of course, as luck would have it, not a bit of that got taped. Damn! The bass player, Angus, was talking about how he preferred we play the songs as they were recorded, almost note-for-note, and I let Santana know that that doesn't work for me. I told him I'd be happy to be their back-up guitar player whenever they need me for gigs and practices, but I just can't do the whole cover band thing. Mike said they have a lot of gigs lined up already, so I may be playing out with these guys fairly soon. I'm supposed to play with them again next Sunday. Mike's still finishing up working on the room, so there's no practice during the week this week, like I'd hoped. Jon gave me a ride home again (Mom drove me there). Working: I just finished looking through the want ads and it was slim pickings once again. I think I may try to get that Cafeteria Attendant job just to hold me over until something else comes along. It's only 2 1/2 hours per day with no insurance or benefits though. I'd be able to pay my bills and that's it. Buying: I've been good on eBay this week, just bought one lot of tapes for $6. I was bad at Best Buy though, spending about $35 on a DVD (Jimi Hendrix "Blue Wild Angel") and two CDs (Los Lobos "Ride This: The Covers EP" and Ray Romano "Live At Carnegie Hall"). I hated spending so much at Best Buy and felt bad doing so, since I owe Mom so much again. Selling: I sold a bunch of items this week, mostly low-dollar stuff though. I have about $60-$70 due in. I need to start listing again tomorrow, as I'm down to 607 items in my store. Eating: I told Mom "no more pie", so I'm done with Key Lime pie (for awhile, anyway). We had pizza and wings again this week, with soda, even more stuff I should be avoiding. No matter how much I want to start eating better, there's always bad stuff around (and if it's around, I eat it). Feeling: Mentally, I'm feeling stressed out a bit still because of my finances and having to look for work. I'm also worried a bit about my band. We haven't played together since July 3rd, much too long. I've asked JP about getting together to jam, but nothing's come of it. It's like these guys don't really want to, or need to, play. I, however, do. Physically, I'm feeling wore down and tired from switching up my sleep schedule and from not being able to get a full night's sleep. I was woken up early again today (Mike showed up to work on the A/C) and it's kicking my butt. Otherwise, I'm feeling ok. Planning: To get a job.

To The Contrary It's funny, I thought I had the whole weekend planned out. Here's a snippet from what I wrote on Friday night: Mike's coming by tomorrow to install a new A/C for us (Mom went ahead and bought the one his friend was selling). I'm hoping he'll be done by 2pm. I have several packages to mail out tomorrow afternoon. We'll probably hit a few thrift stores while we're out too. Sunday I jam with Santana's band again. I'd like to list another 80-85 auctions sometime this weekend. That's pretty much my whole weekend, barring any (unlikely) surprises. Well, for starters, Mike never came over today. He told my Mom he'll be over tomorrow now. I didn't mail anything out this afternoon, in fact, I didn't get there until about 9:30pm tonight (we just got back from the Tampa Post Office). We didn't hit any thrift stores either, instead, I went to Best Buy and bought a Hendrix DVD they had on sale for $9.99 (tonight was the last day of the sale) and two CDs (Los Lobos and Ray Romano). It still looks like I'll be playing with Santana, but I haven't listed any new auctions. I haven't even pulled any new cards to list. It's been nothing but surprises. My original prediction probably would have come true if I hadn't of stayed up so damned late last night. I started working on fixing tapes and I wound up fixing over 100 of them. By the time I made it to bed, Mom was getting up. The noise she made out in the kitchen kept me from sleeping at first, I was up to pee once or twice, Mom woke me up to sign for an envelope the mailman had for me, and finally, I got up to tell Mom I wasn't going to be mailing my packages this afternoon like I'd planned. I finally got some sleep this afternoon but was back out of bed around 5pm, still feeling very, very tired. I'm still feeling zonked out. In fact, I think I'm going to head on to bed (with a book) after I finish here. I think I am finished here.

Good Night I'm not in bed, where I should be, but at least I'm being productive. I've been fixing tapes for the last couple of hours. I have a ton of tapes (about 150 of them) where the little felt piece on the bottom has fallen off. I've fixed about 40 of them so far and am getting ready to start on another 20-25. These are all tapes I've gotten through eBay auctions, all of my own tapes are very well taken care of and don't have that problem. Besides adding a few more cool titles to my collection, I've also given myself even more tapes to sell, thanks to a tiny dab of rubber cement. It's been a pretty relaxing night overall. While I worked on tapes, I half-watched/half-listened to "Metal Mania", a couple of specials on The Darkness, and then a few episodes of Beavis & Butthead. Before I started on the tapes tonight, I watched a new episode of "Real Time w/ Bill Maher". I'm so glad it's back on. There really isn't anything on right now though, just infomercials and bad movies. I think I'm going to finish up this last batch of tapes and then head on to bed.

Friday I thought I was going to be able to stay up all day, but in the end, I crumbled. I was in bed reading by 9:30am and asleep shortly thereafter. I kept waking up throughout the day, got up once to pee, and was back out of bed around 5pm. I don't feel like I slept very much. I had both cats sleeping in there with me for most of the day, Jimmy at my head and Stevie at my feet. After I got up, I got showered. Mom was home by then and we ordered pizza and wings for chow tonight. After dinner, I played "Fahrenheit 911" for Mom. She sat through the whole thing, which surprised me. I thought for sure she'd bolt, especially during the blood and gore parts, but to her credit, she stayed put. After the movie we discussed it a bit, but her arguments weren't making much sense to me. She said that "innocent people die in every war" and seemed more outraged at the lady who lost a son in Iraq ("She was all proud of the military until it was her son that died") than at Bush and his crooked administration who sent the lady's son off to die for their own benefit. I think my Mom's part of a generation that was taught that the President was someone you can trust, period. I think she's like a lot of Americans who refuse to accept the fact that we are The Bad Guys to a lot of the world, especially in the Arab world. A lot of Americans are in complete denial over this fact. I think my Mom has mixed feelings about Bush, but at least the truth has been presented to her and again, to her credit, she's opened herself up to it. Hopefully she'll do the right thing come November and vote Bush out. We watched TV together for awhile, now I'm watching it alone. It's almost bedtime for her, and my "day" is just beginning. I'm so messed up. She sent me a new job posting for a job at the elementary school I attended as a kid, a 20-minute walk from here. It's for the Cafeteria Attendant position and I think I'm going to try for it. It's only 2 and a half hours a day, nine months out of the year, but it's a foot in the door, it would pay my bills each month, the hours are right up my alley (lunchtime hours), it would leave my nights free for music. As soon as I'm driving, which I hope to be doing shortly after I start working again, I'm going to get my own band started. I'm getting older and older, time's running out on me, and it's time for me to put my music out there. I may continue playing with JP's band still too, but I'll havbe to dump Santana's band since they do absolutely originals at all. I'm just not a cover-band man. Mike's coming by tomorrow to install a new A/C for us (Mom went ahead and bought the one his friend was selling). I'm hoping he'll be done by 2pm. I have several packages to mail out tomorrow afternoon. We'll probably hit a few thrift stores while we're out too. Sunday I jam with Santana's band again. I'd like to list another 80-85 auctions sometime this weekend. That's pretty much my whole weekend, barring any (unlikely) surprises.

Up Still I haven't gone to bed yet, and I'm not sure when I will. I'm pretty tired, but I think I can make it until Noontime at least, not that that'll help me much. I need to stay up until 10pm or 11pm if I'm going to try and change my sleep schedule again. I'd be comfortable doing like I've been doing, going to bed with a book around 3am and then getting up sometime around 1:30pm, if it weren't for needing a day job so badly. I haven't been up early enough to do much looking for work and that's not good. So... I'm trying to change my evil ways, yet again. Speaking of evil, I watched Bush, Cheney, Ashcroft, and company, the whole lot of them, in "Fahrenheit 911" earlier this morning (don't ask how). I've been dying to see it but I really haven't had the extra money to go to the movies and besides, I have no one to go with anyway. It's a very good film, and powerful, though a little too heavy-handed at times (typical of Moore documentaries). There have been claims made about this fim's accuracy (which have all been debunked or dismissed as nitpicking), but the truth speaks for itself. I'm bothered that so many Republicans are following the partyline and denouncing this film when so many of them haven't even seen it for themselves. You know, this film isn't about Democrats or Republicans, it's about Americans, all of us. The Bush administration has lied to all of us . They've sent the children of Republicans and Democrats alike off to die in Iraq for no good reason whatsoever. Forget your politics and all of that bullshit and go see this movie. Like I said, the truth speaks for itself. This film is important. It's a "must-see" film if there ever was one, and you certainly "must-see" it before you vote this November.

Thoughts & Stuff Mom and I took a ride over to the school and it's not very far from the main road, which is good, but it is a long way from home, which is not so good. Oh, I talked to my sister tonight. Usually when she calls, I'll answer the phone, she'll ask for Mom, and that's it. Tonight when I answered, she asked me "What's going on?" and it threw me. I said "Not much, why?", which threw her. We wound up talking for awhile, which we haven't done for a long time. She did something really nice for some single-mom with four kids up there. The lady had no money for groceries so my sister went out and bought her a bunch of stuff, which was a great thing to do, especially since she did it out of human kindness and not because she saw the lady's plight as an "in" to push her own religious beliefs (luckily my sister doesn't really have any of those). That's a giant pet peeve I have with religious charities. If someone needs help, then help them, don't use their suffering as an invitation to push your religion on them. It's false kindness. I talked to my sister about voting this year too. She's never voted before. Neither she nor her husband pay any attention to politics or to whatever's going on in the world. It's like, if it doesn't cocern them directly, then it doesn't concern them at all. I couldn't live like that, blind to the realities of the world. Besides, with school beginning next week, she kind of wanted to stay home and get ready for school. I guess I'm done writing now. I feel like I'm rambling.
